http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/Giusti, Giuliana 2015. Nominal Syntax at the interfaces. A comparative study of languages with articles , Newcastle upon Tyne, Cambridge Scholars Publishing (ISBN 978-1-4438-8024-4)  /nhttp://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/blog/post/decolonising-the-curriculum-in-theory-and-practice-seminar-two /n

		<div class="container" id="blogentry">

			<div class="row mb15">
				<div class="span12">
					<ul id="breadcrumb">
						<li class="first">You are here:</li>
						<li><a href="/">Home</a></li>

			<div class="row">
				<div class="span12">

					<h1>Decolonising the Curriculum in Theory and Practice: Seminar 2</h1>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/kasia-buzanska">Kasia Buzanska</a></h4>
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>
            <li class="twitter">
                <a href="https://twitter.com/share?text=Decolonising the Curriculum in Theory and Practice: Seminar 2&url=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/blog/post/decolonising-the-curriculum-in-theory-and-practice-seminar-two" data-social-text="Share on Twitter">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_twitter.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="facebook">
                <a href="http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/blog/post/decolonising-the-curriculum-in-theory-and-practice-seminar-two" data-social-text="Share on Facebook">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_facebook.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="email">
                <a href="mailto:?subject=Decolonising the Curriculum in Theory and Practice: Seminar 2&body=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/blog/post/decolonising-the-curriculum-in-theory-and-practice-seminar-two" data-social-text="Share via email">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icon_mailing.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
        </ul>
    </nav>
</div>

						</div>
					</div>
				</div>
			</div>

			<div class="row mt15 mb20">
				<div class="span12">
					<hr>
				</div>
			</div>

			<div class="row mt15">
				<div class="span2 hidden-phone quotation">
					 
				</div>
				<div class="span6">

					<article class="mb30">

						<p style="text-align: justify;">The <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26979">second event</a> from the &ldquo;Decolonising the Curriculum&rdquo; seminar series has made it clear that &lsquo;decolonising the curriculum&rsquo; is not a ubiquitous struggle but can hold a plethora of meanings ranging from cultivating understanding amongst students to &lsquo;being toxic&rsquo; to universities and turning the establishment upside down. During the second meeting, the focus turned from the UK to perspectives on the decolonisation of education and scholarship in the context of Latin America&nbsp; &ndash; a continent in which decolonising the curriculum means much more than having minority voices and multiple perspectives valued and heard; it involves re-gaining the links to the occupied space both physically and mentally, revitalising ancestral knowledge and ways of living marginalised throughout years of colonial occupation and subsequent domination of the West.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://www.fflch.usp.br/sociologia/asag/">Antonio Sergio Guimares</a>, Simon Bolivar visiting Professor at the Centre of Latin American Studies at the University of Cambridge, began the discussion by introducing us to the work of Guirrermo Ramos, the first Brazilian social theorist that openly identified as black, active in the 1950s. Ramos put forward a critique of what he called consular or colonial sociology, i.e one in which ideas were applied without &lsquo;local colour&rsquo; and posed a question, debated till the present, about the possibility of having a uniquely Brazilian sociology. The question evolves around the wider problematic around the universals and particulars of sociological thought. While there is not a straightforward solution to the issue, Ramos emphasised that the universals of sociology depend on its particulars. That the epistemology and ideas used will always depend on the problems in consideration and the kind of questions asked. Antonio Sergio reminded us that at the time of Guirrermo Ramos the questions and problems raised by sociology in Brazil were not Brazilian; modernisation was considered an inevitable process and society was analysed through a Marxist lens of transition from feudal towards a capitalist society. This situation led Ramos to stress the point, relevant as ever, that sociological research must engage with national reality and that foreign ideas should be used albeit not as a primary source of investigation but complementary to a sociology developed from the &lsquo;bottom up&rsquo;.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://www.ncl.ac.uk/sml/staff/profile/rosaleen.howard">Rosaleen Howard</a>, Chair of Hispanic Studies and Director of Centre of Latin American Studies at&nbsp; Newcastle University, spoke subsequently about the direct efforts to &lsquo;decolonise&rsquo; education in the Andes, focusing on the case of Bolivia.&nbsp; She discussed the intrinsic relationship between language access, discourse and social inclusion and participation taking us on a journey through the transformations that took place within subsequent educational reforms. Following the first introduction of bilingual and intercultural education in 1994, the indigenous could, in the words of an Aymara Education council member, finally &lsquo;have a presence&rsquo; rather than just being &lsquo;observers&rsquo; in the formation of their own education. While not everything in the garden was rosy with the government gradually distancing itself from the intercultural model and planning new reforms it managed to live on with reformation only taking place after Morales took office. The new educational law most differed most saliently from the previous with the inclusion of &lsquo;intraculturality&rsquo; &ndash; recuperation, strengthening, and cohesion within cultures &ndash; and an open call for a &lsquo;decolonisation&rsquo; of education.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Rosaleen underscored the importance of including the call for decolonising education into the official political discourse citing Colombia&rsquo;s indigenous educator&rsquo;s Abadio Green&rsquo;s assertion that if he dared to speak in his country in such &lsquo;big&rsquo; terms he would be called a subversive.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">One issue, acknowledged by both Rosaleen and the audience, is the difficulty of providing equal consideration for all the 36 groups forming the Bolivian &lsquo;plurination&rsquo; with the Chiquitano people (numbering around 180,000) incessantly unrepresented, not to mention the much smaller, mostly Amazonian, cultures or &lsquo;nations&rsquo;. Can there be decolonisation for all? Who are its explicit beneficiaries, who gets left out and with what consequences? How can decolonisation efforts be made as inclusive as possible?</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://www.sociology.cam.ac.uk/people/academic-staff/dlehmann">David Lehman</a>, Professor of Sociology, University of Cambridge and the final from the panelists, spoke about the creation of intercultural universities in Mexico. Such universities, albeit not explicitly &lsquo;indigenous&rsquo; were initiated by educators with aims of increasing indigenous participation in higher education both via their curricular content and locations. While &lsquo;decolonisation&rsquo;, unlike in the case of Bolivia, does not form part of their official discourse it lurks around within the universities&rsquo; rhetoric. David described their objectives as removing the autocratic, authoritarian characteristic of higher education and giving the people &ldquo;their culture back&rdquo;.&nbsp; Although most of the teachers do not come from indigenous backgrounds nor speak the indigenous language the application of the ideas of &lsquo;radical&rsquo; social theorists such as Leon Vygotsky or Paolo Freire has led the universities to concentrate on &ldquo;giving people a voice&rdquo; rather than passively transferring top-down information.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">The audience actively contributed to the discussion raising important questions about the legal basis, content of, and the indigenous response to propositions and occurrences of a potentially decolonising character. What does decolonisation really entail in terms of the details of curricular content and process of its implementation? Should the parties involved be held legally accountable for a lack of adherence to reforms? How can indigenous pride be promoted in environments where racism is still very much alive, as well as privileging participation over the potential alluring alternative of &lsquo;assimilation&rsquo; in reaction to discrimination. Although there is no straightforward answer to any of these questions, possible&nbsp; &lsquo;solutions&rsquo; emerge from different places. In Bolivia, apart from language instruction, curricular reforms involve the inclusion of indigenous worldviews and visions of history as well as community involvement.&nbsp; Rosaleen pointed out how in Peru there exist manuals with guidelines towards legal implementation. Moreover, with the law of prior consultation, indigenous communities affected have a say in their formation. Such guidelines can act as a legal reference when reform implementation has unintended consequences and questions of accountability are raised. David suggested that the absence of an explicit discourse of indigeneity in Mexican intercultural universities can make them more &lsquo;attractive&rsquo; for students at a structural socio-economic disadvantage, yet without an indigenous self-identification.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Overall, the discussion made it clear that Latin America emerges as a continent in which the hope of intellectual decolonisation is materialising into tangible actions and political objectives are positioning decolonisation not as a chimera, but as a realistic goal. Nevertheless, despite the efforts for a volte-face from Western privilege and colonial discourse there is still a scent of ambiguity around who will benefit from them and the precise direction these efforts will take.</p>

<p><em>This blogpost was originally published on decolonisingcambridge.org and is reproduced here by kind permission.</em></p>

<p><em>Find out more about the <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/decolonising-the-curriculum-in-theory-and-practice">Decolonising the Curriculum research group</a>, including forthcoming events, <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/decolonising-the-curriculum-in-theory-and-practice">here</a>.</em></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Contributor: </strong><br />
<em>Kasia Buzanska is an MPhil in Latin American Studies at the University of Cambridge and completed her Bachelor&rsquo;s Degree in Social Anthropology at the London School of Economics. Her primary academic interests revolve around education in the Andes and broader issues in cognitive and linguistic anthropology.</em></p>

						<div class="mt20 meta-content">
							<p class="meta"><i class="icon-calendar"></i> Posted: Tuesday 8 November 2016</p>
							<p class="meta"><i class="icon-user"></i> Contributor: <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/kasia-buzanska">Kasia Buzanska</a></p>
							
						</div>

					</article>

					<hr class="pb30">

				<h3>Stay Informed</h3>
				<p>If you would like to be kept up-to-date with the  events we hold at the Centre and around Cambridge, please join our mailing list</p>

			<div class="row">
				<div class="span12">

					<h1>Decolonising the Curriculum or Decolonising the Mind? Seminar 3</h1>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date"></h4>
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>
            <li class="twitter">
                <a href="https://twitter.com/share?text=Decolonising the Curriculum or Decolonising the Mind? Seminar 3&url=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/blog/post/decolonising-the-curriculum-or-decolonising-the-mind-seminar-3" data-social-text="Share on Twitter">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_twitter.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="facebook">
                <a href="http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/blog/post/decolonising-the-curriculum-or-decolonising-the-mind-seminar-3" data-social-text="Share on Facebook">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_facebook.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="email">
                <a href="mailto:?subject=Decolonising the Curriculum or Decolonising the Mind? Seminar 3&body=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/blog/post/decolonising-the-curriculum-or-decolonising-the-mind-seminar-3" data-social-text="Share via email">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icon_mailing.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
        </ul>
    </nav>
</div>

						</div>
					</div>
				</div>
			</div>

			<div class="row mt15 mb20">
				<div class="span12">
					<hr>
				</div>
			</div>

			<div class="row mt15">
				<div class="span2 hidden-phone quotation">
					 
				</div>
				<div class="span6">

					<article class="mb30">

						<p style="text-align: justify;">The third seminar in the powerful &ldquo;Decolonising the curriculum&rdquo; series looked inward at how our own minds perpetuate colonial ideologies.&nbsp; &ldquo;All research is autobiographical,&rdquo; Prof Debbie Epstein, a Professor of Cultural Studies in Education in the School of Education at the University of Roehampton, quoted one of her friends to open the session.&nbsp; And, thus, the Cambridge community was inspired to look inward to our own misconceptions, myths, and misguided ideas in an attempt to challenge the colonization of our minds.&nbsp; Epstein introduced herself as a Jewish South African, who came to the &ldquo;process of de-colonising&rdquo; from her experiences growing up during apartheid.&nbsp; Session co-leader, Sharon Walker, a PhD student in the University of Cambridge Faculty of Education, shared her own experiences in the struggle of decolonization of the mind: &ldquo;I&rsquo;m Black and I grew up in England.&nbsp; Need I say more?&rdquo;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><img alt="" src="/assets/general/Epstein-Walker.png" style="width: 225px; height: 225px; margin: 10px; float: left;" /></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Epstein and Walker shared stories that punctuated identity struggles within their families&rsquo; experiences.&nbsp; Epstein recounted the astonishment felt by her grandfather and young father when they recalled a miners&rsquo; strike in South Africa violently shut down (and shot down) by police forces, while the protest placards read, &ldquo;Workers of the world unite for a White South Africa.&rdquo;&nbsp; Walker recollected her father describing the first time in his life when he saw a white street-sweeper in England.&nbsp; It was as if &ldquo;something inside his mind turned upside down.&rdquo;&nbsp; In her own youth, Walker starkly remembers having to both apologize for and defend who she was on the school playground.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Walker and Epstein used a participatory approach to ensure the participants had time to both listen to each other and share their own stories.&nbsp;&nbsp; The co-leaders invited workshop members to identify themselves and describe how each felt in one word.&nbsp;&nbsp; All participants mentioned their desire to learn more about decolonization, although post-US election, the mood in the room was strikingly lacking joy.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><img alt="" src="/assets/general/Decolonising_Wshp_E-W.png" style="width: 391px; height: 250px;" /></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><em>[Description: word cloud epstein &amp; walker]</em></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Working in small groups, the participants were asked to find common definitions for the following terms:</p>

<ul>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">decolonising</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">pedagogies</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">dominant discourses</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">nomalisation</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">privilege (in relation to pedagogy)</li>
</ul>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">After an involved discussion, each group shared their definition or an interesting perspective they heard during the conversation.&nbsp; The whole-group discussion that followed placed individuals&rsquo; first encounter with pedagogy in the home, &nbsp;with &ldquo;parenting as the first pedagogy.&rdquo;&nbsp; Additionally, participants recognized privilege as knowledge of &lsquo;the codes&rsquo; of society.&nbsp; The idea of the importance of language emerged early and continued to be a theme in the discussion.&nbsp; As some participants felt they lacked the sophisticated vocabulary to truly express their relationship with de/colonization, one member of the group noted that assigning status to words, and policing language deemed as &lsquo;lower status&rsquo;, is a strategy that aims to exclude voices from discussion.&nbsp; Poignantly, she stated that, &ldquo;The system is gas-lighting us,&rdquo; by seeding doubt that our language, our words, and our ideas can ever be good enough to engage in the discourse of de/colonization.</p>

<p>Walker and Epstein shared with the group a definition of &ldquo;pedagogies&rdquo;:</p>

<p>&ldquo;Pedagogies &ndash; something both formal and informal; the unhidden (formal) and hidden curriculum; what we learn as &ldquo;common sense&rdquo; from the wider society.&rdquo;</p>

<p>To take the discussion further on our time, Epstein recommended we read Elizabeth Ellsworth&rsquo;s&nbsp; <em>Why Doesn&rsquo;t This Feel Empowering?</em></p>

<p>The workshop continued by exploring the pre-assigned readings.&nbsp; To continue your own work on decolonising your mind, please find the readings here:</p>

<p><em>NGuGi&rsquo;s Decolonising the Mind<br />
They Are Burning Memory by Njabulo S. Ndebele<br />
More on Rhodes Must Fall</em></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">To conclude the reflexive session, Walker shared the idea that perhaps, the process of decolonization is one that may be inherently violent.&nbsp; The reclaiming of rights, of spaces, of one&rsquo;s own voice necessitates returning power to its just owner.&nbsp; This idea implies that the current holder of the above may not cede what&rsquo;s rightfully ours peaceably.&nbsp; If so, we should consider the place and meaning of violence in our lives.&nbsp;</p>

<p>To consider the place of violence and justice in your own mind and life, the speakers encouraged Lewis Gordon&rsquo;s lecture on Fanon and Violence, which can be found here: <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7upDMigHgC4"><em>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7upDMigHgC4</em></a></p>

<p>Finally, Epstein and Walker closed the workshop in laughter and community, as we came together to watch Trevor Noah satirize colonialism. <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZJjEE_J6Xzc"><em>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZJjEE_J6Xzc</em></a></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">And, thus, may we all go forward to work on decolonising our own minds and supporting each other.&nbsp; In our work towards justice, we must not forget to take care of and to challenge our own minds.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Contributor: </strong><br />
<em>Tatiana Rostovtseva (Research Assistant, Cambridge Mathematics Education Project (CMEP), University of Cambridge Centre for Mathematical Sciences)</em><br />
<br />
Part of the <strong><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/decolonising-the-curriculum-in-theory-and-practice">Decolonising the Curriculum in Theory and Practice</a> Research Group at CRASSH</strong></p>

						<div class="mt20 meta-content">
							<p class="meta"><i class="icon-calendar"></i> Posted: Wednesday 16 November 2016</p>
							<p class="meta"><i class="icon-user"></i> Contributor: </p>
							
						</div>

					</article>

					<hr class="pb30">

			<div class="span12">
				<hr>

		<div class="row mb30">
			<div class="span3">
				<hr class="visible-phone mb20">
				<h3>Blog</h3>
				
<ul class="blog">
	

	<li>

		<div class="container" id="blogentry">

			<div class="row mb15">
				<div class="span12">
					<ul id="breadcrumb">
						<li class="first">You are here:</li>
						<li><a href="/">Home</a></li>

			<div class="row">
				<div class="span12">

					<h1>Perspectives on Decolonization from South Asia. Seminar 4</h1>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date"></h4>
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>
            <li class="twitter">
                <a href="https://twitter.com/share?text=Perspectives on Decolonization from South Asia. Seminar 4&url=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/blog/post/perspectives-on-decolonization-from-south-asia.-seminar-4" data-social-text="Share on Twitter">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_twitter.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="facebook">
                <a href="http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/blog/post/perspectives-on-decolonization-from-south-asia.-seminar-4" data-social-text="Share on Facebook">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_facebook.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="email">
                <a href="mailto:?subject=Perspectives on Decolonization from South Asia. Seminar 4&body=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/blog/post/perspectives-on-decolonization-from-south-asia.-seminar-4" data-social-text="Share via email">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icon_mailing.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
        </ul>
    </nav>
</div>

						</div>
					</div>
				</div>
			</div>

			<div class="row mt15 mb20">
				<div class="span12">
					<hr>
				</div>
			</div>

			<div class="row mt15">
				<div class="span2 hidden-phone quotation">
					 
				</div>
				<div class="span6">

					<article class="mb30">

						<p style="text-align: justify;">In the fourth talk of the &lsquo;Decolonising the Curriculum&rsquo; series, the focus turned to lessons from South Asia. The panel touched upon three different topics; scholarly traditions developed in India around decolonizing knowledge (Dr Subir Sinha), Pakistan&rsquo;s particular case of dealing with violence and decolonization (Mahvish Ahmed), and questions about continuing &lsquo;internal colonization&rsquo; in India (Ananya Mishra). The discussion brought to fore the challenge of conceptual and historical conflation in the region. Can all of South Asia be known to have the same &lsquo;kind&rsquo; of experience with colonization? What is the history of the people within these contexts? Can the current state and its treatment of some groups of people be seen as a kind of colonization?</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Dr Subir Sinha, SOAS</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">The panel started with Dr Subir Sinha, senior lecturer in Department of Developing Studies, SOAS. Opening the discussion, Dr Sinha deliberated on the emergence of subaltern and &lsquo;anti-modernist&rsquo; studies in India in the 1980s as a challenge to coloniality. The subaltern studies group grew rather influential, but was not without its critics. Latin American scholar Grosfoguel argued that early subaltern studies by using European theorists often reproduced Euro-centrism even as it sought to critique it. The &lsquo;new subaltern&rsquo; started emerging in the late 1990s, particularly in Gayatri Spivak&rsquo;s (1999) work as she started writing about the impossibility of assimilating indigenous movements into Western liberal feminism. The &lsquo;anti-modernists&rsquo;, Dr Sinha said included scholars connected with environmental movements, such as Ashis Nandy and Vandana Shiva. Another field of work emerged with the works of academics S.N. Balgangadhar and Rajiv Malhotra. Dr Sinha critiqued this group of cultural nationalist scholars for appropriating notions of decolonization. For example, Prakash Shah argued that the category of caste itself was imagined by colonialists.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">With this overview, Dr Sinha made two appeals; one pedagogical in nature, and the other conceptual. Pedagogically he pointed that students need to be encouraged to read this scholarship, along with those of Savarkar and Godse, to get a grasp of the work that has challenged dominant colonial thought. Finally, in conclusion to finding ways of reconciling these different strands of scholarship, he pointed to a need of developing hybrid ideas. For instance, he appealed to reclaim and reimagine ideas of enlightenment usually viewed as being European, and use them in works and movements of decolonisation. This, he claimed is a strategy often used by Dalit activists and other movements across the world. Hybrid models such as the caste-class complex in the work of Dalit Marxist scholars have been particularly useful.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><br />
<strong>Mahvish Ahmad, Cambridge</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Mahvish Ahmad brought the view from Pakistan to the table. While Pakistan is usually sidelined in discussions on South Asia, she argued that there are specific perspectives that can be gained from there. She emphasised on the links between knowledge and violence that often emerge in Pakistan in the context of the war on terror, which have implications for institutions of learning. Because of the particularity of Pakistan and its simultaneous attempts of decolonisation, she called for the need to draw parallels between different movements &ndash; decolonisation alongside desecuratisation; blacks movements alongside Islamophobia. Ahmad traced the history of decolonisation to the social movements in the Global South in the 50s and 60s. &nbsp;In propagation of such criticism, scholars may make unlikely bedfellows with ethno-nationalists, Islamists and the post-colonial state that denigrate Western as &lsquo;foreign&rsquo;. Despite the tension inherent in such critique in Pakistan, the need to recognise indigenous ontologies is significant. Ahmad in particular, discussed the work of Maulana Abdul Hamid Khan Bhashani, an Islamic socialist scholar, in East Pakistan (now Bangladesh). She also crucially interrogated universities as a site of critique of Western canon; emphasising Cambridge University&rsquo;s potential of becoming such a node.</p>

<p><br />
<strong>Ananya Misra, Cambridge</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Ananya Misra offered insight into continuing &lsquo;internal colonialism&rsquo; in the Indian education system. By taking the case of a tribal community in mineral rich Orissa, the conflicts between the state, corporates, NGOs and the &lsquo;tribal&rsquo; people were highlighted. Her analysis of the rise of a Sanskritised Hindu education, including the insistence on using Hindi as a protest against colonisation, drew parallels with Ahmad&rsquo;s discussion of the uncomfortable apparent agreement between scholars and Islamists on decolonisation. She discussed at length the attempts to &lsquo;civilise&rsquo; Adivasi tribes. The Vedanta schools (DAV) set up for children of displaced Adivasi population completely disregard and erase Adivasi animist culture and instead force feed Sanskritised Hinduism. The same corporate forces which evict the communities then &lsquo;educate&rsquo; the children by bringing them to mainstream &lsquo;culture&rsquo;. She also demonstrated how the &lsquo;othering&rsquo; of these tribal people continue, as they are often showcased in museums and local research institutes continue to view them as primitive. She also cited stories of tribal resistance; such as tribal use of religion to protect their lands, emphasising the parallel traditions of empowerment within the tribal culture.&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">The three different takes on decolonizing curriculum brought to question many different and conflicting views; starting from the role of history in the movement, the need to understand the &lsquo;kind&rsquo; of colonization that took place in the different parts of the world; to the need to understand what colonization, coloniality, imperialism and decolonization means. The discussion urged us to think about the nature, categories and histories as well as the contemporary region which is South Asia.&nbsp; It was thus not surprising that the talk finished with plans and promises of another series looking at other regions in Africa and around the world.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Contributors:</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Asiya Islam</em> is a PhD candidate in the Department of Sociology and a Gates Cambridge Scholar at the University of Cambridge. Her research explores the formations of class and gender in urban India.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Meghna Nag Chowdhuri</em> is a PhD Candidate (Jawaharlal Nehru Memorial Trust&nbsp;Cambridge&nbsp;International&nbsp;Scholar) in the Faculty of Education, University of Cambridge, researching primary school mathematics education in India.</p>

<p>Part of the<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/decolonising-the-curriculum-in-theory-and-practice"> </a><strong><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/decolonising-the-curriculum-in-theory-and-practice">Decolonising the Curriculum in Theory and Practice</a> Research Group at CRASSH</strong></p>

						<div class="mt20 meta-content">
							<p class="meta"><i class="icon-calendar"></i> Posted: Wednesday 14 December 2016</p>
							<p class="meta"><i class="icon-user"></i> Contributor: </p>
							
						</div>

					</article>

					<hr class="pb30">

            <li class="facebook">
                <a href="http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/blog/post/watch-khaled-el-rouayheb-a-discourse-on-method" data-social-text="Share on Facebook">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_facebook.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="email">
                <a href="mailto:?subject=Watch: Khaled El-Rouayheb - A Discourse on Method&body=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/blog/post/watch-khaled-el-rouayheb-a-discourse-on-method" data-social-text="Share via email">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icon_mailing.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
        </ul>
    </nav>
</div>

						</div>
					</div>
				</div>
			</div>

			<div class="row mt15 mb20">
				<div class="span12">
					<hr>
				</div>
			</div>

			<div class="row mt15">
				<div class="span2 hidden-phone quotation">
					 
				</div>
				<div class="span6">

					<article class="mb30">

						<p>Professor Khaled El-Rouayheb, Leverhulme Visiting Fellow at CRASSH for 2015-2016, delivers the <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26772">first of his Leverhulme lectures</a>.&nbsp;<br />
<br />
The science of &#257;d&#257;b al-ba&#7717;th or mun&#257;&#7827;arah emerged relatively late in Islamic history. Its roots lay in the earlier science of eristic (jadal or khil&#257;f) that had developed among early Islamic theologians and jurists (with some influence from Aristotelian topics and late-antique rhetoric). In this lecture, I will argue that there was an explosion of interest in the science in the Ottoman Empire in the seventeenth century. I will discuss the wider intellectual context of this development, as well as some of its consequences for the Ottoman tradition of logic.</p>

<p>&lt;iframe width="480" height="270" src="//sms.cam.ac.uk/media/2234952/embed" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" allowfullscreen&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;</p>

						<div class="mt20 meta-content">
							<p class="meta"><i class="icon-calendar"></i> Posted: Wednesday 11 May 2016</p>
							<p class="meta"><i class="icon-user"></i> Contributor: </p>
							<p class="meta">
										<i class="icon-tags"></i> Tags:
								
										<a href="/blog/tag/theology" class="ml10">theology</a><a href="/blog/tag/ottoman" class="ml10">ottoman</a><a href="/blog/tag/leverhulme" class="ml10">leverhulme</a><a href="/blog/tag/islamic" class="ml10">islamic</a><a href="/blog/tag/film" class="ml10">film</a><a href="/blog/tag/17th+century" class="ml10">17th century</a>
								
									</
						</div>

					</article>

					<hr class="pb30">

					<div class="hidden-phone">
						<div id="disqus_thread"></div>
						<script type="text/javascript">
							var disqus_shortname = 'crassh';

								dsq.src = '//' + disqus_shortname + '.disqus.com/embed.js';

							})();
						</script>

					<h1>City Seminar: 21 February 2012 - Urban Reflections - Filmic Narratives of Place, Planning and Change</h1>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">21 January 2012</h4>
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>
            <li class="twitter">
                <a href="https://twitter.com/share?text=City Seminar: 21 February 2012 - Urban Reflections - Filmic Narratives of Place, Planning and Change&url=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/gallery/audio/city-seminar-21-february-2012-urban-reflections-filmic-narratives-of-place" data-social-text="Share on Twitter">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_twitter.svg">
                </a>

						<div class="gallery-audio mb20">
							<object type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="350" height="110"
        data="http://downloads.sms.cam.ac.uk/mp3-mediaplayer.swf?file=http://downloads.sms.cam.ac.uk/1190757/1190762.mp3">
    <param name="movie" value="http://downloads.sms.cam.ac.uk/mp3-mediaplayer.swf?file=http://downloads.sms.cam.ac.uk/1190757/1190762.mp3&allowfullscreen=false&usefullscreen=false&allowscriptaccess=sameDomain" />
    <param name="allowFullScreen" value="false" />
    <script type="text/javascript">
    if (navigator.mimeTypes && navigator.mimeTypes["application/x-shockwave-flash"]){
    } else {
       document.writeln('<div class="errors">');
       document.writeln('<ul>');
       document.writeln("<li>You do not appear to have a flash player installed");
       document.writeln("<br />Please choose an alternative format from the alternative formats tab below</li>");
    }
      document.writeln("</div>");
    </script>
</object>

						</div>
						
							<h3>Description</h3>
							<p>Anique Hommels (Maastricht)</p>
						
					</article>

		<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/blog/post/from-analogue-to-aerial-surveillance-reading-the-history-of-political-imagi" class="title">From Analogue to Aerial Surveillance: Reading the History of Political Imaging</a>
		<footer>

		</footer>

					<h1>Barbara Cooke: dog training programmes in US prisons</h1>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">13 November 2013</h4>
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>

			<div class="row mt30">
				<div class="span8">
					<article>
						<div class="gallery-video mb20">
							<iframe width="420" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/KroYUpxg8Qw?rel=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
						</div>
						
							<h3>Description</h3>
							<p><strong>Season 2 Episode 4 of Cambridge PhDcasts with PhDcaster Barbara Cooke.</strong></p>

<p>Barbara Cooke is a PhD student in Criminology researching dog-training programs in correctional settings.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Contact details:&nbsp;<br />
Email <a href="mailto:bjc49@cam.ac.uk">bjc49@cam.ac.uk</a><br />
<a href="http://www.crim.cam.ac.uk/people/phd/barbara_cooke/">Department profile</a>&nbsp;<br />
<a href="http://cambridge.academia.edu/BarbaraJCooke">Academia.edu profile</a>&nbsp;<br />
Twitter <a href="https://twitter.com/bcooke121">@bcooke121</a>&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Cambridge PhDcasts are presented by John Gallagher and produced by Richard Blakemore and Ruth Rushworth with thanks to CRASSH.</p>

<p><textarea id="adlesse_unifier_magic_element_id" style="display: none;"></textarea></p>
						
					</article>

			s.parentNode.insertBefore(g,s)}(document,'script'));
		</script>

			<div class="row">
				<div class="span12">

					<h1>CSER Seminar Series - Prof Charles Kennel and Prof Stephen Briggs</h1>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">9 March 2016</h4>
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>
            <li class="twitter">
                <a href="https://twitter.com/share?text=CSER Seminar Series - Prof Charles Kennel and Prof Stephen Briggs&url=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/gallery/video/cser-seminar-series-professor-charles-kennel" data-social-text="Share on Twitter">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_twitter.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="facebook">
                <a href="http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/gallery/video/cser-seminar-series-professor-charles-kennel" data-social-text="Share on Facebook">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_facebook.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="email">
                <a href="mailto:?subject=CSER Seminar Series - Prof Charles Kennel and Prof Stephen Briggs&body=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/gallery/video/cser-seminar-series-professor-charles-kennel" data-social-text="Share via email">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icon_mailing.svg">
                </a>

    </nav>

			<div class="row mt15">
				<div class="span12">
					<hr>
				</div>
			</div>

			<div class="row mt30">
				<div class="span8">
					<article>
						<div class="gallery-video mb20">
							<iframe width="640" height="360" src="//sms.cam.ac.uk/media/2193366/embed" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" allowfullscreen></iframe>
						</div>
						
							<h3>Description</h3>
							<p><strong>From an event on 26 February 2016, David Attenborough Building, University of Cambridge</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.csap.cam.ac.uk/network/charles-kennel/">Professor Charles Kennel</a> is going to highlight the importance of acknowledging that climate change is not only measurable and noticeable by looking at global temperature, but that assessing a set of planetary vital signs plays a crucial role as well. By relying too much on one indicator, we risk that we over focus on it.<br />
Are there possibilities to use the tools at hand - such as observations from space and ground networks; demographic, economic and societal measures; big data statistical techniques; and numerical models - to inform politicians, managers, and the public of the evolving risks of climate change at global, regional, and local scales? Professor Kennel will be joined by <a href="https://earth.esa.int/web/eo-summer-school/steven-briggs">Professor&nbsp;Stephen Briggs</a> who will talk about planetary vital signs.</p>

<p>About the speakers:</p>

<p>Charles F. Kennel is Distinguished Professor, Vice-Chancellor, and Director&nbsp;emeritus&nbsp;at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography at the University of California.&nbsp;He was educated in astronomy and astrophysics at Harvard and Princeton. He served as UCLA&rsquo;s Executive Vice Chancellor, its chief academic officer, from 1996 to 1998.&nbsp;From 1994 to 1996, Kennel was Associate Administrator at NASA and Director of Mission to Planet Earth, a global Earth science satellite program. Kennel&rsquo;s experiences at NASA influenced him to go into Earth and climate science, and he became the ninth Director and Dean of the Scripps Institution of Oceanography and Vice Chancellor of Marine Sciences at the University of California, San Diego, serving from 1998 to 2006.</p>

<p>Stephen Briggs is currently the senior advisor to the ESA (European Space Agency) and the chair of the UN Global Climate Observing System. He headed the Department of &ldquo;Earth Observation&rdquo; (EO) Science, Applications &amp; Future Technologies of ESA at ESRIN (European Space Research Institute).&nbsp;Before joining ESA in 2000, Stephen worked as Director of Earth Observation British National Space Centre &amp; Head of Earth Observation NERC, UK (1994-1999), Head of Remote Sensing Applications Development Unit, NERC/BNSC (1986-1994), Senior Scientist at NERC Thematic Information Systems (1983-1986), and Lecturer at the Dept of Physics, Queen Mary College London (1982-1983). Stephen Briggs is also a&nbsp;Visiting Professor in the Dept. of Meteorology, Reading University.</p>
						
					</article>
				</div>
				<div class="span4">

				<div class="span12">

					<h1>Explosive Things (Things That Matter Seminar)</h1>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">13 November 2014</h4>
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>
            <li class="twitter">
                <a href="https://twitter.com/share?text=Explosive Things (Things That Matter Seminar)&url=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/gallery/video/explosive-things-things-that-matter-seminar" data-social-text="Share on Twitter">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_twitter.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="facebook">
                <a href="http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/gallery/video/explosive-things-things-that-matter-seminar" data-social-text="Share on Facebook">

                </a>

            <li class="email">

					<hr>
				</div>
			</div>

			<div class="row mt30">
				<div class="span8">
					<article>
						<div class="gallery-video mb20">
							<iframe width="320" height="240" src="//sms.cam.ac.uk/media/1842789/embed" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" allowfullscreen></iframe>
						</div>
						
							<h3>Description</h3>
							<p><strong>Simon Werrett&nbsp;</strong><br />
Theatre and Effect in Early Modern Fireworks</p>

<p>Much of the literature on early modern fireworks displays tends to treat them as texts, to be deciphered and read for their symbolic and allegorical content. In this talk I focus on the performative aspects of early modern pyrotechnics and the practical, material techniques used to create fireworks spectacles in the period. Under the heading theatre I explore the way fireworks were stage-managed and related to pyrotechnic images and knowledge in printed books and manuscripts. Under the heading effects, I review the performative properties of different kinds of fireworks such as sound and colour and the logic of early modern performances &ndash; the ways materials were supposed to relate to one another in order to produce effects. I conclude by showing how these performative elements were not only critical in making fireworks effective tools of state and court spectacle, but also had an impact on natural philosophy in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.<br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Haileigh Robertson</strong><br />
The Role of Gunpowder in Early Modern Science</p>

<p>Gunpowder was a subject of interest for many early modern experimental natural philosophers. Attracted by the massive physical power given off on ignition, the early moderns experimented frequently with gunpowder. Owing to gunpowder&rsquo;s most obvious application, in warfare, some of the experiments conducted had the intention of improving gunpowder&mdash;both procurement and performance. The early modern experimentalists however, especially those following Francis Bacon&rsquo;s (1561-1626) projected mode of inquiry, saw gunpowder as much more than a military propellant.&nbsp; Natural philosophers involved with the Hartlib Circle and early Royal Society, for example, proposed new ways of harnessing gunpowder&rsquo;s energy.&nbsp; Whilst gunpowder&rsquo;s utility was undoubtedly important for the early modern experimentalists, there was much more to be gained from the close study of the incendiary substance. Bacon and Robert Boyle (1627-91), for example, used gunpowder to resolve disputes over matter theory. Gunpowder experiments were significant not only because they were practically interesting. They occasioned theorising over fundamental issues in early modern science.</p>

<p>This paper explores the uses of gunpowder in early modern natural philosophy. I outline how gunpowder was used, why it was used, and the implications of its employment. Drawing on the reproduction of early modern gunpowder experiments conducted in collaboration with the Royal Armouries (Leeds), I examine precisely how gunpowder affected early modern experimental science. It will be demonstrated how gunpowder served the natural philosophers who employed it, as well as the specific challenges it posed. I argue that for early modern experimental natural philosophers gunpowder was not only about what it could do, but what it could tell us. Gunpowder was a source of potential knowledge</p>
						
					</article>
				</div>
				<div class="span4">

			<div class="row">
				<div class="span12">

					<h1>Labour Power, Consumer Power and the Degradation of Work - Willy Brown</h1>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">3 February 2016</h4>
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>
            <li class="twitter">
                <a href="https://twitter.com/share?text=Labour Power, Consumer Power and the Degradation of Work - Willy Brown&url=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/gallery/video/labour-power-consumer-power-and-the-degradation-of-work-willy-brown" data-social-text="Share on Twitter">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_twitter.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="facebook">
                <a href="http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/gallery/video/labour-power-consumer-power-and-the-degradation-of-work-willy-brown" data-social-text="Share on Facebook">

                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="email">

    </nav>
</div>

						</div>
					</div>

			<div class="row mt15">
				<div class="span12">
					<hr>
				</div>
			</div>

			<div class="row mt30">
				<div class="span8">
					<article>
						<div class="gallery-video mb20">
							<iframe width="640" height="360" src="//sms.cam.ac.uk/media/2167163/embed" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" allowfullscreen></iframe>
						</div>
						
							<h3>Description</h3>
							<p>A talk by Willy Brown&nbsp;recorded on 19 January 2016 at CRASSH, University of Cambridge, at the symposium <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26588">Technological Displacement of White-Collar Employment: Political and Social Implications</a>.</p>

<p><strong>About the symposium</strong></p>

<p>In recent years, the debate about automation and employment has taken a new turn. What has re-ignited the debate is the realisation that the process of &lsquo;combinatorial innovation&rsquo; in digital technology&mdash;the combination of massive increases in processing power, big data analytics, sensor technology, digital mapping and machine learning&mdash;has opened up the possibility that large numbers of non-repetitive jobs which require some cognitive skills may become amenable to automation in the foreseeable future. This kind of work&mdash;classically defined as &lsquo;white collar&rsquo; jobs in the UK (&lsquo;middle-class&rsquo; in the US)&mdash;represents a significant proportion of current industrial and commercial employment, and significant displacement of it by technology would be a major development for societies. Estimates of the potential disruption vary, but the best-known study (by Frey and Osborne) estimates that fully 47 per cent of the 702 job categories identified by the US Bureau of Labor could now be vulnerable.&nbsp;</p>

<p>At this stage, there is no way of determining whether the sceptics or the predictions are correct. This uncertainty, however, should not be the end of the discussion, but the beginning. The possibility that a significant proportion of middle-class work could be mechanised at the pace we have seen in other areas affected by digital technology is an eventuality that needs to be taken seriously, even if the probability of it happening is lower than evangelists believe. The existence of a stable middle class is a prerequisite for a viable democracy, and the prospect of it being destabilised is therefore of great interest to our Technology and Democracy project.&nbsp;</p>

<p>To discuss it we have brought together four speakers, each of whom brings a different perspective to the issue.&nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>Robert Madelin is Senior Adviser for Innovation in the European Commission&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Daniel Susskind is a Fellow of Balliol College, Oxford and co-author of The Future of the Professions (OUP)&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Willy Brown is Emeritus Professor of Industrial Relations, University of Cambridge and former Master of Darwin College&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Gerard de Vries is Emeritus Professor of the Philosophy of Science at the University of Amsterdam and a former member of the Netherlands Scientific Council for Government Policy, the think tank of the Dutch government for long-term policy issues&nbsp;</li>
</ul>

<p>This talk is part of the <a href="http://www.techdem.crassh.cam.ac.uk/">Technology and Democracy</a> Events series.</p>
						
					</article>
				</div>

							<li>
								<a href="http://www.chameleonstudios.co.uk/" target="_blank">Web Design by Chameleon</a>
							</li>
						</ul>
					</nav>
				</div>
			</div>
		</footer>
	</div>
</div>

			<div class="row">
				<div class="span12">

					<h1>Refugees and the Urban Poor: In Two Palestinian Enclaves (City Seminar)</h1>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">13 November 2014</h4>
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>
            <li class="twitter">
                <a href="https://twitter.com/share?text=Refugees and the Urban Poor: In Two Palestinian Enclaves (City Seminar)&url=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/gallery/video/refugees-and-the-urban-poor-in-two-palestinian-enclaves-city-seminar" data-social-text="Share on Twitter">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_twitter.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="facebook">
                <a href="http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/gallery/video/refugees-and-the-urban-poor-in-two-palestinian-enclaves-city-seminar" data-social-text="Share on Facebook">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_facebook.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="email">
                <a href="mailto:?subject=Refugees and the Urban Poor: In Two Palestinian Enclaves (City Seminar)&body=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/gallery/video/refugees-and-the-urban-poor-in-two-palestinian-enclaves-city-seminar" data-social-text="Share via email">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icon_mailing.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
        </ul>
    </nav>
</div>

						</div>
					</div>
				</div>
			</div>

			<div class="row mt15">
				<div class="span12">
					<hr>
				</div>
			</div>

			<div class="row mt30">
				<div class="span8">
					<article>
						<div class="gallery-video mb20">
							<iframe width="320" height="240" src="//sms.cam.ac.uk/media/1842779/embed" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" allowfullscreen></iframe>
						</div>
						
							<h3>Description</h3>
							<p>Dr Silvia Pasquetti, University of Cambridge</p>

<p><span style="line-height:1.6em">This paper builds on recent theorizing about refugee camps as urban sites and about the relationships between the urban poor and refugees (e.g. Agier, Malkki and Bauman 2002; Sanyal 2013) to connect and compare two localities of urban marginality across the Green Line between Israel and the West Bank: a West Bank refugee camp and the Arab districts of an Israeli city. Drawing on ethnographic research within and across the camp and the city it traces the historical and ongoing ties between Palestinian refugees and urban minority citizens while exploring their differing sense of injustice, politics, and morality. I argue that a focus on place (camp versus city) and legal-political status (refugees versus minority citizens) alone cannot explain how and why, despite their ethnonational and kin ties, these two segments of poor Palestinians differ in how they perceive and articulate issues of survival and politics. Explaining these differences requires exploring the forms of sociolegal control they experience in their everyday lives. Specifically, it requires studying their distinct relationships with the Israeli state&rsquo;s coercive agencies and, for the refugees, their protracted relationship with humanitarian organizations. The paper concludes by calling for more comparative research on the role of agencies of control in the articulation of practices and meanings of survival and politics in localities of urban marginality. A focus on the interplay between control and space can help bring the urban poor and refugees in the same analytic framework thus enriching ongoing urban sociology debates about urban marginality.</span></p>
						
					</article>
				</div>
				<div class="span4">

					

					<div class="links mb50">

					<h1>Relocating Urban Asylum (City Seminar)</h1>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">4 December 2014</h4>
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>
            <li class="twitter">

			<div class="row mt30">
				<div class="span8">
					<article>
						<div class="gallery-video mb20">
							<iframe width="320" height="240" src="//sms.cam.ac.uk/media/1859987/embed" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" allowfullscreen></iframe>
						</div>
						
							<h3>Description</h3>
							<p>Relocating Urban Asylum: Forced Migration and the Revanchist Production of Marginality&nbsp;<br />
<br />
Jonny Darling (University of Manchester)&nbsp;<br />
<br />
Abstract&nbsp;<br />
<br />
In 2010, the UK Home Office announced that it would be passing contracts to provide dispersal accommodation and reception services for asylum seekers to a series of private providers. This meant the end of asylum accommodation through local authorities in many of the UK&rsquo;s largest cities. This paper seeks to explore the impact of this shift in asylum provision and consider what this means for the relation between cities and asylum seekers in contemporary Britain. The paper draws on fieldwork in four UK cities (Birmingham, Cardiff, Glasgow and Sunderland), including interviews with local authority representatives, politicians, asylum and refugee support services and asylum seekers themselves. In considering this empirical evidence base, the paper argues that we may see a troubling narrative of political neglect, shrinking accountability and the slow recession of support services and expertise. As the realities of &lsquo;austerity urbanism&rsquo; have interacted with the privatisation of asylum support, so we are witnessing the emergence of new assemblages of authority and governance at the urban level. A limited concern with the social needs of asylum seekers, has been replaced with an increasingly revanchist agenda which seeks to both remove those seeking asylum from political debate and to maximise the economic gains to be made from dispersal. In the growing and emerging &lsquo;asylum market&rsquo;, I argue that the realities of asylum urbanism are far removed from the potential for political change so often associated with the image of the city as a site of refuge. This does not, however, mean giving up on the city as a space for critical political practices. Rather, it demands a reorientation of how asylum is politicised and an approach that takes seriously the informalities of urban life. In concluding, I draw on the experience of these four cities to suggest that whilst the revanchist practices of asylum urbanism gain ground, their margins still represent contested spaces in which the image of an irregular city may be kept alive.</p>
						
					</article>
				</div>
				<div class="span4">

	<meta name="description" content="Established at the University of Cambridge in 2001, the Centre for Research in the Arts, Social Sciences and Humanities (CRASSH) works actively with the Schools and Faculties across the University undertaking collaborations that cross faculties and disciplines in order to stimulate fresh thinking and dialogue in and beyond the humanities and social sciences and to reach out to new collaborators and new publics." />
	<meta name="keywords" content="crassh, CRASSH, Centre for Research in the Arts, Social Sciences and Humanities, humanities centre, humanities center, interdisciplinary, interdisciplinarity, conferences, seminars, lectures, research, fellowships, call for papers, early career fellowships, graduate, postdoctoral fellowships, visiting fellowships, risk, conference, modelling futures, challenging models, uncertainty, david spiegelhalter" />

	<title>Research &ndash; CRASSH</title>
	

	<meta name="description" content="Established at the University of Cambridge in 2001, the Centre for Research in the Arts, Social Sciences and Humanities (CRASSH) works actively with the Schools and Faculties across the University undertaking collaborations that cross faculties and disciplines in order to stimulate fresh thinking and dialogue in and beyond the humanities and social sciences and to reach out to new collaborators and new publics." />
	<meta name="keywords" content="crassh, CRASSH, Centre for Research in the Arts, Social Sciences and Humanities, humanities centre, humanities center, interdisciplinary, interdisciplinarity, conferences, seminars, lectures, research, fellowships, call for papers, early career fellowships, graduate, postdoctoral fellowships, visiting fellowships, risk, conference, modelling futures, challenging models, uncertainty, david spiegelhalter" />

	<title>2014-15 Programme &ndash; CRASSH</title>
	

	<meta name="description" content="Established at the University of Cambridge in 2001, the Centre for Research in the Arts, Social Sciences and Humanities (CRASSH) works actively with the Schools and Faculties across the University undertaking collaborations that cross faculties and disciplines in order to stimulate fresh thinking and dialogue in and beyond the humanities and social sciences and to reach out to new collaborators and new publics." />
	<meta name="keywords" content="crassh, CRASSH, Centre for Research in the Arts, Social Sciences and Humanities, humanities centre, humanities center, interdisciplinary, interdisciplinarity, conferences, seminars, lectures, research, fellowships, call for papers, early career fellowships, graduate, postdoctoral fellowships, visiting fellowships, risk, conference, modelling futures, challenging models, uncertainty, david spiegelhalter" />

					<div class="row mb10">
						<div class="span12">
							<h1>2014-15 Programme</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							
							 
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>
            <li class="twitter">
                <a href="https://twitter.com/share?text=2014-15 Programme&url=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/2014-15-programme" data-social-text="Share on Twitter">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_twitter.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="facebook">
                <a href="http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/2014-15-programme" data-social-text="Share on Facebook">

                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="email">
                <a href="mailto:?subject=2014-15 Programme&body=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/2014-15-programme" data-social-text="Share via email">

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">Programme</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Programme</h3>
										<p><span style="line-height: 1.6em;"><table class="table table-bordered table-striped table-hover mt20"><thead><tr><th>Conference programme</th></tr></thead><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25544">Plague and the City: Disease, Epidemic Control and the Urban Environment</a></strong><br><i>05 December 2014, CRASSH, Alison Richard Building, 7 West Road, CB3 9DT</i><br><p>This is the first annual conference of the ERC-funded project &#39;Visual Representations of the Third Plague Pandemic&#39;.&nbsp;It will&nbsp;bring together social scientists, historians, historical geographers, urbanists and epidemiologists to discuss and disentangle the interrelation between bubonic plague (<em>Yersinia pestis</em>) and the urban environment in both historical and contemporary contexts.</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25656">The Politics of Framing and Staging: Performance as Paradigm II</a></strong><br><i>08 December 2014, CRASSH, Alison Richard Building, 7 West Road, CB3 9DT - SG1&2</i><br><p>Framing and staging have historically been powerful metaphors with which to negotiate collectivity. This conference looks at ways in which performance is less about objects than the power of frames.</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25655">Does the Museum Just Preserve the Museum?</a></strong><br><i>12 December 2014, CRASSH, Alison Richard Building, 7 West Road, CB3 9DT - SG1&2</i><br><p>Issues of security and conservation repeatedly draw public attention to the practical problems faced by curators. Questions of repatriation and human remains draw public attention to the ethical issues faced by curators. But the job of curator also raised fundamental intellectual questions that neither the academic not the lay public are led to think about.&nbsp;</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25658">Grasping 'Everyday Justice': An Ethnographic Approach</a></strong><br><i>06 February 2015, CRASSH, Alison Richard Building, 7 West Road, CB3 9DT - SG1&2</i><br><p>This conference aims to generate a cumulative account of the &#39;everyday nature of justice&#39;. We invite theoretically grounded papers offering ethnographic insights into the plural nature of &#39;everyday justice&#39; across the globe.</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25660">The Total Archive: Dreams of Universal Knowledge from the Encyclopaedia to Big Data</a></strong><br><i>19 March 2015, CRASSH, Alison Richard Building, 7 West Road, CB3 9DT - SG1&2</i><br><p>Questions of the total archive cannot be answered from within any one discipline: they engage key issues in the philosophy of classification, the poetics of the universal, the ideology of political high modernism and the technolotgies of information retrieval.&nbsp;</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25643">The Places of Early Modern Criticism</a></strong><br><i>23 March 2015, CRASSH (SG1&2), Alison Richard Building, 7 West Road, CB3 9DT - SG1&2</i><br><p>This conference will bring together scholars working in departments of English, Modern Languages, Classics and Art History to look at the many different places of early modern criticism.&nbsp;</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25640">Pursuing Justice in Africa</a></strong><br><i>27 March 2015, CRASSH, Alison Richard Building, 7 West Road, CB3 9DT - SG1&2</i><br><p>The focus of the conference is on the many varied actors pursuing visions of justice in Africa - their aspirations, divergent practices and articulations of International and vernacular idioms of justice.</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25659">Print Media in the Colonial World</a></strong><br><i>16 April 2015, CRASSH, Alison Richard Building, 7 West Road, CB3 9DT - SG1&2</i><br><p>The conference will bring together scholars in History, Literary Studies, Visual Studies, Anthropology and other associated disciplines working on newspapers and periodicals in societies across the colonial world in order to explore common themes and reflext on the place of the newspaper in colonial societies.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25667">African Heritage Challenges: Development and Sustainability</a></strong><br><i>15 May 2015, CRASSH, Alison Richard Building, 7 West Road, CB3 9DT - SG1&2</i><br><p>The conference aims to explore the ways in which heritage can promote, secure or undermine sustainable development in Africa, and in turn, how this sustainable development affects conceptions of heritage in Africa.</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25666">The Drama of Intellectual Life: Performativity in the Study of Ideas</a></strong><br><i>29 May 2015, CRASSH, Alison Richard Building, 7 West Road, CB3 9DT - SG1&2</i><br><p>This conference explores new perspectives for the study of intellectuals. It will investigate how new theoretical and methodological approaches can reinvigorate the study of intellectuals.</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25668">Objects in Motion: Material Culture in Transition</a></strong><br><i>18 June 2015, CRASSH, Alison Richard Building, 7 West Road, CB3 9DT - SG1&2</i><br><p>What happens when material objects transition between different contexts - geographical, cultural, and temporal? Diverse scholars, curators, and creative voices will meet to explore this theme, around the world and across the millennia.</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25670">Sonorous Sublimes: Music and Sound 1670–1850</a></strong><br><i>23 June 2015, CRASSH, Alison Richard Building, 7 West Road, CB3 9DT - SG1&2</i><br><p>This interdisciplinary conference is the first dedicated to the musical sublime, c.1670&ndash;1850. Spanning the eras of Lully, Handel, Beethoven, and Wagner, this period witnessed dramatic changes in musical praxis alongside the rise to prominence of the philosophical and aesthetic category of the sublime.</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25657">Erotic Literature: Adaptation and Translation in Europe and Asia</a></strong><br><i>29 June 2015, CRASSH, Alison Richard Building, 7 West Road, CB3 9DT - SG1&2</i><br><p>Which aesthetic and cultural concepts inform the creative effort invested in its translation and adaptation? Drawing from various national and cultural traditions, film and literary scholars will come together to establish what divides and unites the erotic in diverse contexts.&nbsp;</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25663">Sound Studies: Art, Experience, Politics</a></strong><br><i>08 July 2015, CRASSH, Alison Richard Building, 7 West Road, CB3 9DT - SG1&2</i><br><p>The conference aims to facilitate dialogue between academics and artists/practitioners across the many disciplinary areas of sound studies.</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25665">Counting the Cost of Drink in Britain, 1830-1918</a></strong><br><i>17 July 2015, CRASSH, Alison Richard Building, 7 West Road, CB3 9DT - SG1&2</i><br><p>The conference will explore attempts to assess the social, political and economic costs of alcohol consumption in Britain.</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25661">The Making of Measurement</a></strong><br><i>23 July 2015, CRASSH, Alison Richard Building, 7 West Road, CB3 9DT - SG1&2</i><br><p>This interdisciplinary conference&nbsp;seeks to consolidate an emerging international community of scholars interested in the history and/or philosophy of measurement.</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25662">Sovereignty and Imperialism: Non-European Powers in the Age of Empire</a></strong><br><i>10 September 2015, CRASSH, Alison Richard Building, 7 West Road, CB3 9DT - SG1&2</i><br><p>The conference addresses the ways in which six&nbsp;non-European powers - Abyssinia (Ethiopia), Afghanistan, China, Japan, the Ottoman Empire, Persia (Iran) and Siam (Thailand) - engaged with European imperialism and struggled to keep their sovereignty.</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25664">Sex, Disease and Fertility in History</a></strong><br><i>28 September 2015, CRASSH, Alison Richard Building, 7 West Road, CB3 9DT - SG1&2</i><br><p>This conference aims to further our understanding of the role of the venereal diseases in influencing the fertility of populations in the past.</p></td></tr></table></span></p>
									</div>
								</div>
							</div>
						</article>
					</div>
				</div>

						<div class="span12">
							<h1>The Alchemical Landscape</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">Alternate Tuesday, 17.00-19.00 during term time</h4>
							
							<p class="meta">
								<span class="location">Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building</span>
							</p>
							
						</div>

					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Convenors</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Programme 2017-18</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="4" >Past events</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p style="margin-left: 40px;">Rise up! Rise up, Cormoran. Woden. Jack-of-Green. Jack-in-Irons. Thunderdell. B&uacute;ri, Blunderbore, Gog and Magog, Galligantus, Vili and V&eacute;, Yggdrasil, Brutus of Albion. Come, you drunken spirits. Come, you battalions. You fields of ghosts who walk these green plains still. Come, you giants!</p>

<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ---<em>Johnny &lsquo;Rooster&rsquo; Byron, in Jez Butterworth, Jerusalem (2009)</em></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">At the end of Jerusalem, Johnny Byron invokes a wide range of cultural, national and mythic figures to aid his &lsquo;curse&rsquo; against the local council. Although it&rsquo;s unclear whether this act &lsquo;succeeds&rsquo;, a wide range of contemporary artists, writers and film-makers increasingly seem to pick-up where Byron leaves off. From the revival of interest in &lsquo;Folk Horror&rsquo; to the cross-over between psychogeographic and artistic practice, from Ben Wheatley&rsquo;s A Field in England (2013) to Andrew Michael Hurley&rsquo;s The Loney (2015) this &lsquo;occultural&rsquo; representation of the rural works as both a link to the past and an articulation of pressing contemporary concerns.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">The link between art, landscape and the visionary tradition is, of course, ancient. However, the recent, post-millennial popularity of this type of work has helped to embed a register of supernaturalism into the creative culture concerned with the 21st century life of Britain&rsquo;s rural, coastal and edge-land areas. In contrast to the metropolitan focus that dominated writing of the 1990s and early 2000s (by the likes of Iain Sinclair, Zadie Smith and Chris Petit) one finds in contemporary work by John Akomfrah, Alice Oswald, English Heretic and Emily Richardson non-urban spaces populated by literal and figurative ghosts.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">This is the territory of The Alchemical Landscape.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Working as an interdisciplinary, multi-platform research project, The Alchemical Landscape brings into collaboration the Faculty of English and the Department of Land Economy. It has two intersecting points of focus: the artistic representation of the British landscape as an uncanny if not haunted space, and the use of comparable &lsquo;spectral&rsquo; language to speak about matters of environment, property and value. From economic ghost towns to geomantic visitations, the interest of the Alchemical Landscape project lies with the way these tropes describe the &lsquo;natural&rsquo; landscape of contemporary Britain and its geographic, architectural and symbolic histories.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Mailing list: <a href="mailto:thealchemicallandscape@gmail.com">thealchemicallandscape@gmail.com</a></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">For more information visit&nbsp; The Alchemical Landscape <a href="http://thealchemicallandscape.blogspot.co.uk/">external website.</a><br />
<em>CRASSH is not reponsible for the content of external websites</em></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Administrative assistance: <a href="mailto:gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk">gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk</a></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><br />
&nbsp;</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Convenors</h3>
										<p><strong>Convenors</strong><br />
<br />
<a href="mailto:yps1000@cam.ac.uk">Yvonne Salmon </a>(MA (Cantab), MRes FRSA FRGS FRAI, Dept. of Land Economy, Faculty of Law, Faculty of English, Dept. of Art History)<br />
<a href="mailto:rjer22@cam.ac.uk">Dr James Riley</a> (FRSA, Girton College, Faculty of English)</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><br />
<strong>Yvonne Salmon</strong> directs the Alchemical Landscape Project. She lectures for the Department of Land Economy where she has directed courses on law and behavioural economics since 2009, she is also an affiliated lecturer with the Faculty of Law (since 2011), member of the Faculty of English, associate of the Department of Art History and an affiliate member of the Centre for Film and Screen, University of Cambridge. Her interdisciplinary research on law, literature, art, photography and film mirrors the principle of solve et coagula found throughout the Alchemical Landscape Project. She is a fellow of the Royal Society of Arts, Royal Geographical Society and Royal Anthropological Institute and chairs the Cambridge University Counterculture Research Group. She was formerly a convener of the CRASSH Screen Media Group. She has been published by Getty, Cambridge University Press, Intersentia and the BFI, amongst others. She is currently writing on law, literature and the culture of the 1960s.<br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>James Riley</strong> is Fellow and College Lecturer in English at Girton College where he is also Graduate Tutor. He works on modern and contemporary literature, film and counterculture. Recent publications involve a multi-volume collection on the film and literature of the 1960s. He&rsquo;s currently at work on Playback Hex, a study of William Burroughs and the tape recorder. James is a Fellow of the Royal Society of Arts. He writes about his research and other matters at the blog Residual Noise.&nbsp;</p>

<p>---<br />
<strong>Faculty Advisors</strong></p>

<p>Dr Robert Macfarlane (Lecturer in English, Faculty of English, University of Cambridge )<br />
Dr Alastair Reid (Faculty of History, Life Fellow, Girton College, University of Cambridge)<br />
&nbsp;</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
