					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Apply for Funding</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p><strong>Graduate and Faculty Research Groups</strong></p>

<p style="text-align:justify">The Graduate/Faculty Research Groups programme supports groups of Cambridge graduate students and faculty members working together with a common interdisciplinary research interest,&nbsp; bringing together early-career researchers, established academics and guest speakers on particular research topics for a year of collaborative work. Groups range in size from reading groups to full-scale symposia. Experimental forms of engagement are encouraged. Since its inception in 2006, the programme has hosted 50 groups.<br />
<br />
<strong>The annual competition</strong> <strong>to apply for</strong><strong> the 2017-18 academic year is now closed.</strong><br />
The next competition (2018-19) will be open in January 2018</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><br />
<strong>Current Groups 2016-17</strong></p>

<ol>
	<li style="text-align:justify"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/in-search-of-good-energy-policy">In Search of a &#39;Good&#39; Energy Policy</a></li>
	<li style="text-align:justify"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/cambridge-conversations-in-translation">Cambridge Conversations in Translation</a></li>
	<li style="text-align:justify"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/ethics-of-big-data-research-group">Ethics of Big Data</a></li>
	<li style="text-align:justify"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/performance-network">Performance Network (CIPN)</a></li>
	<li style="text-align:justify"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/things">Embodied Things, c 1400-1900</a></li>
	<li style="text-align:justify"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/cybernetics-and-society">Cybernetics and Society</a></li>
	<li style="text-align:justify"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/decolonising-the-curriculum-in-theory-and-practice">Decolonising the Curriculum in Theory and Practice</a></li>
	<li style="text-align:justify"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/images-of-care">Images of Care and Dying</a></li>
	<li style="text-align:justify"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/photography-between-invisibility-and-the-unseen">Photography between Invisibility and the Unseen</a></li>
	<li style="text-align:justify"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/the-politics-and-paradoxes-of-transparency">The Politics of Paradoxes of Transparency</a></li>
	<li style="text-align:justify"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/alchemical-landscape">The Alchemical Landscape</a></li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify"><br />
To see the previous groups <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/research-groups/past-groups-archive">click here</a><br />
<br />
For further information: <a href="mailto:gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk">gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk</a></p>

<p style="text-align:justify">&nbsp;</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Apply for Funding</h3>
										<p>The Annual Competition to apply for funding for Graduate and Faculty Research Groups&nbsp; (academic year 2017-18) is now close.<br />
<strong>The next competition 2018-19 wil be open in January 2018</strong><br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><br />
The Graduate and Faculty Research Groups are the engine room of CRASSH&rsquo;s intellectual project. We are looking to support exciting, new ideas that need detailed exploration. Groups must come from more than one faculty or department; they must have an interdisciplinary question at their core. The form of meeting can be of any type and we positively encourage experimental combinations. Some groups have been very small &ndash; a dozen people; others have grown to be major seminars. Some groups host formal papers; others combine reading groups and discussions. But every group must have at least an hour each session for genuine discussion. Each group is supported administratively and financially to meet fortnightly through the academic year at CRASSH. Above all, the intellectual work of the group must provide a stimulating forum for a cutting edge question.<br />
<br />
<strong>Provision</strong><br />
CRASSH offers administrative support, funding and a venue to groups for one academic year. Funding of up to &pound;1500 per year is offered for relevant activities, as well as administrative assistance with events, publicity and budgets. Activities may include seminars, workshops, reading/discussion groups, short visits by guest speakers to Cambridge. Successful applicants are offered a regular bi-weekly, two-hour slot in one of the seminar rooms at ARB <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/conference-facilities">(see facilities)</a>, during term time for their sessions.&nbsp; Groups may also apply for one-day workshops or colloquia. A webpage on the CRASSH website is created for each group, which includes a brief summary of the group, convener information and the events programme for the academic year.<br />
<br />
<strong>Eligibility</strong><br />
<em>Graduate Research Groups:</em>&nbsp; Lead applicants should be Cambridge graduate students from at least two different faculties/disciplines. Each group should also be supported by at least two Faculty advisors from two different disciplines.&nbsp;</p>

<p><em>Faculty Research Groups</em>:&nbsp; Applicants should be two Cambridge CTOs/UTOs and/or postdoctoral researchers from at least two different disciplines.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">In both cases support will not normally be given to groups whose activities could be supported within a single Faculty. Details of activities funded so far and links to previous groups may be found here. Research groups will be selected by a panel led by the Director and Deputy-Director of CRASSH. The Graduate/Faculty Programme Manager will co-ordinate the selection process and inform the applicants of the result by the end of&nbsp; May.<br />
<br />
<strong>How to Apply</strong><br />
The <strong>Online Application </strong>can be found here in January 2018<strong>. </strong>Please do not sent the applications by post or email. <strong>Only Online Application will be accepted.</strong><br />
<br />
Proposals should give an account of the interdisciplinary nature of the research project and its contribution to disciplinary development. In addition, applicants should provide information about previous activities (if any), plans for future activities with a preliminary budget outline, and evidence of an existing network/constituency across University departments. CRASSH is keen to support wide-ranging activities and to encourage new collaborative initiatives that reach across disciplinary boundaries, including those between the sciences and the humanities.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Interested applicants should discuss their plans with relevant teaching and/or research faculty in the areas involved, and are also invited to discuss proposals with the Director, Professor Simon Goldhill, or the Deputy Director, Dr. Jan-Melissa Schramm.&nbsp;Proposals should be accompanied by two letters of support from&nbsp;referees, at least one of whom should be from Cambridge, and one of whom may also serve as the Group&#39;s Faculty Advisor in the event that the proposal is successful.&nbsp;<br />
Referees must be submit their comments via the online system by the deadline.<br />
<br />
<strong>Re-applying Groups</strong><br />
Groups coming to the end of their funded period are welcome to re-apply by completing the application form and submitting it, along&nbsp;with their&nbsp; <strong>Yearly Report 2017-18 </strong>(form will be found here) <strong>by ----- April 2018 (noon). </strong><em><u>Please include your report as part of the application (one document) when you upload to the Online Application System.</u></em></p>

<p><br />
For more information please contact: <a href="mailto:grad/fac@crassh.cam.ac.uk">grad/fac@crassh.cam.ac.uk</a></p>
									</div>
								</div>
							</div>
						</article>
					</div>
				</div>

				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Fellows and Lectures</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The competition for 2018-19 is now closed.&nbsp; </strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">In 2009 the Faculty of History&nbsp; received funding&nbsp; from the International Balzan Prize Foundation to establish an annual Lecture in modern intellectual history since c. 1500. The Balzan-Skinner scholar held a Visiting Fellowship at CRASSH&nbsp; for one term during the academic year. He/she presented the Balzan-Skinner lecture and participated in the related symposium during the academic year of attendance. This fellowship is now known as the Quentin Skinner Fellowship in Intellectual History since c1500.&nbsp; Like the Balzan-Skinner scholar the Quentin Skinner fellow will hold a Visiting Fellowship at CRASSH for one term, present the Quentin Skinner lecture, as well as organise and participate&nbsp; in the related symposium.</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Fellows and Lectures</h3>
										<p><strong>Quentin Skinner Fellows</strong></p>

<p>2017-18</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/avi-lifschitz">Dr Avi Lifschitz </a>(UCL)<br />
Philosophy and Political Agency in the Writings of Frederick II of Prussia.</p>

<p>2016-17</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/sophie-smith">Dr Sophie Smith</a> (University of Oxford)<br />
<em><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27189">The Nature of Politics </a></em></p>

<p><strong>Balzan Skinner Fellows</strong></p>

<p>2015-16</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/teresa-m-bejan">Dr Teresa M Bejan</a> (University of Oxford)<br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26651"><em>Acknowledging Equality</em></a></p>

<p>2014-15</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/anna-becker">Dr Anna Becker</a> (University of Basel)<br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26148"><em>Gender in the history of&nbsp; early modern political thought</em></a></p>

<p>2013-14</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/karuna-mantena">Dr Karuna Mantena </a>(Yale University)<br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/25480"><em><strong>Gandhi&#39;s Realism: Means and Ends in Politics</strong></em></a></p>

<p>2012-13</p>

<p><a href="http://www.gabepaquette.net/">Dr Gabriel Paquette&nbsp;</a> (The Johns Hopkins Univeristy)<br />
<em><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/24695">Romantic Liberalism in Southern Europe, c 1820-1850</a></em></p>

<p>2011-12</p>

<p>Dr Tim Stanton (University of York)<br />
<em><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/23267">John Locke and the Fable of Liberalism</a></em></p>

<p>2010-11</p>

<p>Dr Joel Isaac (Queen Mary, University of London)<br />
<em><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/24219">Analytic Philosophy in Britain and America: the Forging of a Tradition</a></em></p>

<p>2009-2010</p>

<p>Dr Hannah Dawson (University of Edinburgh)<br />
<em><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/24020">Normativity of Nature</a></em></p>
									</div>
								</div>
							</div>
						</article>
					</div>
				</div>

	<meta name="description" content="Established at the University of Cambridge in 2001, the Centre for Research in the Arts, Social Sciences and Humanities (CRASSH) works actively with the Schools and Faculties across the University undertaking collaborations that cross faculties and disciplines in order to stimulate fresh thinking and dialogue in and beyond the humanities and social sciences and to reach out to new collaborators and new publics." />

                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="email">
                <a href="mailto:?subject=Becoming a Research Leader 2016-17&body=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/becoming-a-r" data-social-text="Share via email">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icon_mailing.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
        </ul>
    </nav>
</div>

						</div>
					</div>
					<hr>
				</div>
			</div>

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Apply</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Programme</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="4" >Readings</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;">The CRASSH &lsquo;Becoming a Research Leader&rsquo; programme offers an intensive and structured process for thinking about and building research leadership.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Good leadership can makes things happen in ways that are truly productive and sustaining. Intellectual bravery and bravura are givens. This programme focuses on skills and ways of thinking that transform nascent ideas into fully-fledged initiatives, whether through a collaborative research grant, an international network or conference, or public scholarship.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">This programme will help you build the knowledge and qualities that make such leadership credible and possible:</p>

<ul>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">knowing the research landscape (now and predicted)</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">balancing intellectual commitment with epistemic openness</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">building resilience and greater self-awareness</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">identifying limiting and enabling assumptions (your own and others&rsquo;)</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">clarifying your strengths, blind-spots and ambitions</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">developing strategies for effective and timely decision-making</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">practicing effective listening and communication</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">understanding influence, networks and the usefulness of mentoring</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">managing competing demands (on your time, priorities, efforts)</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">working well with others, especially across differing working styles</li>
</ul>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The programme is intensive: a small group of people meeting for 3 full-day workshops over 4 months (November 2016 &ndash; February 2017) supported by peer-mentoring and a reading programme.&nbsp; There will also be small amounts of homework before each workshop.</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Participants in the programme say:</p>

<ul>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">&ldquo;It&rsquo;s transformative, game changing&rdquo;</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">&ldquo;[it] surpassed expectations&rdquo;</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">&ldquo;I have greater confidence, better tools for action, better self-awareness: what the programme offered is already making a difference to my career&rdquo;</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">&ldquo;The best &lsquo;training&rsquo; environment I have encountered&rdquo;</li>
</ul>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Places are (very) limited and only available by application.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Deadline for Applications: 12.00pm noon GMT on Friday 7 October 2016</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Further details, including on how to apply, can be found by clicking on the tabs on this page.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Hosted by the CRASSH Post-Doctoral Forum in conjunction with <a href="http://www.learning-for-good.co.uk/">Learning for Good</a>.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Convenor</em>s: <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/alison-wood"><strong>Dr Alison Wood</strong></a>, Mellon/Newton research fellow at CRASSH and co-convenor of the Post-Doctoral Forum from 2014</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/john-regan"><strong>Dr John Regan</strong>,</a> Research Associate, Concept Lab, CRASSH, and co-convenor of the CRASSH Post-Doctoral Forum from 2016.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Facilitators</em>: &nbsp;<strong>Rebecca Nestor:</strong> Rebecca has 25 years&rsquo; senior experience working with groups and teams in higher education and the public sector, including the universities of Oxford and Cambridge. She facilitates awaydays and residentials, strategic planning sessions and action learning, and has delivered a range of management and leadership topics for academic, research and professional/support staff. She is qualified to offer personality profiling and team building using the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator and the Team Management Profile. Following a first degree in English Literature at Cambridge University (1985) Rebecca achieved a Master&rsquo;s in Business Administration from the Open University in 2003. She is currently studying for the Master&rsquo;s in Consulting and Leading in Organisations at the Tavistock.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Anne Augustine:</strong> Anne has a multi sector and international career spanning information technology, sustainable development and business psychology. Over the last few years she has worked as a leadership development and organisational consultant; as well as an innovation and partnerships manager for a regional economic development body. In this role she works with research institutions to accelerate local engagement, impact and commercialisation. Anne was educated at the University of Oxford, University of Cambridge and King&rsquo;s College London. She is an EMCC-certified executive coach and group facilitator, and is accredited in psychometric personality tools (NEO PI-R, BPS Level A and B). Anne has professional interests in social psychology, design thinking and improvisational practice.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Logistics</em>: Programme workshops will be held at the Post-Doc Centre Mill Lane and on the Sidgwick Site, West Rd, Cambridge.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Costs</em>: All costs of the workshop (facilities, catering, materials) will be covered by CRASSH. We regret however that we cannot cover costs for transport or accommodation.</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Apply</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>THIS COMPETITON HAS NOW CLOSED.</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">YOU WILL BE NOTIFIED BY EMAIL IN MID OCTOBER 2016 IF YOU HAVE BEEN SUCCESSFUL IN SECURING A PLACE.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">By completing this application you are agreeing to commit to attending the full set of workshops, outlined on the Programme tab on this page.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Before applying please read the following points carefully;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Eligibility</strong>:</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">You are only eligible to attend if you:</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">- are currently a postdoctoral researcher in the Arts, Humanities and Social Sciences at the University of Cambridge, and will be in post for the duration of the programme;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">- have at least 2 years postdoctoral experience (in Cambridge or elsewhere, or both) ;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">- and can demonstrate current or pending leadership responsibility: for example, convening a major international conference; convening a research network; taking up responsibilities for leading people in a research or departmental setting (this does not include supervising PhD students); being Co-I or PI on a research project (it doesn&#39;t have to be a large grant or project but you should be able to demonstrate significant intellectual ownership); serving on boards or executives of scholarly associations or journals</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>How to Apply</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Application can be made through the CRASSH<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/applications/position/view/133"> </a><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/applications/position/view/151">online application system</a> only. You will be asked to attach a 2-page CV (PDF) and submit a statement (of up to 500 words) outlining why you would like a place on the programme, and your current or pending leadership responsibilities. We are unable to accept emailed or posted applications.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">When you register for the first time you will receive a confirmation email with a link to continue the application online.&nbsp; To apply please click <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/applications/position/view/151">here</a><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/applications/position/view/133">.</a></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Application and Cancellation</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">If your application is accepted, you will be obliged to attend the full programme.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Submission of this form does not secure a place on the programme. If your application is accepted, any subsequent cancellations must be made no later than 5.00 pm on 28 October 2016.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">(&nbsp; )&nbsp; Please tick here if you have read, understood and agree to the above terms and conditions for &lsquo;Becoming a Research Leader 2016/17.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/applications/position/view/151">Online Application</a></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Programme</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;">Tuesday 15 November 2016, 9.15am-4.30pm</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27006"><strong>Workshop 1: The personal and academic landscape</strong></a></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Focusing on: the concept of good research leadership; the research landscape now and predicted (challenges, likely pressure points, opportunities); your intellectual and professional identity, and development</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Wednesday 25 January 2017, 9.15am-4.30pm</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27009"><strong>Workshop 2: Principled and self-aware leadership</strong></a></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Focusing on: values, understanding personality types and differences; leadership styles and strengths; self-care; cultivating influence; skills (listening, prioritizing, managing)</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Thursday 23 February 2017, 9.15am-4.30pm</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27010"><strong>Workshop 3: Working productively with others</strong></a></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Focusing on: creating productive teams; enabling productive thinking in groups; handling conflict; building better networks; understanding working styles</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="4" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Readings</h3>
										<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/assets/general/Mentorship_and_sponsorship_%28The_New_Academic%29.pdf">&lsquo;Successful Approaches to Mentorship and Sponsorship&rsquo;. Shelda Debowski <em>The New Academic: A Strategic Handbook</em>. Open University Press, 2012 (p36-45)</a></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Anthony Grafton <em>Worlds Made with Words: Scholarship and&nbsp;Community&nbsp;in the Modern&nbsp;West</em> (Harvard, 2009).</p>

<p>[Of particular relevance: Chapter 1 &lsquo;&rsquo;A Sketch of a Lost Continent: The Republic of Letters&rsquo;; Ch 13 &lsquo;The Public Intellectual and the American University&rsquo;; Ch 15 &lsquo;Codex in Crisis: The Book Dematerialises&rsquo;]</p>

<p>Bill Readings<em>. The University in Ruins</em>. Harvard University Press, 1996.&nbsp;</p>

<p>[Of Particular Relevance: Ch 2. &lsquo;The Idea of Excellence&rsquo; (21-43)]</p>

<p><a href="http://raley.english.ucsb.edu/wp-content2/uploads/234/Readings.pdf">http://raley.english.ucsb.edu/wp-content2/uploads/234/Readings.pdf</a></p>

<p>Hefei Statement on &ldquo;The Ten Characteristics of Contemporary Research Universities&rdquo;. Announced by the League of European Research Universities (LERU), the Association of American Universities (AAU), the Consortium of China Research Universities (C9) and the Group of Eight Australia (Go8). Munich, October 2013. (6 pages)</p>

<p><a href="http://www.leru.org/files/news/Hefei_statement.pdf">http://www.leru.org/files/news/Hefei_statement.pdf</a></p>

<p>Nancy Kline <em>Time to&nbsp;Think: Listening to Ignite the Human Mind.</em> Octopus Publishing Group, 2015</p>

<p>A summary can be found here: <a href="http://blog.soton.ac.uk/mentoring/files/2013/03/Introduction-to-The-Thinking-Environment.pdf">http://blog.soton.ac.uk/mentoring/files/2013/03/Introduction-to-The-Thinking-Environment.pdf</a></p>

<p>Rosalind Gill. &ldquo;Breaking the silence: The hidden injuries of the neoliberal university&rdquo;. in Flood,R. &amp; Gill,R. (Eds.) <em>Secrecy and Silence in the Research Process: Feminist Reflections</em>. Routledge, 2009</p>

<p><a href="http://diafaneia.ee.auth.gr/sites/default/files/silence.pdf">http://diafaneia.ee.auth.gr/sites/default/files/silence.pdf</a></p>

<p>Michael Barber, Katelyn Donnelly and Saad Rivzi. <em>An Avalanche Is Coming: Higher Education and the Revolution Ahead</em>. Institute for Public Policy Research, London. Web.</p>

<p><a href="http://www.ippr.org/files/images/media/files/publication/2013/04/avalanche-is-coming_Mar2013_10432.pdf?noredirect=1">http://www.ippr.org/files/images/media/files/publication/2013/04/avalanche-is-coming_Mar2013_10432.pdf?noredirect=1</a></p>
									</div>

						<div class="span12">
							<h1>Becoming a Research Leader 2016-17</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							
							 
						</div>

					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Apply</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Programme</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="4" >Readings</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;">The CRASSH &lsquo;Becoming a Research Leader&rsquo; programme offers an intensive and structured process for thinking about and building research leadership.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Good leadership can makes things happen in ways that are truly productive and sustaining. Intellectual bravery and bravura are givens. This programme focuses on skills and ways of thinking that transform nascent ideas into fully-fledged initiatives, whether through a collaborative research grant, an international network or conference, or public scholarship.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">This programme will help you build the knowledge and qualities that make such leadership credible and possible:</p>

<ul>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">knowing the research landscape (now and predicted)</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">balancing intellectual commitment with epistemic openness</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">building resilience and greater self-awareness</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">identifying limiting and enabling assumptions (your own and others&rsquo;)</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">clarifying your strengths, blind-spots and ambitions</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">developing strategies for effective and timely decision-making</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">practicing effective listening and communication</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">understanding influence, networks and the usefulness of mentoring</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">managing competing demands (on your time, priorities, efforts)</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">working well with others, especially across differing working styles</li>
</ul>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The programme is intensive: a small group of people meeting for 3 full-day workshops over 4 months (November 2016 &ndash; February 2017) supported by peer-mentoring and a reading programme.&nbsp; There will also be small amounts of homework before each workshop.</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Participants in the programme say:</p>

<ul>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">&ldquo;It&rsquo;s transformative, game changing&rdquo;</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">&ldquo;[it] surpassed expectations&rdquo;</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">&ldquo;I have greater confidence, better tools for action, better self-awareness: what the programme offered is already making a difference to my career&rdquo;</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">&ldquo;The best &lsquo;training&rsquo; environment I have encountered&rdquo;</li>
</ul>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Places are (very) limited and only available by application.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Deadline for Applications: 12.00pm noon GMT on Friday 7 October 2016</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Further details, including on how to apply, can be found by clicking on the tabs on this page.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Hosted by the CRASSH Post-Doctoral Forum in conjunction with <a href="http://www.learning-for-good.co.uk/">Learning for Good</a>.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Convenor</em>s: <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/alison-wood"><strong>Dr Alison Wood</strong></a>, Mellon/Newton research fellow at CRASSH and co-convenor of the Post-Doctoral Forum from 2014</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/john-regan"><strong>Dr John Regan</strong>,</a> Research Associate, Concept Lab, CRASSH, and co-convenor of the CRASSH Post-Doctoral Forum from 2016.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Facilitators</em>: &nbsp;<strong>Rebecca Nestor:</strong> Rebecca has 25 years&rsquo; senior experience working with groups and teams in higher education and the public sector, including the universities of Oxford and Cambridge. She facilitates awaydays and residentials, strategic planning sessions and action learning, and has delivered a range of management and leadership topics for academic, research and professional/support staff. She is qualified to offer personality profiling and team building using the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator and the Team Management Profile. Following a first degree in English Literature at Cambridge University (1985) Rebecca achieved a Master&rsquo;s in Business Administration from the Open University in 2003. She is currently studying for the Master&rsquo;s in Consulting and Leading in Organisations at the Tavistock.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Anne Augustine:</strong> Anne has a multi sector and international career spanning information technology, sustainable development and business psychology. Over the last few years she has worked as a leadership development and organisational consultant; as well as an innovation and partnerships manager for a regional economic development body. In this role she works with research institutions to accelerate local engagement, impact and commercialisation. Anne was educated at the University of Oxford, University of Cambridge and King&rsquo;s College London. She is an EMCC-certified executive coach and group facilitator, and is accredited in psychometric personality tools (NEO PI-R, BPS Level A and B). Anne has professional interests in social psychology, design thinking and improvisational practice.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Logistics</em>: Programme workshops will be held at the Post-Doc Centre Mill Lane and on the Sidgwick Site, West Rd, Cambridge.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Costs</em>: All costs of the workshop (facilities, catering, materials) will be covered by CRASSH. We regret however that we cannot cover costs for transport or accommodation.</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Apply</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>THIS COMPETITON HAS NOW CLOSED.</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">YOU WILL BE NOTIFIED BY EMAIL IN MID OCTOBER 2016 IF YOU HAVE BEEN SUCCESSFUL IN SECURING A PLACE.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">By completing this application you are agreeing to commit to attending the full set of workshops, outlined on the Programme tab on this page.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Before applying please read the following points carefully;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Eligibility</strong>:</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">You are only eligible to attend if you:</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">- are currently a postdoctoral researcher in the Arts, Humanities and Social Sciences at the University of Cambridge, and will be in post for the duration of the programme;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">- have at least 2 years postdoctoral experience (in Cambridge or elsewhere, or both) ;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">- and can demonstrate current or pending leadership responsibility: for example, convening a major international conference; convening a research network; taking up responsibilities for leading people in a research or departmental setting (this does not include supervising PhD students); being Co-I or PI on a research project (it doesn&#39;t have to be a large grant or project but you should be able to demonstrate significant intellectual ownership); serving on boards or executives of scholarly associations or journals</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>How to Apply</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Application can be made through the CRASSH<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/applications/position/view/133"> </a><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/applications/position/view/151">online application system</a> only. You will be asked to attach a 2-page CV (PDF) and submit a statement (of up to 500 words) outlining why you would like a place on the programme, and your current or pending leadership responsibilities. We are unable to accept emailed or posted applications.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">When you register for the first time you will receive a confirmation email with a link to continue the application online.&nbsp; To apply please click <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/applications/position/view/151">here</a><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/applications/position/view/133">.</a></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Application and Cancellation</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">If your application is accepted, you will be obliged to attend the full programme.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Submission of this form does not secure a place on the programme. If your application is accepted, any subsequent cancellations must be made no later than 5.00 pm on 28 October 2016.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">(&nbsp; )&nbsp; Please tick here if you have read, understood and agree to the above terms and conditions for &lsquo;Becoming a Research Leader 2016/17.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/applications/position/view/151">Online Application</a></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Programme</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;">Tuesday 15 November 2016, 9.15am-4.30pm</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27006"><strong>Workshop 1: The personal and academic landscape</strong></a></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Focusing on: the concept of good research leadership; the research landscape now and predicted (challenges, likely pressure points, opportunities); your intellectual and professional identity, and development</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Wednesday 25 January 2017, 9.15am-4.30pm</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27009"><strong>Workshop 2: Principled and self-aware leadership</strong></a></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Focusing on: values, understanding personality types and differences; leadership styles and strengths; self-care; cultivating influence; skills (listening, prioritizing, managing)</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Thursday 23 February 2017, 9.15am-4.30pm</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27010"><strong>Workshop 3: Working productively with others</strong></a></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Focusing on: creating productive teams; enabling productive thinking in groups; handling conflict; building better networks; understanding working styles</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="4" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Readings</h3>
										<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/assets/general/Mentorship_and_sponsorship_%28The_New_Academic%29.pdf">&lsquo;Successful Approaches to Mentorship and Sponsorship&rsquo;. Shelda Debowski <em>The New Academic: A Strategic Handbook</em>. Open University Press, 2012 (p36-45)</a></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Anthony Grafton <em>Worlds Made with Words: Scholarship and&nbsp;Community&nbsp;in the Modern&nbsp;West</em> (Harvard, 2009).</p>

<p>[Of particular relevance: Chapter 1 &lsquo;&rsquo;A Sketch of a Lost Continent: The Republic of Letters&rsquo;; Ch 13 &lsquo;The Public Intellectual and the American University&rsquo;; Ch 15 &lsquo;Codex in Crisis: The Book Dematerialises&rsquo;]</p>

<p>Bill Readings<em>. The University in Ruins</em>. Harvard University Press, 1996.&nbsp;</p>

<p>[Of Particular Relevance: Ch 2. &lsquo;The Idea of Excellence&rsquo; (21-43)]</p>

<p><a href="http://raley.english.ucsb.edu/wp-content2/uploads/234/Readings.pdf">http://raley.english.ucsb.edu/wp-content2/uploads/234/Readings.pdf</a></p>

<p>Hefei Statement on &ldquo;The Ten Characteristics of Contemporary Research Universities&rdquo;. Announced by the League of European Research Universities (LERU), the Association of American Universities (AAU), the Consortium of China Research Universities (C9) and the Group of Eight Australia (Go8). Munich, October 2013. (6 pages)</p>

<p><a href="http://www.leru.org/files/news/Hefei_statement.pdf">http://www.leru.org/files/news/Hefei_statement.pdf</a></p>

<p>Nancy Kline <em>Time to&nbsp;Think: Listening to Ignite the Human Mind.</em> Octopus Publishing Group, 2015</p>

<p>A summary can be found here: <a href="http://blog.soton.ac.uk/mentoring/files/2013/03/Introduction-to-The-Thinking-Environment.pdf">http://blog.soton.ac.uk/mentoring/files/2013/03/Introduction-to-The-Thinking-Environment.pdf</a></p>

<p>Rosalind Gill. &ldquo;Breaking the silence: The hidden injuries of the neoliberal university&rdquo;. in Flood,R. &amp; Gill,R. (Eds.) <em>Secrecy and Silence in the Research Process: Feminist Reflections</em>. Routledge, 2009</p>

<p><a href="http://diafaneia.ee.auth.gr/sites/default/files/silence.pdf">http://diafaneia.ee.auth.gr/sites/default/files/silence.pdf</a></p>

<p>Michael Barber, Katelyn Donnelly and Saad Rivzi. <em>An Avalanche Is Coming: Higher Education and the Revolution Ahead</em>. Institute for Public Policy Research, London. Web.</p>

<p><a href="http://www.ippr.org/files/images/media/files/publication/2013/04/avalanche-is-coming_Mar2013_10432.pdf?noredirect=1">http://www.ippr.org/files/images/media/files/publication/2013/04/avalanche-is-coming_Mar2013_10432.pdf?noredirect=1</a></p>
									</div>

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >People</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Events</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;">2012&ndash;2017<br />
CRASSH, University of Cambridge</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">This project will investigate the interface between the study of the bible and the study of antiquity in the nineteenth century. These two areas &ndash; the bible and classics &ndash; are central to the intellectual world of the nineteenth century, a source of knowledge, contention, and authority both as discrete topics, and, more importantly, in relation to and in competition with one another. It is impossible to understand Victorian society without appreciating the intellectual, social and institutional force of these concerns with the past. Yet modern disciplinary formation has not only separated them in the academy, but also marginalized both subject areas &ndash;&nbsp;which has deeply attenuated comprehension of this foundational era. Our project will bring together scholars working on a range of fields including classics, history of education, cultural history, art history, literary history to bring back into view a fundamental but deeply misunderstood and under explored aspect of the nineteenth century, which continues to have a significant impact on the contemporary world.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><a href="mailto:bible@crassh.cam.ac.uk">Contact the Bible and Antiquity project.</a></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">People</h3>
										<p><strong>Directors</strong></p>

<p><a href="/people/profile/simon-goldhill">Professor Simon Goldhill</a>, PI (CRASSH/Classics, University of&nbsp;Cambridge)<br />
<a href="http://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/people/secord/">Professor James Secord</a>&nbsp;(HPS, University of Cambridge)<br />
<a href="http://www.divinity.cam.ac.uk/directory/janet-soskice">Professor Janet Soskice</a>&nbsp;(Divinity, University of Cambridge)<br />
<a href="http://www.hist.cam.ac.uk/directory/shm24@cam.ac.uk">Dr Scott Mandelbrote</a>&nbsp;(History, University of Cambridge)<br />
<a href="http://www.kcl.ac.uk/artshums/depts/trs/people/staff/academic/ledgerlomas.aspx">Dr Michael Ledger-&shy;Lomas</a>&nbsp;(Theology and Religious Studies, KCL)<br />
<a href="https://www.trinhall.cam.ac.uk/contact/contact-directory.asp?dirKeywords=Jeremy+Morris&amp;Char_3=&amp;staff=Search+Staff">Revd&nbsp;Dr Jeremy Morris</a>&nbsp;(Trinity Hall,&nbsp;Cambridge)</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Post-Doctoral Research Fellows</strong></p>

<p><a href="/people/profile/gareth-atkins">Dr Gareth Atkins</a><br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/jocelyn-paul-betts">Dr Jocelyn Paul Betts</a><br />
<a href="/people/profile/shinjini-das">Dr Shinjini Das</a><br />
<a href="/people/profile/theodor-dunkelgruen">Dr Theodor Dunkelgr&uuml;n</a><br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/ruth-jackson">Dr Ruth Jackson</a><br />
<a href="/people/profile/alison-knight">Dr Alison Knight</a></p>

<p><strong>Alumni of the Project</strong></p>

<p>Dr Brian Murray, King&#39;s College London<br />
<a href="http://bham.academia.edu/KateNichols">Dr Kate Nichols</a>, University of Birmingham</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Events</h3>
										<h4><strong>Forthcoming:</strong></h4>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27180">Reframing Stained Glass in Nineteenth-Century Britain: Culture, Aesthetics, Contexts</a> 11-12 May 2017</p>

<h4>&nbsp;</h4>

<h4><strong>Past:</strong></h4>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26896">Bible and Antiquity - Conference</a>&nbsp;3-5 April 2017</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27105">Theologies of Reading in the Nineteenth Century</a>&nbsp;23 February 2017</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27088">Philology in the 19th century: ideals, traditions, methods</a>&nbsp;10 January 2017</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26738">An Evening in the Victorian Parlour: the Bible and Antiquity at Home</a>&nbsp;8 June 2016</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26737">A Passion for Things</a>&nbsp;7 June 2016</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26736">A Passion for Manuscripts</a>&nbsp;31 May 2016</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26735">A Passion for Travel: Victorian Collectors, Travellers and Tourists</a>&nbsp;17 May 2016</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26380">Bible and Antiquity in 19th-Century Political Thought</a> 10 March 2016</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26591">Orientalism and its Institutions in the Nineteenth Century</a>&nbsp;18 February 2016</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><em><strong>2015</strong></em></p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26067">Solomon Schechter&#39;s Life and Legacy: A Jewish Scholar in Victorian England (1882 &ndash;&nbsp;1901)</a>&nbsp;22 November 2015</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26441">Herodotus and the 19th Century</a>&nbsp;8 September 2015</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/25698">Hebrew Melodies: Music and the Bible in 19th Century Europe</a> 25 June 2015</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/25871">The Victorians and Classical Form</a> 21 May 2015</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26159">Exhibiting Belief: Materiality and religous display in the 19th Century</a>&nbsp;7 May 2015</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/25682">The Discipline of Theology in the 19th Century</a>&nbsp;4 March 2015</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong><em>2014</em></strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/25977">Stabilising the Sacred Texts in Judaism, Christianity and Islam: c.750-c.1000</a> 5 December 2014</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/25683">Fictions of Antiquity: the biblical and classical past of the 19th century&nbsp;novel</a> 6 November 2014</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/25512">Chosen Peoples, Promised Lands </a>14 July 2014</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/25536">Persistence of the Past in 19th Century&nbsp;Scholarship</a> 19 June 2014</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/25479">Collecting Greece in the 19th Century: text, image, object, knowledge</a> 13 February 2014</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong><em>2013</em></strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/24537">Visualising the Bible in the 19th Century</a>&nbsp;13 June 2013</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/24958">Anthropology and Religion in the 19th Century</a> 14 March 2013</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26442">The Camera and the Critic: Photography, Antiquity, and 19th Century Scholarship</a>&nbsp;3 June 2013</p>

                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="email">
                <a href="mailto:?subject=Calls for Papers&body=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/call-for-papers" data-social-text="Share via email">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icon_mailing.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
        </ul>
    </nav>
</div>

						</div>
					</div>
					<hr>
				</div>
			</div>

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">Open calls for papers</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Open calls for papers</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;"><em>See individual event pages for more detailed event summaries and submission guidelines.</em></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<h4><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27517">Comic Epidemic: Cartoons, Caricatures and Graphic Novels</a>, 16-17 February&nbsp;2018</h4>

<p>Both allowing governments to reach broad and diverse audiences, and critics of governmental policies to effectively undermine dominant outbreak narratives, comics are perhaps the most democratic and creative mode of fixing and destabilising truth as regards epidemic crises like SARS, Ebola or Zika in the twenty-first century. At the same time &#39;comic epidemics&#39; have risen to be a popular theme in the realm of graphic novels proper, with works like <em>The</em>&nbsp;<em>Walking Dead</em>&nbsp;or the Argentinean best-seller&nbsp;<em>Dengue</em>&nbsp;dwelling upon the graphic narration of imaginary outbreaks to communicate commentaries on social collapse, survival ethics and the human condition at large.</p>

<p>Though often illustrating historical or anthropological works of epidemic disease, the comic figuration of epidemics has remained an analytically unexamined area.&nbsp;</p>

<p>We are soliciting papers from across the social sciences and the medical humanities that examine the emergence, utilisation and transformation of comics, caricatures and animation in relation to epidemic disease, and the prospects and risks of their use in epidemic prevention, preparedness and control.</p>

<p>Those interested in participating in the conference should send a title and abstract of 300-400 words to Lukas Engelmann (<a href="mailto:lukas.engelmann@ed.ac.uk">lukas.engelmann@ed.ac.uk</a>) and Christos Lynteris (<a href="mailto:cl537@cam.ac.uk">cl537@cam.ac.uk</a>) by <strong>15 December&nbsp;2017</strong>.</p>

<p>Successful applicants from the call for papers will be offered two nights&#39; accommodation in Cambridge and up to &pound;100 in support towards travel costs.&nbsp;</p>

<p>For more information, please visit the conference <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27517">homepage</a>.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h4><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27375" style="text-align: justify;">Reimagining the Cooperative: An Interdisciplinary Conversation</a><span style="text-align: justify;">, 20-21 June 2018 &nbsp; &nbsp;</span></h4>

<p>We invite papers from across the social sciences and humanities (anthropology, history, geography, economics, political sciences, development studies) and from emerging and established scholars, to contribute to an interdisciplinary workshop aimed at re-theorizing contemporary and historic cooperative practice.</p>

<p>There has been considerable and sustained interested in cooperatives across the humanities and social sciences. Yet these approaches, which centre upon cooperatives&rsquo; status as economic organizations, political projects, and sites of meaning and value-making, remain largely siloed within specific disciplines. In anthropology, political science, and sociology, much of the debate has centred on whether cooperatives constitute a launch-pad for radical departures from prevailing social and economic conditions, or whether they instead reinforce the status quo. Other work, particularly in economics and development studies, has focused on more explicitly descriptive and applied ends: analysing the structure, efficiency, and successes/failures of particular cooperative projects, often in order to contribute to the advancement of cooperative entities overall.</p>

<p>What can we gain from bringing these strands of research together? Is it possible for us to move discussions of cooperatives beyond a consideration of structural politics and applied approaches, and what are the implications of this? What other (shared) avenues of analysis are open to us as cooperative scholars?</p>

<p>Participants are invited to consider the following:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Theoretical reconsiderations of the cooperative as social form and political potentiality</li>
	<li>History and historiography of cooperatives, the cooperative movement, and cooperative &lsquo;experiments&rsquo;</li>
	<li>The practice of cooperatives as &#39;total social institutions&#39; and sites of meaning and value-making &nbsp;</li>
	<li>Continuities and frictions between cooperatives, the state, development NGOs, and market actors</li>
	<li>Micro-politics: governance, collective labour, and membership</li>
	<li>Theoretical and analytical connections between cooperatives and other types of communal and collaborative working associations (labour unions, collectives, informal work groups, the sharing economy, mutual and co-owned business, and associations)</li>
</ul>

<p>Please send a 300-word abstract and short CV to Corinna Howland, cfh39 [at] cam.ac.uk by <strong>20&nbsp;December&nbsp;2017</strong>. Applicants will be notified if they have been accepted by 5 January 2018.</p>

<p>Successful applicants will then be asked to submit a 3000-word paper by April 20th, 2018 for circulation among the workshop participants. This, together with a fifteen-minute presentation, will form the basis of the workshop discussions.</p>

<p>Accommodation, lunches, and a workshop dinner will be provided for speakers.</p>

<p>For more information, please visit the workshop <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27375">homepage</a>.</p>
									</div>
								</div>
							</div>
						</article>
					</div>
				</div>

	<title>Cambridge Conversations in Translation &ndash; CRASSH</title>
	

	<meta name="description" content="Cambridge currently has no institutional infrastructure devoted to such work, and those interested in translation tend to be confined to informal fragmentary clusters that rarely converge. The Cambridge Conversations in Translation (CCiT) research group seeks to rectify this by providing a forum in which anyone and everyone with an active interest in translation can meet to exchange ideas about this rich and complex subject.
Translating poetry; How ideas travel; Translation and language learning; Translation and the Other; Translating the Sacred; Translation and music" />
	<meta name="keywords" content="translation, philosophy, english, languages, music, poetry, conversations" />

				<li class="chevron"><img src="/static/svg/chevron_right_grey.svg"></li>
				<li><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/">Research</a></li>
				<li class="chevron"><img src="/static/svg/chevron_right_grey.svg"></li>
				
				<li><a href="/programmes/research-groups">Research Groups</a></li>

				<li>Cambridge Conversations in Translation</li>

			<div class="row">
				<div class="span12">
					<div class="row mb10">
						<div class="span12">
							<h1>Cambridge Conversations in Translation</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">Alternate Mondays, 17.00-19.00 during term-time</h4>
							
							<p class="meta">
								<span class="location">Seminar room SG1, Alison Richard Building</span>
							</p>
							
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>
            <li class="twitter">

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Convenors</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Programme 2017-18</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="4" >Past Events</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;">In recent decades, the theory and practice of translation has become an increasingly prominent area of academic discussion and debate. Offering important opportunities for interdisciplinary research, this flourishing field inevitably promotes interactions across and within a wide range of different discourses. However, the University of Cambridge currently has no institutional infrastructure devoted to such work, and those interested in translation tend to be confined to informal fragmentary clusters that rarely converge. <em>The Cambridge Conversations in Translation</em> (CCiT) research group seeks to rectify this by providing a forum in which anyone and everyone with an active interest in translation can meet to exchange ideas about this rich and complex subject.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">A series of panel discussions and workshops will bring together practitioners and scholars from fields as diverse as literary studies, linguistics, theology, history, music, philosophy, and anthropology to consider and respond to what we anticipate will be provocative insights from our invited speakers. The resulting discussions will encourage an engagement with both practice and theory as they draw on the experiences of professional translators alongside more speculative theoretical frameworks and methodologies.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Themes 2017-18</strong><br />
Translation and Poetry<br />
Translationa and Diversity<br />
Translation and Gender<br />
Conference (2 days event)</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">---<br />
Previous years:</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Themes 2016-17</strong><br />
Translation and Humour<br />
Translation and Drama<br />
Translation and Technology<br />
Translation and Censorship<br />
Translation and Multimodality (One-day event)</p>

<p><strong>Themes 2015-16</strong><br />
<em>Translation and Poetry<br />
Translation and the Sacred Text<br />
Translation and Philosophy<br />
Translation and the Periphery<br />
Translation and Children&#39;s Literature<br />
Translation and Music</em></p>

<p><br />
Administrative assistance: <a href="mailto:gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk">gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk</a></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Convenors</h3>
										<p><strong>Convenors</strong></p>

<p><a href="mailto:ac289@cam.ac.uk">Dr Angeles Carreres</a> (Faculty of Modern and Medieval Languages)<br />
<a href="mailto:mb2087@cam.ac.uk">Monica Boria </a>(Freelance Translator, CULP Italian teacher, Language Centre)<br />
<a href="mailto:mn316@cam.ac.uk">Dr Mar&iacute;a Noriega-S&aacute;nchez</a> (Faculty of Modern and Medieval Languages)<br />
<a href="mailto:mt126@cam.ac.uk">Dr Marcus Tomalin</a> (Faculty of English/Department of Engineering)</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Faculty Advisors</strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Professor Timothy Crane (Faculty of Philosophy)<br />
Professor Robin Kirkpatrick (Faculty of English/Faculty of Modern and Medieval Languages)<br />
Professor James Montgomery (Faculty of Asian and Middle Eastern Studies)<br />
Dr Rowan Williams (Master of Magdalene College)</p>

<p><strong>Faculty Advisors (previus year)</strong><br />
<br />
Dr Ruth Davis (Faculty of Music)<br />
Dr Rowan Williams (Master of Magdalene College)</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Programme 2017-18</h3>
										<p>&nbsp;<table class="table table-bordered table-striped table-hover mt20"><thead><tr><th>Conversations in Translation</th></tr></thead><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27385">Translation and Poetry (Panel)</a></strong><br><i>16 October 2017, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building. NB Different room today*</i><br><p>&nbsp;Mar&iacute;a&nbsp;Menc&iacute;a&nbsp;(Kingston,e-poet), Peter Robinson and Olivia McCannon (Poet and Translator) - Conversations in Translation</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27387">Translation and Poetry (Workshop)</a></strong><br><i>13 November 2017, Seminar room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Viviane&nbsp;Carvalho&nbsp;da&nbsp;Annuncia&ccedil;&atilde;o&nbsp;(Cambridge), Jennifer&nbsp;Harris&nbsp;(Cambridge) - Conversations in Translation</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27388">Translation and Poetry (Translation Hub)</a></strong><br><i>27 November 2017, Seminar Room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>&nbsp;- Conversations in Translation</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27527">Translation and Diversity (Panel)</a></strong><br><i>12 February 2018, Seminar room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Jeremy Munday (Leeds), Maria Sanchez-Ortiz (Aberdeen) - Conversations in Translation</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27528">Translation and Diversity (Workshop)</a></strong><br><i>26 February 2018, Seminar room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>&nbsp;Paul Howard (Cambridge) - Conversations in Translation</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27529">Translation and Diversity (Translation Hub)</a></strong><br><i>12 March 2018, Seminar room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>- Conversations in Translation</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27530">Translation and Gender (Panel)</a></strong><br><i>08 May 2018, Seminar room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Caroline Summers (Leeds), Pauline Henry-Tierney (Newcastle), Jen Calleja (Translator) - Conversations in Translation</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27531">Translation and Gender (Workshop)</a></strong><br><i>21 May 2018, Seminar room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Serena Bassi (Cardiff) - Conversation in Translation</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27373">Beyond Words: Multimodal Encounters in Translation</a></strong><br><i>05 July 2018, SG1 and SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>During the past decade, the rise and sprawl of digital media has ensured that interconnections between different visual, aural, and oral modalities have acquired much greater cultural prominence. This conference aims to bring together both those who produce multimodal &lsquo;translations&rsquo; as well as those who theorise about them. By encouraging truly inter and trans-disciplinary dialogue, the event aspires to impact on research directions in the area of translation and multimodality.</p></td></tr></table></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="4" class="tab ">

							<li>
								<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/legal/sitemap/">Sitemap</a>

		</footer>
	</div>

						<div class="span12">
							<h1>Cambridge Early Career Fellowships</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">For Cambridge UTOs and CTOs to apply for a term of leave</h4>
							 
						</div>

					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Fellows 2017-18</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Fellows 2016-17</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="4" >Past Fellows</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<blockquote>
<p>To me CRASSH represents intellectual life here at its best.</p>

<p>Shruti Kapila (History), Early Career Fellow, Michaelmas 2010</p>
</blockquote>

<p style="text-align: justify;">The Early Career Fellowship scheme at CRASSH, jointly funded by the Isaac Newton Trust and the Schools of Arts &amp; Humanities and Humanities &amp; Social Sciences, allows Cambridge University Teaching Officers and College Teaching Officers to apply for an additional term of research leave in order to develop a new research project. Up to ten fellows&nbsp; are appointed each year. The scheme is also open to UTOs and CTOs working in the department of Geography (supported by the School of Physical Sciences).</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><br />
<strong>The competiton for&nbsp; 2018-19 has now closed. </strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><br />
<strong>Eligibility</strong><br />
All UTOs and CTOs who have been in post for less than five years at date of application are eligible, provided that they have obtained prior permission from their Faculty and/or College. UTOs must apply for leave under Statute D,II,6 (b) and the period of leave granted will not be reckonable for purposes of entitlement to sabbatical leave (granted under statute D,II,5).&nbsp; This is a residential fellowship and successful applicants are expected to spend their period of research leave in Cambridge.<br />
<br />
<strong>Provision</strong><br />
CRASSH&nbsp; provides a forum for presenting work-in-progress and mentoring support through regular contact with its visiting fellows and interdisciplinary research community. The value of the award is set at a flat rate of &pound;2,000 per fellow per term (if Easter Term leave is requested, the sum is reduced to &pound;1,000). This amount will be transferred to the fellow&rsquo;s Faculty or College to enable replacement teaching to be bought in. If the fellow&rsquo;s teaching is split between a Faculty and a College, it will be the responsibility of the Faculty to negotiate the amount passed on to the college (up to a maximum of half the total).</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Fellows 2017-18</h3>
										<p>Michaelmas Term 2017</p>

<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27351">Circulations of Law: Trace, Translation, Trajectory</a></p>

<p>2014-15</p>

<p><table class="table table-bordered table-striped table-hover mt20"><thead><tr><th>Early Career Fellows Work in Progress</th></tr></thead><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25495">Beyond One Man and One Woman: A History of Early American Polygamy</a></strong><br><i>13 October 2014, CRASSH Meeting Room</i><br><p>&nbsp;Dr Sarah Pearsall (History/Robinson College)</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25494">The Cold War Enlightenment</a></strong><br><i>20 October 2014, CRASSH Meeting Room</i><br><p>&nbsp;Dr Joel Isaac (History/Christ&#39;s College)</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25517">George Eliot's Forms of Research</a></strong><br><i>27 October 2014, CRASSH Meeting Room</i><br><p>Dr Ruth Abbott (English/St John&#39;s)</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25515">Stourbridge Fair: Performance, Memory and the Vanished Polis</a></strong><br><i>19 January 2015, CRASSH Meeting Room</i><br><p>Dr Michael Hrebeniak (English/Wolfson)</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25516">Adult Social Care and Property Rights</a></strong><br><i>26 January 2015, CRASSH Meeting Room</i><br><p>Dr Brian Sloan (Robinson)</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25518">Divine Violence  in Modern Jewish Philosophy</a></strong><br><i>02 February 2015, CRASSH Meeting Room</i><br><p>Dr Daniel Weiss (Divinity/Murray Edwards)</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25520">Descartes’s Fictions: Reading Philosophy with Poetics</a></strong><br><i>09 February 2015, CRASSH Meeting Room</i><br><p>Dr Emma Gilby (French/Sidney Sussex)</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26128">The historical assumptions behind the General Scholium: a non-metaphysical Newton</a></strong><br><i>27 April 2015, CRASSH  Meeting Room, Alison Richard Building</i><br></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26157">Mathematics for University Reform: Lefèvre d’Étaples in Classroom and Print</a></strong><br><i>01 June 2015, CRASSH  Meeting Room, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Work in progress</p></td></tr></table></p>

<p>2013-14</p>

<p><table class="table table-bordered table-striped table-hover mt20"><thead><tr><th>Early Career Fellows Work in Progress</th></tr></thead><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25109">Local Priests on the College)</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/24947">The Euro Crisis and Fiscal Union: Legitimacy, Identity and Solidarity beyond the State</a></strong><br><i>11 November 2013, CRASSH Meeting Meeting Room</i><br><p>Dr Alfred Moore (CRASSH Postdoctoral Research Fellow)</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/24955">Means to an End: Hesiod's Apocalyptic Legacies</a></strong><br><i>03 						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About CSER</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Events</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Managing ETR</a></li>
									</ul>

								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About CSER</h3>
										<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/huw-price">Professor Huw Price</a>, Academic Director CSER<br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/sean-o-heigeartaigh">Dr Se&aacute;n &Oacute; h&Eacute;igeartaigh</a>, Executive Director CSER<br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">The Centre for the Study of Existential Risk&nbsp;is an interdisciplinary research centre focused on the study of risks threatening human extinction that may emerge from technological advances. CSER aims to combine key insights from the best minds across disciplines to tackle the greatest challenge of the coming century: safely harnessing our rapidly-developing technological power.<br />
<br />
An existential risk is one that threatens the existence of our entire species. &nbsp;The Cambridge Centre for the Study of Existential Risk (CSER) &mdash; a joint initiative between philosopher Huw Price, cosmologist Martin Rees, and software entrepreneur Jaan Tallinn &mdash; was founded on the conviction that these risks require a great deal more scientific investigation than they presently receive. The Centre&rsquo;s aim is to develop a new science of existential risk, and to develop protocols for the investigation and mitigation of technology-driven existential risks.<br />
<br />
CSER is hosted within the Centre for Research in the Arts, Social Sciences and Humanities (CRASSH), under the management of Dr Se&aacute;n &Oacute; h&Eacute;igeartaigh. The Centre&#39;s Management Committee is supported by an international Advisory Board. See the CSER project website for more information.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">CSER&rsquo;s current research agenda comprises two main strands:</p>

<ol>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Developing a general methodology for the management of extreme technological risk. The aim is to develop a set of methods and protocols specifically designed for the identification, assessment and mitigation of this class of risks: high-impact risks associated with technological developments. These methods will be applicable to complementary and subsequent projects on risks associated with specific technologies.</li>
	<br />
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Analysis of specific potential risks. Initial focus areas are likely to include artificial intelligence, synthetic biology, geoengineering, virus research, systemic risks with catastrophic consequences, and biodiversity loss.</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong style="line-height: 1.6em;"><em>Details of our current projects can be found on the adjoining pages.</em></strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">

	</li>

	</li>

	</li>
