	</li>
</ul>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Managing ETR</h3>
										<h2><u><em>Managing Extreme Technological Risk</em></u></h2>

<h3>Templeton World Charity Foundation&nbsp;</h3>

<p><em><strong>October 2015 &ndash; September 2018</strong></em></p>

<p><strong>Executive Summary</strong></p>

<p>We know of natural risks to our species, such as asteroid impacts. &nbsp;We also know that we threaten our own existence, e.g., by nuclear war. &nbsp;Such home-grown extreme risks have been with us for decades. &nbsp;But many distinguished scientists are now concerned that developments in technology (e.g., in AI or biotechnology) may soon pose more direct catastrophic threats. &nbsp;The new capabilities of such technologies might place the power to do catastrophic harm in dangerously few human hands, or (in the case of AI) take it out of our hands altogether.</p>

<p>The nature and level of such extreme technological risks (ETRs) is at present difficult to assess, because they have received little serious scientific attention. &nbsp;The need to consider them is a new one, but one we seem likely to face for the foreseeable future, as technology becomes even more powerful. &nbsp; hence it is crucial that we investigate these risks seriously, and learn how they can best be managed, in the long term. &nbsp;The purpose of the new Cambridge Centre for the Study of Existential Risk (CSER), within which this project is based, is to lead the international scientific community in conducting research on these issues.</p>

<p>This project begins with a preliminary model of the components needed for the study and management of ETR. We will refine the model by implementing some of it, and by learning from our successes and failures. &nbsp;In this way, we will clarify both the present ETRs themselves, and how risks of this class should be managed in the future. &nbsp;Our outputs will be both theoretical (e.g., scientific papers) and practical (e.g., establishing best practices for ETR mitigation). &nbsp;In the process, we will greatly expand the community of scholars, technologists and policy-makers who are aware of the task of managing ETRs, and do much to define their understanding of the nature of this task. &nbsp;By this means, in the long term, we hope to reduce substantially the rusk that our species will not survive its own technological success.</p>

<p><strong><em>Managing Extreme Technological Risk</em> </strong>is a three-year project funded by the Templeton World Charity Foundation within the Centre for the Study of Existential Risk (CSER). The project <em>Managing Extreme Technological Risk</em> is linked primarily to the first strand of CSER&rsquo;s research agenda. &nbsp;It consists of a number of subprojects:</p>

<ul>
	<li><strong>Evaluation of extreme technological risk</strong><br />
	<a href="http://www.econ.cam.ac.uk/people/crsid.html?crsid=pd10000&amp;group=emeritus">Professor Partha Dasgupta</a><br />
	PDRA tbc</li>
</ul>

<p style="margin-left: 40px; text-align: justify;">This subproject aims to examine the limitations of standard cost-benefit analysis (CBA) as a means of assessing the importance of mitigating extreme technological risk (ETR); to develop a version of CBA more suitable to this context; and derive conclusions about the importance of mitigating ETR compared to other global priorities. Relevant disciplines include: Philosophy (especially moral philosophy, applied ethics, and formal decision theory) and Economics (e.g., the economics of sustainability, the theory of future discounting).</p>

<ul>
	<li><strong>Horizon-scanning and foresight for extreme technological risk</strong><br />
	<a href="http://www.zoo.cam.ac.uk/directory/bill-sutherland">Professor William Sutherland</a><br />
	<u>Dr Bonnie Wintle</u></li>
</ul>

<p style="margin-left: 40px; text-align: justify;">Successful management of ETR is likely to require early detection. This subproject aims to optimise the horizon-scanning and foresight techniques available for this task, and to understand the similarities and differences between the case of ETR and other horizon-scanning applications. Relevant disciplines include: Zoology and Ecology, Conservation Studies, Science and Technology Studies, Psychology.</p>

<ul>
	<li><strong>Responsible innovation and extreme technological risk</strong><br />
	<a href="http://cser.org/about/who-we-are/martin-rees/">Professor Martin Rees</a><br />
	<a href="http://www.csap.cam.ac.uk/network/robert-doubleday/">Dr Robert Doubleday</a><br />
	PDRA tbc</li>
</ul>

<p style="margin-left: 40px; text-align: justify;">This subproject asks what can be done to encourage risk-awareness and societal responsibility, without discouraging innovation, within the communities developing future technologies with transformative potential. Relevant disciplines include: Science and Technology Studies, Geography, Philosophy of Science, plus relevant technological fields (e.g., AI, Virology, Synthetic biology).</p>

<ul>
	<li><strong>Extreme risk and the culture of science</strong><br />
	<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/huw-price">Professor Huw Price</a><br />
	PDRA tbc</li>
</ul>

<p style="margin-left: 40px; text-align: justify;">This subproject (a) explores the hypothesis that the culture of science is in some ways ill-adapted to successful long-term management of extreme technological risk (ETR); and (b) investigates the option of &lsquo;tweaking&rsquo; scientific practice, so as to improve its suitability for this special task. It will examine topics including inductive risk, use and limitations of the precautionary principle, and the case for scientific pluralism and &lsquo;breakout thinking&rsquo; where extreme technological risk is concerned. Relevant disciplines include: Philosophy of Science, Ethics, Science and Technology Studies, Sociology.</p>

<ul>
	<li><strong>Decision theory and goal-stability in self-improving AI</strong><br />
	<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/huw-price">Professor Huw Price</a><br />
	PDRA tbc</li>
</ul>

<p style="margin-left: 40px; text-align: justify;">Unlike the previous subprojects, this subproject focuses on a key challenge relating to the long-term safe development of one of CSER&rsquo;s core focus technologies: artificial intelligence. It will investigate technical and philosophical problems at the intersection of AI and philosophical decision theory, including a rigorous characterization of the the problem of decision-theoretic stability under algorithmic self-improvement. Relevant disciplines include: Mathematics, Computer Science, Philosophical Decision Theory.</p>
									</div>
								</div>
							</div>
						</article>
					</div>
				</div>

						<div class="span12">
							<h1>Mellon Centre for Disciplinary Innovation</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">2011-2016</h4>
							 
						</div>

					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Visiting Fellows</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Teaching Fellowships</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="4" >How to Apply</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;">The Centre for Disciplinary Innovation (CDI) is part of a project funded by the Andrew W Mellon Foundation. The CDI is a focus for collaboration and innovation at the graduate level and beyond, complementing other activities initiated within the CRASSH themes Cultural Transmission, Disciplinary Change, The Future University, Cultures and Politics of the Transregional and, for 2013-15, The Location of Knowledge.&nbsp; Since its start, the CDI has sponsored a wide range of activities focused around the following programmes at CRASSH:</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/research-groups">Graduate/Faculty Research Groups</a><br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/centre-for-disciplinary-innovation">Mellon CDI Visiting Fellows Programme</a><br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/centre-for-disciplinary-innovation">Collaborative Teaching Fellowships</a><br />
A series of conferences focused on disciplinary change across the Humanities, the first, <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/23303">Changing the Humanities/the Humanities Changing</a>, in July 2009, coinciding with the University&#39;s 800th celebrations.&nbsp; The follow-up event, <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/23940">The Future University</a> was held on 30 June - 2 July 2011. A third Mellon CDI conference, <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/24876">The Location of Knowledge,</a> was held on Friday 8 March 2013.</p>

<p><strong>About the Consortium of Centres for Disciplinary Innovation</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">The CDI forms part of a Mellon-funded international consortium. The other partner humanities centres are The Franke Institute (University of Chicago), The Heyman Center for the Humanities (University of Columbia) and The Townsend Center (University of California at Berkeley).</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Growing out of a Mellon-funded initiative at the Franke Institute (New Perspectives on the Humanities: Comparative Studies in Higher Education), the consortium will collectively address the problem of how universities in the twenty-first century can best respond to the challenge of disciplinary change in the humanities and social sciences (and beyond). Each of these universities has been characterised by their intellectual vitality and by the wish to reflect on the structures and procedures of disciplinary knowledge. The four Centers will pursue their programmatic activities according to the local strengths and needs of their institutions.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;Aims and Activities of the Consortium</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">The aim of the Consortium is to link disciplinary innovation with curricular change. At Cambridge, building on&nbsp; programmes recently launched at CRASSH for graduate/faculty research groupus and for early career fellowships, the focus will be on disciplinary innovation at graduate level and on linking research to the curriculum. Drawing Cambridge graduates and faculty into the work of the Centre, the CRASSH programmes encourage the piloting of interdisciplinary courses at both graduate and undergraduate level.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">The Chicago programme focuses on development in graduate education with a series of team-taught courses involving both Chicago faculty and invited faculty. The Columbia programme will sponsor a series of disciplinary retreats on the major disciplines to reflect on possibilities for new structures and linkages at graduate and undergraduate level. The Berkeley programme focuses on the undergraduate curriculum, tracing thematic &#39;threads&#39; through multiple disciplines in relation to undergraduate concentrations. The consortium will meet annually during the project</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">

									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Teaching Fellowships</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The Mellon Teaching Fellowships have now come to an end and are no longer offered by CRASSH.</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">The Mellon Teaching Fellowships, part of the Centre for Disciplinary Innovation at CRASSH, are co-taught by two people from different disciplinary areas, Faculties, or Schools at the University of Cambridge. They are designed to encourage dialogue across disciplines, stimulate research-led teaching, or pilot a course for a new MPhil. or Tripos paper.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Mellon Teachiing Fellowships 2016-17</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Michaelmas 2016<br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26849">Gesture, Perception and Event</a><br />
<a href="http://www.divinity.cam.ac.uk/directory/catherine-pickstock">Catherine Pickstock</a> (Divinity)<br />
<a href="http://www.mml.cam.ac.uk/hmw53">Heather Webb</a> (MML)</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26865">Academia Meets Industry: creating long-term collaborations</a><br />
<a href="http://www.law.cam.ac.uk/people/academic/laf-bently/1109">Lionel Bently </a>(Law)<br />
<a href="http://www.mus.cam.ac.uk/directory/ananay-aguilar">Ananay Aguilar </a>(Music)</p>

									</div><div data-tab-id="4" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">How to Apply</h3>
										<p><strong>The Mellon Teaching Fellowships have now come to an end and are no longer offered by CRASSH.</strong></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Open to faculty members of the University of Cambridge</p>

<p><strong>The </strong><strong>deadline&nbsp;for 2016-17 Teaching Seminars is now closed. </strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">CRASSH is now soliciting proposals from members of Cambridge University faculty for collaborative&nbsp; seminar courses to be taught at CRASSH in Michaelmas Term 2016 or Lent 2017. Courses should be co-taught by two people from different disciplinary areas, Faculties, or Schools. Proposals should present their rationale in relation to interdisciplinarity and/or disciplinary innovation. These courses should not normally be ones that could be offered within a single Faculty or existing curricular structure. Proposals will be selected by a committee including the two Heads of Schools.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">CRASSH seminar courses should be designed to encourage dialogue across disciplines, stimulate research-led teaching, or pilot a course for a new MPhil. or Tripos paper. They should be designed with graduate students (including PhD students) in mind as participants. The Teaching Fellowship scheme will provide compensation directly to the Faculties and/or colleges at the rate of &pound;6.5K per fellow. Courses will count towards the Teaching Fellow&#39;s Faculty/University teaching stint and release them from other teaching during the term of their Fellowship and they will be expected to become part of the CRASSH research community. Information about previous recipients is available here.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Joint proposals, including a rationale, detailed description, outline syllabus and term requested should be submitted electronically to <a href="mailto:ch335@cam.ac.uk">the Administrator</a>, CRASSH, Alison Richard Building, 7 West Road, Cambridge CB3 9DT, accompanied by both CVs. Prospective co-applicants are invited to consult the Director, <a href="mailto:sdg1001@cam.ac.uk">Simon Goldhill,</a>&nbsp; about their proposed course and should have discussed their application ahead of time with Faculty and/or college, who should supply a letter of support to accompany application.</p>
									</div>
								</div>

	</li><li>

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">Fellowship</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Fellows</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Fellowship</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;">The <a href="http://www.wallace-trusts.org.uk/cwt_india.html">Charles Wallace India Trust</a> fellowship at CRASSH offers funding for a term of study and residence in Cambridge during the academic year.&nbsp; The scheme is intended for earlier-career academics from India (defined as resident and domiciled in India, normally between the ages of 25 and 45 years). Applicants should have been in full-time academic employment in an Indian university or research institute of equivalent standing for at least five years and have completed a PhD.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">The Charles Wallace India Trust gives grants to Indians in the early or middle stages of their careers who are living in India and working or studying in the arts, heritage conservation or the humanities. The grants enable successful applicants to achieve their artistic, academic or professional ambitions through spending time in the United Kingdom. Full information about the various types of grants available, and guidance on eligibility and how to apply, can be found on the website of the British Council in India<strong>: </strong>https://www.britishcouncil.in/study-uk/scholarships/charles-wallace-india-trust-scholarships.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The competition to select a Fellow for 2018-19 is now closed. </strong></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Fellows</h3>
										<p><strong>Charles Wallace India Trust Fellow 2017-18</strong><br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/ananay-vajpeyi">Dr Ananya Vajpeyi </a>(Centre for the Study of Developing Societies, New Delhi)<br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27350">A Biography of Sanskrit</a></p>

<p><strong>Past Fellows</strong></p>

<p><strong>2016-17</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/bina-gandhi-deori">Dr Bina Gandhi Deori</a> (Visva-Bharati, Santiniketan)<br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26803"><em>Activating the North-East Indian ethnography collections in Cambridge archives and museums</em></a></p>

<p>2015-16<br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/ananya-dutta-gupta">Dr Ananya Dutta Gupta</a> (Visva-Bharati, Santiniketan)<br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26320"><em>This goodly Cittie: Representations of the Urban Space in Select Elizabethan and Jacobean English Texts</em></a></p>

<p>2014-15<br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/sukanya-dasgupta1">Dr Sukanya Dasgupta</a> (Loreto College, University of Calcutta)<br />
<em>Ovid Revisited: Locating the Heroides in Michael Drayton and Madusudan Dutt</em></p>

<p>2013-14<br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/swarnalatha-rangarajan">Dr Swarnalatha Rangarajan</a><em> </em>(IIT Madras)<br />
<em>Ecocriticism of the Global South</em></p>

<p>2012-13<br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/abhijit-gupta">Dr Abhijit Gupta</a> (Jadavpur University)<br />
<em>Print and Missionary Networks in Early 19<sup>th</sup>-century South and South-East India</em></p>

<p>2011-12<br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/sucheta-bhattacharya">Dr Sucheta Bhattacharya</a> (Jadavpur University)<br />
<em>The Mysterious Women of G W M Reynolds and their Indian Sisters</em></p>
									</div>
								</div>
							</div>
						</article>
					</div>
				</div>

							<h1>China in a Global World War II</h1>

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About the Summer Institute</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Aims of the Summer Institute</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About the Summer Institute</h3>
										<p>The CCKF-CHCI Summer Institute <em>China in a Global WWII</em> has two main objectives. The first is to foster a more dynamic understanding of the history of WWII in China; the second is to function as a spur to making the history of WWII truly global.</p>

<p>The Summer Institute will take place 3 - 15 July 2017 at CRASSH, University of Cambridge, with presentations by invited guest speakers and early career scholars selected through an application process. &nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>The deadline for applications to participate in the Summer Institute has now passed.</strong></p>

<p><strong>Principle Investigator</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/simon-goldhill">Simon Goldhill </a>(CRASSH, University of Cambridge)</li>
</ul>

<p><b>Conveners</b></p>

<ul>
	<li><a href="http://www.ames.cam.ac.uk/directory/vandevenhans">Hans van de Ven</a> (University of Cambridge)</li>
	<li><a href="http://history.berkeley.edu/people/wen-hsin-yeh">Yeh Wen-hsin</a> (University of California, Berkeley)</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>Confirmed guest speakers</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li><a href="http://manoa.hawaii.edu/history/people/faculty/brown/">Shana Brown</a> (University of Hawaii)</li>
	<li><a href="https://elliott.gwu.edu/yang">Yang Daqing</a> (George Washington University)</li>
	<li><a href="http://www.ames.cam.ac.uk/directory/daruvalasusan">Susan Daruvala</a> (Cambridge University)</li>
	<li>Richard Frank (US National WWII&nbsp;Museum)</li>
	<li><a href="http://www.orinst.ox.ac.uk/staff/ea/chinese/mhillenbrand.html">Margaret Hillenbrand </a>(Oxford University)</li>
	<li><a href="http://www.croft.olemiss.edu/people/joshua-howard">Joshua Howard </a>(University of Mississippi)</li>
	<li><a href="http://www.harvard-yenching.org/scholars/lee-seung-joon">Seung-joon Lee</a> (University of Singapore)</li>
	<li><a href="https://www.merton.ox.ac.uk/people/professor-micah-muscolino">Micah Muscolino</a> (Oxford University)&nbsp;</li>
	<li>Hans van de Ven (University of Cambridge)</li>
	<li>Mingwei Song (Wellesley College)</li>
	<li>Per Vamos (University of Cambridge)</li>
	<li>Yeh Wen-hsin&nbsp;(UC Berkeley)</li>
	<li><a href="https://www.uni-frankfurt.de/42584670/yang_zhiyi">Yang Zhiyi (</a>University of Frankfurt)</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>Support</strong></p>

<p>The Institute is made possible by a grant from the Consortium of Humanities Centers and Institutes (CHCI) and the Chiang Ching-kuo Foundation for International Scholarly Exchange (CCKF); we are grateful for their support.</p>

<p><img alt="" src="/assets/general/CHiang_Ching-kuo_Foundation_logo.png" style="width: 469px; height: 75px;" /></p>

<p><img alt="" src="/assets/general/CHCI_Logo.png" style="width: 295px; height: 75px; float: left; border-width: 1px; border-style: solid; margin: 1px;" />&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><img alt="" src="/assets/general/CRASSH-grey-logo-2013.jpg" style="width: 75px; height: 75px; float: left; border-width: 1px; border-style: solid; margin: 1px;" /></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Aims of the Summer Institute</h3>
										<p>World War Two has become something like the axial moment of our times, an event that shaped not just the geopolitical contours of the world in which we now live, but also our moral bearings, our identities, and our sense of the past. If this is true for most Western countries, it has also become the case for China. Now that communism (and, to an extent, consumerism) has lost its grip on the public imagination in China, the country&rsquo;s leaders have turned to China&rsquo;s war with Japan to construct a new, more inclusive, narrative of the emergence of New China, one which has allowed the healing of wounds resulting from class war, but which China&rsquo;s leaders are also exploiting to justify a dominant role for China in East Asia.</p>

<p>The Summer Institute has two main objectives. The first is to foster a more dynamic understanding of the history of WWII in China. Beginning in the late 1980s, much work has been done in China and in the UK and the USA to account more fully for China&rsquo;s role in WWII. Much of that history remains traditional in its approach, recounting battles, tracing international relations, and narrating personal conflicts. By examining the writings of poets, dramatists, and authors, by analysing the work of painters, cartoonists, musicians, and film makers, and by studying the many works of history and other forms of scholarship written in the period, the Institute will recover the intellectual vitality and creativity of the period, and so provide a spur to less politicized and ideological readings of China&rsquo;s wartime past as well as to a proper accounting of the role of the humanities in (and at) war.</p>

<p>China in WWII was not simply the USA&rsquo;s and the UK&rsquo;s junior partner. During her famous tour of the USA in 1943, Madame Chiang Kaishek became America&rsquo;s favourite Asian other, an antidote to Japan, of course, but also a beacon of a new post-imperialist world, deliberately so fashioned by the Roosevelt Administration, in part to boost Chinese morale but also to contain Churchill&rsquo;s imperialist instincts. Mao Zedong took to reading Clausewitz while trying to evolve a strategy for revolutionary success while sitting in his cave in the Yan&rsquo;an Mountains. Indian Congress leader Jawaharlal Nehru discussed Asia&rsquo;s future with Chiang Kaishek in a Chongqing bomb shelter hiding from Japanese bombing raids. The second aim, then, of the Institute is to move scholarship on from its tired focus on US &ndash; China relations to one much more fully aware of the diversities and richness of the international and Chinese domestic context of the war. &nbsp;</p>

<p>A longer range aim of the Institute is to function as a spur to making the history of WWII truly global. Especially in military history, World War II remains told as the fight by the Allies against Germany in Europe and Japan in East Asia. Large areas of the world &ndash; the Middle East, continental East Asia, South-East Asia, and Africa &ndash; are largely overlooked. By approaching the topic in an interdisciplinary way and by bringing a broad range of humanities subjects to bear on it, we hope that a convincing case emerges for a more globally aware, a more cosmopolitan, and a less ideological approach to an event that does indeed continue to shape our time in profound time.&nbsp;</p>
									</div>
								</div>
							</div>
						</article>
					</div>
				</div>

				<div class="span4">
					<div class="row mb30">

									<p class="caption">'War and Flower' by Feng Zikai</p>
									<p class="credit">In Feng, Manhua de Miaofao (Shanghai, Kaiming, 1948), p.21</p>

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Conveners</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Past events</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Theme 2014-15</strong>&nbsp;&nbsp; <strong>The&nbsp; Margins of the City</strong><br />
<br />
The city is a space made of, and build around, heterogeneous margins. Borders, both empirical and conceptual, divide the city&#39;s centre from its periphery; trace the contours of zones of access on the basis of income, race, and gender; split the city into private and public zones. Some borders segregate (the poor from the rich) and others isolate (the rich from the poor). The urban life along the borders and inside the margins often does not conform to the idea of the productive urban citizen. The margins are the spaces of minority groups, migrants, homeless deviants, illegals.<br />
<br />
The seminar explores urban marginality from a variety of perspectives - political and economic exclusion, marginalisation on the basis of race, ethnicity, gender, and religion, to name just a few - in order to question how these margins are produced, sustained, and reproduced in contemporary cities, both in the Global North and South. It aims to challenge the canonical understanding of life at the margin in order to cast a new light on what we consider to be, and what we know of, contemporary urban marginalisation.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Conveners</h3>
										<p><strong>Conveners</strong></p>

<p><a href="mailto:hb400@cam.ac.uk">Hanna Baumann</a> (Department of Architecture)<br />
<a href="mailto:ml710@cam.ac.uk">Michele Lancione </a>(Urban Studies Postdoctoral Fellow, Department of Geography)<br />
<a href="mailto:fs388@cam.ac.uk">Farhan Samanani </a>(Department of Anthropology)<br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Previous conveners</strong><br />
<a href="mailto:aks63@cam.ac.uk">Kathryn Schoefert</a> (Department of History and Philosophy of Science)&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Faculty Advisors</strong></p>

<p><strong>Dr Wendy Pullan </strong>(Director of the Martin Centre for Architectural Studies and Urbanism, Department of Architecture)<br />
<strong>Dr Tatiana A Thieme</strong> (University Lecturer in Human Geography, Fellow and Director od Studies of Fitzwilliam College)<br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Faculty Advisor </strong>(previous years)<br />
<br />
<strong>Professor Andrew Webber</strong> (Professor of Modern German and Comparative Culture, Head of Department, Dept of German and Dutch)</p>

						<div class="span12">
							<h1>Civic Matter: Infrastructure as Politic [2013-2015]</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">From 2013 to 2015</h4>
							 
						</div>

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About </a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Conveners</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Past events</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About </h3>
										<h4 style="text-align: justify;">2014-15&nbsp; Civic Matter: Infrastructure in Sense and Resonance</h4>

<p style="text-align: justify;">This Faculty Research Group builds on the existing Civic Matter programme on the social, ethical and political work of infrastructure. The programme to date has focused on infrastructural design, (re)construction and maintenance, and on &#39;matter&#39; as locus of staggered, juxtaposed and disjointed temporalities of the civic. Moving out from considerations of civic matter in respect of its spatio-temporal extension, this series proposes to examine the &#39;matter&#39; of civic life (built, landscaped, public, aesthetic) as sensory, embodied, and resonant, in terms of the articulation of materiality with civic affect and sociability. In this formulation, civic matter is alternately fugitive and invasive, elusive and intrusive, as much personal as mediated and social, constituted precisely of what eludes systematic social scientific research and of what emerges in the nexus of affect and performance.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">As such, civic matter is attractive, amenable, subject to, and constitutive of a range of novel performance and research interventions and enterprises across the arts, humanities and social sciences. The proposed Faculty Research Group aims to articulate and consolidate converging methodological interests among organisers, speakers, and audiences at CRASSH in the materiality, context, violence, play and inequity emergent in the experiential dimensions of the civic and infrastructural, our subject matter in the 2013-14 series. This programme seeks to bring together thinkers from geography and urban planning, environmental history, art practice and performance, the anthropology of movement, and sonic arts and ethnomusicology to discern and interrogate the resonances and sensory life of civic matter, as it networks amid, constitutes and exceeds the infrastructural with which we have been hitherto concerned.</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Conveners</h3>
										<p><strong>Conveners</strong></p>

<p><a href="mailto:pwg20@cam.ac.uk">Professor P Wenzel Geissler </a>&nbsp;(Director of Research, Division of Social Anthropology, Cambridge and University of Oslo)<br />
<a href="mailto:jm918@cam.ac.uk">Dr John Manton</a> (Research Associate, Division Social Anthropology)<br />
<a href="mailto:rr455@cam.ac.uk">Dr Remy Rouillard</a> (Research Fellow , Scott Polar Research Institute)</p>

<p><br />
<strong>Co-conveners (2013-15)</strong></p>

<p><a href="mailto:rd429@cam.ac.uk">Dr Rohan Deb-Roy </a>&nbsp; (Faculty of History and Philosophy of Science)<br />
<a href="mailto:pwg20@cam.ac.uk">Professor P Wenzel Geissler</a> &nbsp;(Director of Research, Division of Social Anthropology, Cambridge and University of Oslo)<br />
<a href="mailto:cl537@cam.ac.uk">Dr Christos Lynteris </a>&nbsp; (Research Fellow, CRASSH)<br />
Professor Henrietta Moore &nbsp;(William Wyse Professor of Anthropology, Division of Social Anthropology)<br />
<a href="mailto:bp356@cam.ac.uk">Dr Branwyn Poleykett </a>&nbsp;&nbsp;( Research Fellow, Division of Social Anthropology)<br />
<a href="mailto:rjp61@cam.ac.uk">Ruth Prince </a>&nbsp; (Senior Research Fellow, Division of Social Anthropology)<br />
<a href="mailto:nt349@cam.ac.uk">Dr Noemi Tousignant</a> &nbsp;(Division of Social Anthropology)</p>

<p><br />
<br />
<strong>Faculty Advisors (2014-15)</strong></p>

<p>Professor Ian Cross (Professor of Music and Science, Faculty of Music)<br />
Professor Ash Amin &nbsp;(Department of Geography)<br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Faculty Advisor (2013-14)</strong><br />
Dr Marie-Louise Sorensen &nbsp;(Department of Archeology and Anthropology)<br />
<br />
&nbsp;</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Past events</h3>
										<p>&nbsp;<table class="table table-bordered table-striped table-hover mt20"><thead><tr><th>Civic Matter</th></tr></thead><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/22993">Luxury Infrastructure and Socialism</a></strong><br><i>09 October 2013, CRASSH, Seminar room SG2, Ground floor</i><br><p>Owen Hatherley (Writer and Journalist) at Civic Matter</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25111">The Gift, Art’s Infrastructure</a></strong><br><i>23 October 2013, CRASSH, Seminar room SG2, Ground floor</i><br><p>Nikolai Ssorin-Chaikov (Cambridge) at Civic Matter</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25112">Camps as Infrastructure: Perspectives</a></strong><br><i>06 November 2013, CRASSH, Seminar room SG2, Ground floor</i><br><p>Irit Katz Feigis (Cambridge), Silvia Pasquetti (Cambridge) at Civic Matter</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25117">Roundtable on Scientific Infrastructure in Africa</a></strong><br><i>20 November 2013, CRASSH, Seminar room SG2, Ground floor</i><br><p>Roundtable</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25114">Animated Space</a></strong><br><i>04 December 2013, CRASSH, Seminar room SG2, Ground floor</i><br><p>Ash Amin &amp; Filip de Boeck in Conversation, at Civic Matter</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25423">Infrastructural Visibility: The Political Performance of Transport in Contemporary Mumbai</a></strong><br><i>15 January 2014, CRASSH Seminar room SG2, Ground floor</i><br><p>Andrew Harris (UCL) at Civic Matter</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25424">Infrastructures of Resource Economy in (sub-)Arctic Russia</a></strong><br><i>29 January 2014, CRASSH Seminar room SG2, Ground floor</i><br><p>Tatiana Safonova &amp; Istvan Santha (Cambridge), R&eacute;my Rouillard (Cambridge) at Civic Matter</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25425">The Makeshift City: Radical Infrastructure and the Politics of Squatting in Berlin</a></strong><br><i>12 February 2014, CRASSH, Seminar room S1, First floor*</i><br><p>Alex Vasudevan (Nottingham) at Civic Matter</p>

<p><textarea id="adlesse_unifier_magic_element_id" style="display: none;"></textarea></p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25426">Planned Violence: Performing and Resisting Urban Infrastructures in London and Johannesburg</a></strong><br><i>26 February 2014, CRASSH, Seminar room S1, First floor* (NB change room)</i><br><p>Prof Elleke Boehmer and Dominic Davies (Oxford University) at Civic Matter</p>

<p><textarea id="adlesse_unifier_magic_element_id" style="display: none;"></textarea></p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25427">Looping Time and Thick Data  in a Cholera Research Field Site in Bangladesh</a></strong><br><i>12 March 2014, CRASSH Seminar room SG2, Ground floor</i><br><p>Michelle Murphy (Toronto) at Civic Matter</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25530">Infrastructures of Exposure: Toxicity, Temporality and Political Economies in Africa</a></strong><br><i>13 March 2014, Darwin College and CRASSH</i><br><p>Workshop at Civic Matter. Limited places</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25571">Mostra d'Oltramare: Recuperating Mussolini's Show Case</a></strong><br><i>23 April 2014, CRASSH Seminar room SG2</i><br><p>Marcial Echenique (Cambridge) at Civic Matter</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25572">Taking Infrastructure to its Geographical Extreme</a></strong><br><i>07 May 2014, CRASSH Seminar room SG2</i><br><p>Michael Bravo (Cambridge) at Civic Matter</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25573">Mobilizing Development Narrative in South Korea, 1956-1973</a></strong><br><i>21 May 2014, CRASSH Seminar room SG2</i><br><p>John DiMoia (Singapore) at Civic Matter</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25574">Ruins of Utopia: Ponty to the University of the African Future”</a></strong><br><i>04 June 2014, CRASSH Seminar room SG2</i><br><p>Ferdinand De Jong (East Anglia), Brian Quinn (UCLA) at Civic Matter</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25818">Re-Imagining the Sound of a Mining Landscape</a></strong><br><i>13 October 2014, Room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Sarah Buckler (Robert Gordon University),&nbsp;No&eacute;mi Tousignant ( Cambridge) at Civic Matter</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25769">Exposure, Ethics and Art-Anthropology in Post-Disaster Japan</a></strong><br><i>10 November 2014, Room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Jennifer Clarke (Aberdeen) at Civic Matter</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25771">Participatory Sonic Arts in Rio and Belfast</a></strong><br><i>24 November 2014, Room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Pedro Rebelo ( Belfast)&nbsp; 			<div class="row">
				<div class="span12">
					<div class="row mb10">
						<div class="span12">
							<h1>Climate Histories / Paris 2015  [2011-2016]</h1>
						</div>

								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About </h3>
										<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Climate Histories Interdisciplinary Discussion Series/ Paris 2015</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">This Faculty Research Group was funded in 2011 and co-convened by the Departments of Social Anthropology, Geography, and the Engineering Department&#39;s Centre for Sustainable Development. It brings together people from a range of academic and non-academic backgrounds including the sciences, arts, humanities, and social sciences, and those working within policy, industry, activism, and media. Together we discuss past, present, and future environments and debate how to tackle the challenges presented by the changing climate.<br />
<br />
The key questions we ask are:</p>

<ul>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">What can we learn about climate change from history?</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">How do people envision their future environments?</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">How do people gain knowledge of their environments, and why does this knowledge matter?</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">How can different disciplines work together to develop our understanding?</li>
</ul>

<p style="text-align: justify;">For the upcoming academic year (2015-2016) the seminar series will be based on the upcoming <strong><em>Paris 2015 climate conference</em>,</strong> which is to feature global political leaders and determine the future of climate change politics for decades to come. Paris 2015 will be a crucial conference as it aims to achieve a new international agreement on the climate applicable to all countries, with the aim of keeping global warming below 2&deg;C.<br />
Throughout the seminar series we will invite specialists with a direct connection to, or research interest in, specific themes that feature during the Paris 2015 conference, including among others the 2&#730;c limit; the relationship between science and policy; political engagement with climate change; the role of religion and morality; issues surrounding gender and indigenous knowledge and the role of government in mitigating against climate-induced challenges. Supported by our broad network of researchers and participants the seminars will be structured according to three sub-themes corresponding to the three terms of the year:</p>

<ol>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Lead-up to Paris 2015: discuss the background and broader context to the event, proceedings, relevant speakers</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">Arising from Paris 2015: discuss the social, cultural, political, economic, scientific, indigenous, and gendered issues arising from the conference, including relevant speakers</li>
	<li style="text-align: justify;">After Paris 2015: debate the successes, failures, value and relevance of global climate change conferences and discuss the broader future of climate change engagement.</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><br />
For more information, please contact <a href="mailto:rf376@cam.ac.uk)">Richard Fraser (rf376@cam.ac.uk)</a></p>

<p>External website: <a href="http://www.cire.group.cam.ac.uk/Climate%20Histories">Cambridge Interdisciplinary Research on the Environmental (cire group)</a><br />
<em>CRASSH is not reponsible for the content of external websites</em></p>

<p>Administrative assistance: <a href="mailto:gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk">gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk</a><br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p>---<br />
<strong>2014-15</strong></p>

<p>The Climate Histories Interdisciplinary Seminar is about bringing&nbsp; together and expanding a network of people from different backgrounds (sciences, arts, humanities, and social sciences, as well as people working in policy, media, and industry) to tackle questions about climate and environmental change in the past, present, and future.</p>

<p>The general questions we ask as a network are: Why does environmental knowledge matter? What can we learn about climate change from history? How can different disciplines work together to develop our understanding? (See our website created for a one-year AHRC&nbsp; network project at http://climatehistories.innerasiaresearch.org/ )</p>

<p>The aim of the seminar series will be to share knowledge, start conversations, and work towards new ways of thinking for future research projects.</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Conveners</h3>
										<p><strong>Conveners</strong></p>

<a href="mailto:rf376@cam.ac.uk">Dr Richard Fraser</a> (Mongolia and Inner Asia Studies Unit)</p>

<p><strong>Previous Conveners</strong><br />
Dr Barbara Bodernhorn&nbsp; (Division of Social Anthropology)<br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Faculty Advisors</strong></p>

<p><strong>Professor Simon Schaffer&nbsp;</strong> (Department of History and Philosophy of Science)<br />
<strong>Dr David Sneath</strong>&nbsp; (Division of Social Anthropology)<br />
&nbsp;</p>

		<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/blog/post/waltz-with-bashir-a-discussion-on-visual-technologies-representational-capa" class="title">Waltz with Bashir: A discussion on visual technologies’ representational capacities</a>
		<footer>

		</footer>
	</li><li>

		<footer>

		<footer>
			
				Adrian Currie, 
			
			Monday 20 November 2017
		</footer>
	</li><li>

		</footer>
	</li><li>

		</footer>

						<div class="span12">
							<h1>Facilities</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							
							 
						</div>

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">Alison Richard Building</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Alison Richard Building</h3>
										<p style="text-align:justify">At the beginning of 2012, CRASSH moved into the new Alison Richard Building at the West Road gateway to the University&rsquo;s Sidgwick Site, the main base for humanities and social science teaching and research at Cambridge.&nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><img alt="" src="/assets/general/IMG_1769.JPG" style="float:left; height:233px; margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:5px; margin-right:5px; margin-top:0px; width:350px" /><strong>SG1</strong>&nbsp;is situated on the ground floor and has a capacity of 70 seats,&nbsp;complete with state-of-the-art AV facilities.&nbsp;Combined with SG2 this can go up to 110 seats.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><img alt="" src="/assets/general/IMG_1768.JPG" style="float:left; height:233px; margin-left:5px; margin-right:5px; width:350px" /></p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>SG2</strong>&nbsp;is also situated on the ground floor and has a capacity of 40 seats, complete with state-of-the-art AV facilities.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><img alt="" src="/assets/general/IMG_1790.JPG" style="margin-left: 5px; margin-right: 5px; float: left; width: 350px; height: 233px; " /><strong>S1</strong> is situated on the first floor and has a capacity of 40 seats, complete with state-of-the-art AV facilities.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><img alt="" src="/assets/general/IMG_1793.JPG" style="margin-left: 5px; margin-right: 5px; float: left; width: 350px; height: 233px; " /><strong>S2</strong>&nbsp;is situated on the second floor&nbsp;and has a capacity of 25&nbsp;seats, complete with state-of-the-art AV facilities.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong><img alt="" src="/assets/general/IMG_1794.JPG" style="margin-left: 5px; margin-right: 5px; float: left; width: 350px; height: 233px; " /></strong>&nbsp;<strong>S3</strong>&nbsp;is situated on the third floor&nbsp;and has a capacity of 25&nbsp;seats, complete with state-of-the-art AV facilities.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><img alt="" src="/assets/general/IMG_1774.JPG" style="float:left; height:233px; margin-left:5px; margin-right:5px; width:350px" /></p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>The Atrium&nbsp;</strong>is used as a social space where&nbsp;coffees, lunches and drinks receptions take place.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><img alt="" src="/assets/general/IMG_1773.JPG" style="height:233px; margin-left:5px; margin-right:5px; width:350px" /></p>
									</div>
								</div>
							</div>
						</article>
					</div>
				</div>

				<div class="span4">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<div class="span4">
							<nav class="links">
								

								
									<p class="poster mb10"><img src="/assets/programme_posters/_sized/ARB_facilities.png"></p>
									
									
								
								
								
							</nav>
						</div>

			<div class="row">
				<div class="span12">
					<div class="row mb10">
						<div class="span12">
							<h1>Conference Funding</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">2018–19</h4>
							
							<p class="meta">
								<span class="location">CRASSH</span>
							</p>
							
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>
            <li class="twitter">
                <a href="https://twitter.com/share?text=Conference Funding&url=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/conference-funding" data-social-text="Share on Twitter">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_twitter.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="facebook">
                <a href="http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/conference-funding" data-social-text="Share on Facebook">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_facebook.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="email">
                <a href="mailto:?subject=Conference Funding&body=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/conference-funding" data-social-text="Share via email">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icon_mailing.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
        </ul>
    </nav>

						</div>

					<hr>
				</div>
			</div>

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">CRASSH funding</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >What we offer</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Selection criteria</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="4" >Additional funding</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">CRASSH funding</h3>
										<p style="text-align:justify">CRASSH supports an annual programme of conferences and workshops.&nbsp;Funding of up to &pound;2,500, plus administrative support, is available to college and university faculty and graduate students of the University of Cambridge.&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">The competition for conference support&nbsp;in 2018-19&nbsp;is now <strong>open</strong>. We are accepting applications for&nbsp;conferences taking place between September 2018 and July 2019.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">The application portal can be accessed here:<strong> <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/applications/position/view/100">http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/applications/position/view/100</a></strong>.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">The deadline for applications&nbsp;is 12.00pm (GMT) on Friday 26 January 2018.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">If you have any questions about the competition then please email Oliver Wright, CRASSH&#39;s Conference &amp; Events Manager, on <a href="mailto:odw22@cam.ac.uk">odw22@cam.ac.uk</a>.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">A sample budget is available <a href="/assets/general/Sample_CRASSH_conference_budget.xlsx">here</a>, and a sample conference programme is available <a href="/assets/general/Sample_CRASSH_programme.pdf">here</a>.&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><em>Please note that references are not required for the conference competition. You may receive an email from the application system that mentions referees - this can be disregarded.&nbsp;</em></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">What we offer</h3>
										<p>The package offered for a typical two-day conference is up to &pound;2,500 in financial support for speaker travel, hospitality and accommodation.&nbsp;CRASSH support also includes administrative assistance and a&nbsp;conference venue. One-day workshops may be supported with a pro rata financial contribution.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Applications for financial support always automatically include the in-kind contribution.&nbsp;Convenors&nbsp;are&nbsp;however able to apply for the in-kind support only.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h4>Financial support</h4>

<p>Two-day conferences are typically offered up to &pound;2,500 in financial support. A one-day event would be supported with a maximum pro rata contribution of &pound;1,250.</p>

<p>Convenors would generally need&nbsp;to find additional funding to cover some costs to ensure that the maximum financial contribution from CRASSH is not exceeded, especially as it is CRASSH&#39;s policy not to pay for honoraria or publications.</p>

<p>For reference, the average total cost of a conference&nbsp;supported via the competition over 2016-17 was around &pound;5,500. A list of other potential funding sources can be found in the &lsquo;additional funding&rsquo; tab.</p>

<p>A sample conference budget is available <a href="/assets/general/Sample_CRASSH_conference_budget.xlsx">here</a>.</p>

<p><em>Please note that any unspent sums below the maximum agreed revert to the CRASSH conference support fund.</em></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h4>Conference facilities and administrative assistance</h4>

<p>The CRASSH conference facilities at the Alison Richard Building&nbsp;will be available to convenors. We are also willing to support conferences that will take place at other venues within Cambridge.</p>

<p>Administrative assistance includes:</p>

<ul>
	<li><strong>Conference Budget:</strong> Devising a budget, setting up conference account to manage income and expenditure, online delegate registration/payment, producing final accounts.</li>
	<li><strong>Conference Webpage:</strong> Creating a conference website that includes a registration form, conference summary and/or call for papers, posters, conference programme, links, and convenor information.</li>
	<li><strong>Publicity:</strong> Designing a poster; publicising the event via email, social media, and the CRASSH blog. Other forms of publicity such as a video conference trailer or audio/video of the event are usually discussed on an individual basis and the cost of this will normally come out of CRASSH&#39;s financial contribution.</li>
	<li><strong>Arrangements for Speakers:</strong> Assisting conveners with booking accommodation (usually college); reimbursing speakers&rsquo; travel costs.</li>
	<li><strong>Catering:</strong> Arranging lunches and refreshments; assisting with college dinner bookings.</li>
	<li>Production and printing of a conference booklet and support on the day, including registration of participants.</li>
	<li>Post-conference delegate survey.</li>
</ul>

<p>AV assistance is typically available in the Alison Richard Building during normal working hours. Arrangements can be made for AV support outside of normal working hours&nbsp;or at alternate venues. The cost of this will be dependent on the specific requirements of the event.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h4>Conference dates</h4>

<p>We are generally aiming to hold conferences out of term and will book suitable slots in the Alison Richard Building.</p>

<p>Please list a range of preferred dates in order, or tell us if dates are fixed. We cannot guarantee preferred dates will be offered.</p>

<p>Conferences can take place during term time, however it is always more problematic to secure accommodation as students are in residence. Please also note that conferences in the Alison Richard Building&nbsp;can only be held on Fridays and Saturdays during term time, meaning that catering costs will be higher. We&nbsp;suggest that you avoid degree and other ceremony dates, e.g. graduation weekend in June or alumni weekend in September.</p>

<p>Please note that CRASSH&#39;s policy is to not hold conferences on Sundays.</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Selection criteria</h3>
										<p>Conferences will be selected by a panel comprising the Director and Deputy Director&nbsp;of CRASSH,&nbsp;members of the Centre&rsquo;s Management Committee, and the Conference Programme Manager. The Conference Programme Manager will co-ordinate the selection process and inform the applicants of the result by the end of March&nbsp;2018.</p>

<p>We are looking to support genuinely interdisciplinary conferences convened or co-convened by Cambridge researchers. As our funds are limited (we estimate that we will be able to support around 20 conferences in this competition), the emphasis is on using CRASSH resources to enhance their academic dimension.</p>

<p>We encourage conference organisers to make ample provision for discussion and for the participation of graduate students. A sample programme can be found <a href="/assets/general/Sample_CRASSH_programme.pdf">here</a>.</p>

<p>Workshops related to externally funded projects may also be eligible for administrative support only; please state clearly the funds already available.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">Selection will be made on the basis of the following:</p>

<ul>
	<li style="text-align:justify">The contribution of the conference to interdisciplinary, strategic, innovative areas of research;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Evidence of how CRASSH support will add value;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">A coherent programme (aspirational or confirmed);</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">A viable budget with information about other possible sources of funding;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Availability of preferred conference dates.</li>
</ul>
									</div><div data-tab-id="4" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Additional funding</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;">Convenors are strongly advised to seek additional funding to top up what CRASSH is able to offer, for instance to bring overseas speakers or offer student bursaries. Colleges and departments in Cambridge are sometimes able to make additional funds available to conference convenors. A number of funds, foundations and organisations that make conference grants are listed below by subject area. It is also worth searching <a href="http://www.researchprofessional.com">Research Professional</a> (from a Cambridge-networked computer) or <a href="http://euraxessfunds.britishcouncil.org/Search.aspx/Index">Euraxess Funding Search</a>.&nbsp; Please note that the list below is by no means exhaustive!</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<h4>General</h4>

<p><strong>The&nbsp;Fritz Thyssen Foundation</strong>&nbsp;supports&nbsp;conferences in a range of subject areas.<br />
Deadlines: February, May, August, and November.&nbsp;Normally a decision is made eight to ten weeks after each of these dates.<br />
More information: please click&nbsp;<a href="http://www.fritz-thyssen-stiftung.de/funding/types-of-support/conferences/?L=1">here</a>.</p>

<p><strong>The&nbsp;Wellcome Trust</strong>&nbsp;provides grants of up to &pound;30,000 as part of its Small Grants in Humanities and Social Science scheme. This does allow for conference funding, however only as part of a wider programme of events. &nbsp;<br />
Deadline: Applications are accepted online at any time.<br />
More information: please click&nbsp;<a href="http://wellcome.ac.uk/funding/small-grants-humanities-and-social-science">here</a>.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<h4><span style="text-align: justify;">Anthropology</span></h4>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The Wenner-Gren Foundation</strong> makes grants of up to $20,000 available to bring international scholars together to develop anthropological knowledge and debate.<br />
Deadlines: June 1 (for conferences/ workshops to be held no earlier than January of the following year) and December 1 (for conferences/ workshops to be held no earlier than July of the following year).<br />
More information: please click <a href="http://www.wennergren.org/programs/conference-and-workshop-grants">here</a>.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<h4 style="text-align: justify;">History</h4>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The Economic History Society</strong> aims to encourage otherwise unfunded workshops, special meetings and other interesting initiatives in economic and social history. A maximum of &pound;2,000 can be awarded.<br />
Deadlines: 1&nbsp;May and 1 October.<br />
More information: please click&nbsp;<a href="http://www.ehs.org.uk/the-society/grants-awards-and-prizes/initiatives-and-conference-fund.html">here</a>.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The Faculty of History&#39;s</strong>&nbsp;George Macaulay Trevelyan Fund offers grants of up to &pound;1,500 to support&nbsp;travel, accommodation, and subsistence costs for external speakers.&nbsp;<br />
Deadlines: February, May, and November.<br />
More information: please click&nbsp;<a href="https://www.hist.cam.ac.uk/research/research-funding/conference-travel-funding#section-5">here</a>.&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The</strong> <strong>Royal Historical Society</strong> makes grants to conference organisers (of any status) to assist in the financing of small, specialised historical conferences where there is substantial involvement of junior researchers. They are intended to subsidize registration fees (which in this scheme may include accommodation costs) and travel costs for these junior researchers. The value of grants awarded in this scheme is between &pound;100 and &pound;500.<br />
Deadlines: 13 April&nbsp;and 6 November.<br />
More information: please click&nbsp;<a href="http://royalhistsoc.org/grants/conference-organisation/">here</a>.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<h4 style="text-align: justify;">History and Philosophy of Science</h4>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The Foundation for the Sociology of Health and Illness</strong> funds symposia, small conferences or workshops which address important issues in the development of the sociology of health and illness. A maximum of &pound;2,500 will be provided for one-day meetings and &pound;3,000 for two-day or longer meetings.<br />
Deadlines: 31&nbsp;March and 31 October.<br />
More information: please click <a href="http://www.shifoundation.org.uk/?page_id=28">here</a>.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The Institute of Medical Ethics</strong> considers grants of up to &pound;500 to support meetings or other activities of which medical ethics is a substantial and explicit component and which promote understanding of ethical issues related to health care.<br />
Deadlines: Conference grants are available throughout the year.<br />
More information: please click&nbsp;<a href="http://www.instituteofmedicalethics.org/website/index.php?option=com_content&amp;view=category&amp;id=42&amp;layout=blog&amp;Itemid=17">here</a>.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<h4 style="text-align: justify;">MML</h4>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The Modern Humanities Research Association</strong> make up to ten grants of up to &pound;1,500 each to support conferences or colloquia within the field of medieval and modern European languages and literatures (including English).<br />
Deadlines: January and June.<br />
More information: please click <a href="http://www.mhra.org.uk/funding">here</a>.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The Society for French Studies</strong> offers grants in support of conferences held in the UK or Ireland and concerned with research in any area of French Studies.&nbsp;Grants normally range from &pound;100 to &pound;500.<br />
Deadlines: 1 September for events from 1 January to 31 August, 1 January for events from 1 May to 1 January, 1 April for events from 1 September to 30 April.&nbsp;<br />
More information: please click <a href="http://www.sfs.ac.uk/funding/">here</a>.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<h4 style="text-align: justify;">Music</h4>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The Royal Musical Association</strong> welcomes proposals from conference organisers for the affiliation of their events to the RMA and will consider applications for financial support of generally not more than &pound;500.<br />
Deadlines: 15 March and 30 October. Applications received by the deadlines will receive consideration within three months.<br />
More information: please click <a href="http://www.rma.ac.uk/conferences/affiliation.htm">here</a>.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<h4 style="text-align: justify;">Philosophy</h4>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The&nbsp;Aristotelian Society&nbsp;</strong>considers applications of up to &pound;500 for conferences.<br />
Deadlines: September 15th (Autumn meeting) and April 1st (Spring meeting).<br />
More information: please click&nbsp;<a href="http://www.aristoteliansociety.org.uk/editorial-grants/conference-grants/">here</a>.&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The</strong> <strong>British Society of Aesthetics</strong> gives small grants in support of UK activities in aesthetics, including conferences and lecture series, of up to &pound;5,000.<br />
Deadlines: 1 April (for a decision by mid-May) and 1 October (for a decision by mid-November).<br />
More information: please click <a href="http://british-aesthetics.org/?portfolio=small-grants">here</a>.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The Mind Association</strong> awards up to &pound;2,000 in support of conferences that are philosophically innovative.<br />
Deadlines: April and November.<br />
More information: please click&nbsp;<a href="http://mindassociation.org/conference-grants/">here</a>.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<h4 style="text-align: justify;">Social Sciences</h4>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The Galton Institute</strong> offers grants of up to &pound;1,000 (up to &pound;2,000 in &lsquo;exceptional circumstances&rsquo;) to help meet the costs of conferences or workshops concerned with biosocial sciences in the most liberal sense.<br />
Deadlines: 1 March and 1 September.&nbsp;Decisions about funding will be taken within 2-3 weeks of these deadlines.<br />
More information: please click <a href="http://www.galtoninstitute.org.uk/grants/grants-for-conferences-or-workshops/">here</a>.</p>
									</div>
								</div>
							</div>
						</article>
					</div>
				</div>

	<div class="container mb15">
		<header id="site">
			<div class="visible-phone" id="phone-menu"><a href="#" onclick="$('#nav-sub').toggle(); return false;"><img src="/static/img/menu.png"></a></div>
			<div class="visible-phone" id="phone-search"><a href="/search"><img src="/static/img/search.png"></a></div>
			<div class="row">
				<div class="span2 logo">
					<a href="/">
						<img src="/static/svg/crassh_logo.svg" alt="">

				<div class="span4 hidden-phone pt10"><div class="socialShare">

			<div class="row">
				<div class="span8">
					<article>

						<p style="text-align:justify">The conference programme is a highly valued, flagship activity that showcases arts, social sciences and humanities research in action. It enables Cambridge scholars to look beyond their own disciplines and broker exciting collaborations. Diverse protagonists from academic and other spheres bring different perspectives to bear on shared problems and linked themes, enabling new forms of understanding.&nbsp;The programme allows us to promote the vitality and productivity of world-class research in Cambridge.&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">For further information: <a href="mailto:conferences@crassh.cam.ac.uk">conferences@crassh.cam.ac.uk</a></p>

						 <!-- Conferences -->

	<meta name="description" content="Established at the University of Cambridge in 2001, the Centre for Research in the Arts, Social Sciences and Humanities (CRASSH) works actively with the Schools and Faculties across the University undertaking collaborations that cross faculties and disciplines in order to stimulate fresh thinking and dialogue in and beyond the humanities and social sciences and to reach out to new collaborators and new publics." />
	<meta name="keywords" content="crassh, CRASSH, Centre for Research in the Arts, Social Sciences and Humanities, humanities centre, humanities center, interdisciplinary, interdisciplinarity, conferences, seminars, lectures, research, fellowships, call for papers, early career fellowships, graduate, postdoctoral fellowships, visiting fellowships, risk, conference, modelling futures, challenging models, uncertainty, david spiegelhalter" />

					<a href="/">
						<img src="/static/svg/crassh_logo.svg" alt="">
						<h1>CRASSH</h1>
						<div class="colours">
							<div class="green"></div>

				<div class="span8"><h1>Conferences</h1></div>
				<div class="span4 hidden-phone pt10"><div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>

			<div class="row">
				<div class="span8">
					<article>

						<p style="text-align:justify">The conference programme is a highly valued, flagship activity that showcases arts, social sciences and humanities research in action. It enables Cambridge scholars to look beyond their own disciplines and broker exciting collaborations. Diverse protagonists from academic and other spheres bring different perspectives to bear on shared problems and linked themes, enabling new forms of understanding.&nbsp;The programme allows us to promote the vitality and productivity of world-class research in Cambridge.&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">For further information: <a href="mailto:conferences@crassh.cam.ac.uk">conferences@crassh.cam.ac.uk</a></p>

						 <!-- Conferences -->

	<meta name="description" content="Established at the University of Cambridge in 2001, the Centre for Research in the Arts, Social Sciences and Humanities (CRASSH) works actively with the Schools and Faculties across the University undertaking collaborations that cross faculties and disciplines in order to stimulate fresh thinking and dialogue in and beyond the humanities and social sciences and to reach out to new collaborators and new publics." />

			<div class="row">
				<div class="span8"><h1>Past Conferences</h1></div>
				<div class="span4 hidden-phone pt10"><div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>
            <li class="twitter">
                <a href="https://twitter.com/share?text=Past Conferences&url=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/conferences/archive" data-social-text="Share on Twitter">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_twitter.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="facebook">
                <a href="http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/conferences/archive" data-social-text="Share on Facebook">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_facebook.svg">
                </a>

            <li class="email">
                <a href="mailto:?subject=Past Conferences&body=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/conferences/archive" data-social-text="Share via email">
