<a href="http://www.english.cam.ac.uk/people/Zeeman/Nicolette/">Professor Nicolette Zeeman</a>&nbsp;(Faculty of English, University of Cambridge and Fellow of King&rsquo;s College)</p>

<p><a href="https://www.english.cam.ac.uk/people/Peter.De_Bolla/">Professor Peter De Bolla</a> (Professor of Cultural History and Aesthetics and Chair of the Faculty Board of English, University of Cambridge; Fellow of King&#39;s College)</p>

<p><strong>Exhibition Advisor</strong></p>

<p><strong>Project Alumni</strong></p>

<p><a href="https://pure.york.ac.uk/portal/en/researchers/timothy-john-stuartbuttle(cbefb766-30ae-4648-be11-d55b59568a1a).html">Dr Tim Stuart-Buttle</a> (University of York/JRF Clare Hall, Cambridge)<br />

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/gaenor-moore" target="_blank">Mrs Gaenor Moore</a></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Events</h3>
										<p><strong>Forthcoming events:</strong></p>

<p><em>There will be a conference on the final strand of the project, Law, Monday 2&nbsp;July - Wednesday 4 July&nbsp;2018. Details to follow.</em></p>

<p><strong>Previous events:</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26037" target="_blank">Crossroads of Knowledge: Literature and Theology in Early Modern England</a>, Fitzwilliam College &ndash;&nbsp;Saturday 14 February 2015</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26089" target="_blank">Crossroads of Knowledge: Knowledge, Belief and Literature in Early Modern England,</a> Trinity Hall - Thursday 7 May - Friday 8 May 2015</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26308" style="line-height: 1.6em;" target="_blank">Interdisciplines: Drama, Economics and Law in Early Modern England</a><span style="line-height: 1.6em;">, Fitzwilliam College - Saturday 17 October 2015</span></p>

<p><span style="line-height: 1.6em;"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26483" target="_blank">Change and Exchange</a>, Trinity Hall - Friday 29 April - Saturday 30 April 2016</span></p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26984">Matter at the Crossroads: Literature and Natural Philosophy in Early Modern England</a>, Trinity Hall - Friday 25 November 2016</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27058">Crossroads of Knowledge: Early Modern Literature and Natural Philosophy</a>,&nbsp;Alison Richard Building - Friday 3 March - Saturday 4 March 2017</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="4" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Visiting Fellows</h3>
										<p><u><strong>2014-2015 - Theology Strand</strong></u></p>

<p><strong>Professor Debora Shuger (UCLA)&nbsp;</strong></p>

<p>Professor Shuger&#39;s interests range across a number of fields: Tudor-Stuart devotional poetry and prose, theology and biblical exegesis, legal history, political thought, rhetoric, life writing (biography, memoirs, diaries, etc.). Under the right circumstances, she also shows interest in gender, sexuality, colonialism, Classics, and Shakespeare. Along with the books listed above, she is the co-editor of <em>Religion and Culture in Renaissance England </em>(1997) and contributed the essay on early Stuart religious literature to the new <em>Cambridge History of Early Modern English Literature</em> (2002); she has also published articles on Spenser, Shakespeare, Sidney, Milton, Donne, Jonson, Middleton, rhetoric, hagiography, and mirrors. She has been a fellow at the the Liguria Study Center, the National Humanities Center, the Huntington Library, and the Wissenschaftskolleg zu Berlin, as well as recipient of Guggenheim, NEH, and UC President&#39;s fellowships. Recent graduate seminars have focused on political theory from antiquity through the late Middle Ages, 17th century life-writing, Elizabethan religious prose, the sacred literature of the Jacobean era, early modern English law, Saint Augustine, and Renaissance commentaries on Paul&#39;s Epistle to the Romans.</p>

<p><strong>Professor Brian Cummings (University of York)</strong></p>

<p>Professor&nbsp;Cummings &nbsp;was appointed at York in&nbsp;October 2012 as one of sixteen Anniversary Professors appointed across the arts and sciences to promote the University&rsquo;s international research profile in its 50th&nbsp;year. Before moving there he was Professor of English at the University of Sussex, where he co-founded the Centre for Early Modern Studies in 2004. In Spring 2014 he was Distinguished Visiting Scholar at the University of Toronto, based at the Centre for Reformation and Renaissance Studies. He has also held Visiting Fellowships in Los Angeles, Munich, and Oxford, and he was previously Fellow of Trinity College, Cambridge. Among a number of academic honours he has given the Shakespeare Birthday Lecture in Washington D.C. in 2014, the Clarendon Lectures in Oxford in 2012-13, and the British Academy Shakespeare Lecture in 2012. From 2009-2012 he held a Leverhulme Trust Major Research Fellowship, and in 2007 he was a British Academy Exchange Fellow. He is a Fellow of the Society of Antiquaries, one of the oldest learned societies in the world.</p>

<p><u><strong>2015-2016 - Economic History Strand</strong></u></p>

<p><strong>Professor Valerie Forman (NYU Gallatin)</strong></p>

<p>Professor Forman&rsquo;s research and teaching interests lie in the literature and culture of 16th- and 17th-century England and Europe, the early modern Caribbean, early modern drama, early modern women writers, early modern economic history and political theory, and Marxist theory. She received a PhD in literature from UC Santa Cruz, where she specialized in Renaissance and 17th-century English literature and culture and 16th-century French literature. Before coming to Gallatin, Professor Forman&nbsp;taught in the Department of English at the University of Colorado, Boulder. Her first book,&nbsp;<em>Tragicomic Redemptions: &nbsp;Global Economics and the Early Modern English Stage</em>&nbsp;(University of Pennsylvania Press, 2008), explores the relationship between innovations in the theatre and new economic practices necessary to the beginnings of global trade, including that among England, the East Indies, and the Ottoman Empire. Her second book project, which turns to trade and cultural relations in the Caribbean, is entitled&nbsp;<em>Developing New Worlds: Property, Freedom, and the Economics of Representation in Early Modern England and the Caribbean</em>.&nbsp;She teaches courses on theatre and politics, labor, and global markets, and the rise of globalization in the early modern period.</p>

<p><strong>Dr&nbsp;Ceri Sullivan (Cardiff University)</strong></p>

<p>Dr Sullivan&#39;s first&nbsp;career was in the City of London&nbsp;as a senior charterted accountant and banking analyst and her second&nbsp;as a Finance Director through VSO. She now teaches&nbsp;early modern literature and modern political drama and her research interests deal with whether one may persuade oneself in devotion, focusing on&nbsp;&nbsp;Catholic texts in her publication (<em>Dismembered Rhetoric: English Recusant Writing 1580-1603</em>).&nbsp;&nbsp;Further publications explore&nbsp;how a merchant represents himself and reads others&#39;&nbsp;&nbsp;representations in the real and dramatic markets (<em>The Rhetoric of Credit:&nbsp;&nbsp;Merchants in Early Modern Writing</em>).&nbsp;and whether, if the conscience&nbsp;&nbsp;is structured as a language, the consequence of the divine<em> I am</em> is <em>You aren&#39;t</em>&nbsp;&nbsp;(<em>The Rhetoric of the Conscience in Donne, Herbert and Vaughan</em>). Her&nbsp;&nbsp;next book will be&nbsp;<em>Private Prayer in Shakespeare&#39;s Histories.</em> Imagine a society where every single adult was trained in - and practised - composing short original texts, every single day. This project asks an audacious but compelling question: at the turn of the seventeenth century, did changes in writing private prayers underlie major developments in drama? Required to pray independently, convinced their private prayers had an impact on the course of events, the laity developed literary - indeed, specifically dramatic - skills: in characterisation, in counter-factual narrative, and in striking verbal forms. Playwrights interested in experiments in form, particularly Shakespeare, gleefully seized on this novel expertise in their audience.</p>

<p><u><strong>2016-2017 - Natural Philosophy Strand</strong></u></p>

<p><strong>Professor Jonathan Sawday (Saint Louis University)</strong></p>

<p>Professor Jonathan Sawday studied English at Queen Mary College (University of London) and University College London, where he took his PhD in Renaissance Literature. He has taught at British, Irish, and American universities, most recently at the University of Strathclyde, in Glasgow, Scotland where he held the Chair in English Studies. He has held fellowships at the Huntington Library (California), the Russian State University for the Humanities in Moscow, and been a visiting scholar in the Centre for Renaissance Studies at the Newberry Library in Chicago. He has held awards and grants from the Fulbright Association, the British Academy, The British Council, and the UK Arts and Humanities Research Council. He is a Fellow of the English Association (FEA), the Royal Society for the Arts (FRSA), and of the Royal Historical Society (FRHistS). He is on the advisory board of the&nbsp;Journal for Literature and Science&nbsp;and on the editorial boards of&nbsp;Medical Humanities&nbsp;and&nbsp;Writing Technologies. Professor&nbsp;Sawday is a cultural historian. His research is focused on the intersection between science, technology, and literature particularly (but not exclusively) in the early-modern period. Currently, he is working on the idea of blanks or voids in literature, art, and culture. He is also working on an intellectual biography of Robert Burton (1577-1640), the inscrutable author of&nbsp;<em>The Anatomy of Melancholy&nbsp;</em>(1621), the first (and probably longest) psychoanalytic work published in English.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Dr Michael&nbsp;Witmore (Folger Shakespeare Library)</strong></p>

<p>Dr. Witmore was appointed the seventh director of the Folger on July 1, 2011. Upon his arrival, he worked with the Board of Governors to draft a Strategic Plan for the institution, adopted in June 2013. He was formerly professor of English at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, and before that he served as associate professor of English and assistant professor of English at Carnegie Mellon University. The recipient of numerous fellowships, he has held an Andrew Mellon Postdoctoral Fellowship at the University of California, Los Angeles, a research fellowship and a curatorial residency fellowship at the Folger, and a predoctoral fellowship at the Max-Planck-Institut f&uuml;r Wissenschaftsgeschichte in Berlin. He was awarded (but declined) an ACLS Digital Innovation Fellowship for the academic year 2011-12. Dr. Witmore earned an A.B. in English at Vassar College, and an M.A. and Ph.D. in rhetoric at the University of California, Berkeley. Among his more recent projects, he launched the Working Group for Digital Inquiry at the University of Wisconsin-Madison and organized the Pittsburgh Consortium for Medieval and Renaissance Studies. His publications include numerous articles, website resources, and book chapters, and he has published five books:&nbsp;<em>Landscapes of the Passing Strange: Reflections from Shakespeare,</em> with Rosamond Purcell&nbsp;(2010),&nbsp;<em>Shakespearean Metaphysics</em>&nbsp;(2009),&nbsp;<em>Pretty Creatures: Children and Fiction in the English Renaissance</em>&nbsp;(2007),&nbsp;<em>Childhood and Children&rsquo;s Books in Early Modern Europ</em>e, 1550-1800&nbsp;(2006), and&nbsp;<em>Culture of Accidents: Unexpected Knowledge in Early Modern England</em>&nbsp;(2001). In addition, he has given scores of presentations and been invited to serve on numerous academic panels. He currently has several books in progress, including a study of early modern wisdom literature and a book on the nature of digital inquiry in the humanities.&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Professor Lorraine Daston (Max Planck Institute for the History of Science)</strong></p>

<p>Professor Daston has published on a wide range of topics in the history of science, including the history of probability and statistics, wonders in early modern science, the emergence of the scientific fact, scientific models, objects of scientific inquiry, the moral authority of nature, and the history of scientific objectivity. Recent books include (with Paul Erikson et al.)&nbsp;<em>How Reason Almost Lost Its Mind: The Strange Career of Cold war Rationality&nbsp;</em>(2014)&nbsp; and (co-edited with Elizabeth Lunbeck),&nbsp;<em>Histories of Scientific Observation</em>&nbsp;(2011), both products of MPIWG Working Groups. Her current projects include a history of rules, based on her 2014 Lawrence Stone Lectures at Princeton University, the emergence of Big Science and Big Humanities in the context of nineteenth-century archives, and the relationship between moral and natural orders. She is the recipient of the Pfizer Prize and Sarton Medal of the History of Science Society, the Schelling Prize of the Bavarian Academy of Sciences, the Lichtenberg Medal of the G&ouml;ttingen Academy of Sciences, the Luhmann Prize of the University of Bielefeld, and an honorary dotorate of humane letters from Princeton University. In addition to directing Department II of the MPIWG, she is a regular Visiting Professor in the Committee on Social Thought at the University of Chicago and Permanent Fellow of the Wissenschaftskolleg zu Berlin.</p>

<p><u><strong>2016-2017 - Law Strand</strong></u></p>

<p><strong>Professor&nbsp;Kathy H. Eden (Columbia University)</strong></p>

<p>Professor Eden began teaching at Columbia in 1980. She studies the history of rhetorical and poetic theory in antiquity, including late antiquity, and the Renaissance, within the larger context of intellectual history and with an emphasis on the problems of reception. Her books include&nbsp;<em>Poetic and Legal Fiction in The Aristotelian Tradition&nbsp;</em>(Princeton,1986),&nbsp;<em>Hermeneutics and the Rhetorical Tradition: Chapters in the Ancient Legacy and its Humanist Reception&nbsp;</em>(New Haven, 1997), and&nbsp;<em>Friends Hold All Things in Common: Tradition, Intellectual Property and the &#39;Adages&#39; of Erasmus</em>&nbsp;(New Haven, 2001). Her articles appear in&nbsp;Journal of the History of Ideas,&nbsp;Rhetorica,&nbsp;Yale Journal of Law and the Humanities,&nbsp;Studies in the Literary Imagination,&nbsp;Erasmus of Rotterdam Society Yearbook&nbsp;and&nbsp;Traditio. Her current project explores epistolary theory and the construction of letter collections in antiquity and the Renaissance. In 1981-82 she received a fellowship from the Center for Hellenic Studies in Washington, D.C. and in 1998-99 a Guggenheim fellowship. In 1998 she won the Great Teacher Award from the Society of Columbia Graduates and in 2001 the Mark Van Doren Award and the Award for Distinguished Service to the Core Curriculum.</p>

<p><strong>Professor Lorna Hutson&nbsp;(Merton College, University of Oxford)</strong></p>

<p>Professor Hutson&#39;s interests are in the relationship between literary form and the formal aspects of non-literary culture. Most recently, she&nbsp;has&nbsp;been interested in legal-literary relations (for example, in how legal techniques of proof can become, in fiction, modes of vividness). She&nbsp;currently holds a&nbsp;Leverhulme Major Research Fellowship&nbsp;for a project entitled&nbsp;Shakespeare&rsquo;s Scotland, which looks at Anglo-Scots literary and legal imagining in the century leading up to Shakespeare&rsquo;s great tragedies. Professor Hutson&nbsp;has written on Thomas Nashe (1989); on gender in sixteenth century English literature,&nbsp;<em>The Usurer&rsquo;s Daughter: Male Friendship and Fictions of Women in Sixteenth Century England&nbsp;(</em>1994); on drama and participatory justice in&nbsp;<em>The Invention of Suspicion</em>&nbsp;(2007), which won the&nbsp;Roland Bainton Prize for Literature in 2008, and on theatrical &lsquo;unscene&rsquo; in&nbsp;<em>Circumstantial Shakespeare</em>&nbsp;(2015) based on the&nbsp;Oxford Wells Shakespeare Lectures, 2012. Edited collections include&nbsp;<em>Feminism and Renaissance Studies&nbsp;</em>(1999) and, with Victoria Kahn,&nbsp;<em>Rhetoric and Law in Early Modern Europe&nbsp;</em>(2001). For the&nbsp;Cambridge Complete Works of Ben Jonson&nbsp;(2012), she&nbsp;edited Jonson&rsquo;s&nbsp;Discoveries&nbsp;(1641). Forthcoming is the<em>&nbsp;Oxford Handbook of English Law and Literature, 1500-1700.</em></p>
									</div>
								</div>

		<footer>

							<h1>Cybernetics and Society [20016-17]</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">Alternate Tuesdays, 12.00-14.00 during term time</h4>
							
							<p class="meta">
								<span class="location">Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building</span>

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Convenors</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Programme 2016-17</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p><strong>Cybernetics as a History of the Present</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">As more and more of our collective activities (education, pension planning, health management, environmental protection) are mediated by rapidly moving markets and computerized technologies, uncertainties abound.&nbsp; Ours, we are told, is an information age, in which new forms of data collection and analysis will enable ever more efficient management of supply chains, regulation of energy usage and even allocation of personal time.&nbsp; Such visions of a technologically mediated &mdash; and seemingly limitless &mdash; future are not new.&nbsp; They echo the technological futurism popularized in the middle of the twentieth century by cybernetics.&nbsp; Beginning with the 1948 publication of Norbert Wiener&rsquo;s book, Cybernetics: Or Control and Communication in the Animal and the Machine, cybernetics inaugurated path-breaking scientific explorations of feedback and self-regulation in biological and mechanical system. &nbsp;In the process, it provided the conceptual foundation for contemporary advances in fields such as bioinformatics, operations research, game theory and artificial intelligence.&nbsp; Our group brings together a diverse range of experts in the humanities, the social and computational sciences, law and the arts. Together we examine how emerging information models are altering experiences of social belonging and the ways in which citizens are situated within emerging projects of governance and market allocation.&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Revisiting mid-century information science and its multiple offshoots offers a powerful framework for addressing the multidisciplinary questions raised by Big Data and its growing centrality to contemporary social life.&nbsp; Cybernetics attracted scholars from a surprisingly wide array of disciplines, because it provided a language and method for commensurating diverse phenomena.&nbsp; Mathematicians, physicists, linguists, anthropologists, psychologists and biologists, working in collaboration, made cybernetics a popular scientific reference during the 1950s and 1960s.&nbsp; Their research formed a particularly American response to the challenges of the post-World War II era, combining US Cold War defense funding with support from private foundations, academic centers and emerging industry.&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">While much of this history is well researched, our work challenges the common notion that cybernetics was merely a vogueish mid-century techno-science, which fell into obscurity by the1970s.&nbsp; Instead we seek to understand more precisely how systems analysis and practices of control and regulation persisted beyond that moment, transformed by new emphases on open (as opposed to closed) systems, and on disruption and innovation (rather than homeostasis). &nbsp;How does the language of optimization alter how we measure and understand human excellence in everything from teacher performance to healthcare outcomes?&nbsp; What are the ethical commitments of the cybernetic sciences?&nbsp; How are ideas of legal justice and human rights transformed as the limits of personhood itself come to be quantified with new precision? The opportunity to cast our net far and wide &mdash; though challenging &mdash; will allow us to think about familiar questions differently, and in dialogue with knowledge outside of our individual disciplines.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Our aim is not merely to investigate the history of information theory, but to understand more precisely how the conceptual logic of our current information infrastructure has developed over the course of the last 70 years.&nbsp; Cybernetics and Society will sponsor 12 fortnightly meetings throughout the academic year, four each term.&nbsp; We will intersperse smaller, reading group sessions with public lectures.&nbsp; Doing so gives us an opportunity to&nbsp; engage with speakers&#39; work ahead of time and will help support a more robust and lively discussion with our invited guests. &nbsp;&nbsp;Themes will include Systems Science and Industrial Management; Histories of Modern Risk; Cybernetics and Design Thinking; Rethinking Cold War Science; Historicising the Information Age; and Cybernetics and the Psychology of Happiness.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Administrative assistance: <a href="mailto:gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk">gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk</a></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Convenors</h3>
										<p><strong>Convenors</strong></p>

<p><a href="mailto:am2213@cam.ac.uk">Dr Andrew McKenzie-McHarg</a> (Research Associate ,CRASSH)<br />
<a href="mailto:lsp33@cam.ac.uk">Dr Poornima Paidipaty</a> (Philomathian Reseach Associate, Faculty of History)</p>

<p><br />
<strong>Faculty Advisors</strong></p>

<p>Professor John Naughton (Senior Research Fellow, CRASSH)<br />
Professor Simon Szreter (Professor of History and Public Policy, Faculty of History)</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Programme 2016-17</h3>
										<p><table class="table table-bordered table-striped table-hover mt20"><thead><tr><th>Cybernetics and Society</th></tr></thead><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26993">Cybernetics, Unknowability and Politics</a></strong><br><i>18 October 2016, Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Andrew Pickering (Exeter), Simon Schaffer (Cambridge) - at Cybernetics and Society</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26994">The Liberal Effect: System-Cybernetic Governmentality during the Cold War</a></strong><br><i>01 November 2016, Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Egle Rindzeviciute&nbsp; (London)- at Cybernetics and Society</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26995">Design for a Brain and the Humanity of the Non-Human</a></strong><br><i>15 November 2016, Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Reading Group at Cybernetics and Society</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27060">2084: Cryptography, Magic, and Politics (joint event)</a></strong><br><i>24 November 2016, Seminar room SG1/SG2 Alison Richard Building.</i><br><p>Joint Seminar: Technology &amp; Democracy and Cybernetics &amp; Society</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26996">Modelling the Complex Dynamics of Modern Economies</a></strong><br><i>29 November 2016, Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Reading group -at Cybernetics and Society</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27104">The Family as Machine: Film, Infrastructure and Cybernetic Kinship in Suburban America</a></strong><br><i>28 February 2017, Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Bernard Geoghagen (Coventry)- at Cybernetics and Society</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27073">Brainwashing the Cybernetic Spectator: The Ipcress File, 1960's Cinematic Spectacle and ...</a></strong><br><i>14 March 2017, Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Marcia Holmes (Birkbeck)-at Cybernetics and Society</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27074">Computational Rationality, NUTS, and the Nuclear Leviathan</a></strong><br><i>06 April 2017, Seminar room S1, 1st Floor, Alison Richard Building. NB Out of term session*</i><br><p>Sonja M. Amadae (Helsinki and MIT), David Runciman (POLIS) -at Cybernetic and Society</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27174">The Disunity of Cybernetics and the Digital</a></strong><br><i>25 April 2017, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Ronald Kline (Cornell),&nbsp;Richard Staley (Cambridge) at Cybernetics and Society</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27175">Cybernetic Fantasies of Value</a></strong><br><i>06 June 2017, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Seb Franklin (KCL)&nbsp;at Cybernetics and Society</p></td></tr></table></p>
									</div>
								</div>
							</div>
						</article>
					</div>

                    <img src="/static/svg/icon_mailing.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
        </ul>
    </nav>
</div>

						</div>
					</div>
					<hr>
				</div>
			</div>

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Convenors</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Programme 2016-17</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="4" >Blogs</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;">The call for decolonisation is resonating in universities across the globe today. The most dramatic instance has been the Rhodes Must Fall movement in South Africa, which inspired protests such as Rhodes Must Fall at Oxford and &ldquo;Why is My Curriculum White&rdquo; at UCL. These movements have found affinities with expanding struggles around race, gender, and class on North American campuses and with the upsurge of interest in decolonisation within professional academia.&nbsp; Our workshops and seminars will focus on one particular aspect of today&rsquo;s demand to decolonise the university: the curriculum. Drawing from postcolonial, decolonial, and subaltern critiques of social science knowledge production and circulation, the research group will aim to explore the &ldquo;postcolonial turn&rdquo; or &ldquo;Southern turn&rdquo; in different domains of the humanities and social sciences. The series of activities are both inspired by and in dialogue with the increasing attention to the global plurality of particular disciplines, for example, the need to work toward &ldquo;a world anthropologies framework&rdquo;, &ldquo;global sociology&rdquo;, or non-Western international relations.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Our questions of decolonising knowledge in the academy are four-fold. First, why is the demand for decolonisation being heard so widely in universities today? Second, what place does decolonising the curriculum have in these broader demands for decolonising the university? Third, what are the experiences with decolonising the university curriculum in different parts of the world? Fourth, what would it mean to decolonise the curriculum in Cambridge?</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><br />
<em>CRASSH is not reponsible for the content of external websites</em></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Administrative assistant:<a href="mailto:gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk"> gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk</a></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Convenors</h3>
										<p><strong>Convenors</strong></p>

<p><a href="mailto:arb209@cam.ac.uk">Dr Adam Branch</a> (POLIS)<br />
<a href="mailto:md644@cam.ac.uk">Dr Manali Desai</a> (Department of Sociology)<br />
<a href="mailto:mm2051@cam.ac.uk">Dr Monica Moreno Figueroa </a>(Department of Sociology)<br />
<a href="mailto:as621@cam.ac.uk">Dr Arathi Sriprakash</a> (Faculty of Education)</p>

<p><br />
<strong>Faculty Advisors</strong></p>

<p>Dr Jo-Anne Dillabough (Reader, Faculty of Education)</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Programme 2016-17</h3>
										<p><table class="table table-bordered table-striped table-hover mt20"><thead><tr><th>Decolonising the curriculum in Theory and Practice</th></tr></thead><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26978">Decolonizing the Curriculum (Launch)</a></strong><br><i>19 October 2016, Seminar Room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Kehinde Andrews (Birmingham), Kerem Nisancioglu (SOAS), Sarah Radcliffe (Cambridge) -at Decolonising the Curriculum</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26979">Decolonising the Curriculum: Experiences from Latin America</a></strong><br><i>02 November 2016, Seminar Room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Antonio Sergio Guimaraes (S&atilde;o Paulo), Rosaleen Howard (Newcastle), David Lehmann (Cambridge)-at Decolonising the Curriculum</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26980">Pedagogy Workshop. Decolonising Pedagogies or Decolonising the Mind?</a></strong><br><i>16 November 2016, Seminar Room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Debbie Epstein (Roehampton), Sharon Walker (Cambridge)-at Decolonising the Curriculum. Online Registration. Limited places</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26983">Decolonizing the Curriculum: Lessons from South Asia</a></strong><br><i>30 November 2016, Seminar Room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Subir Sinha (SOAS), Ananya Mishra and Mahvish Ahmed (University of Cambridge) (Cambridge) -at Decolonising the Curriculum</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27098">Racism and Emotions in Knowledge-Encounters (Workshop)</a></strong><br><i>01 February 2017, Seminar room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>M&oacute;nica Moreno Figueroa (Cambridge) -at Decolonising the Curriculum<br />
Free but Registration required. (POLIS)- at Decolonising the Curriculum</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27102">Transforming the Tripos?</a></strong><br><i>15 March 2017, Seminar room SG1, Alison Richard the Curriculum in Theory and Practice</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27185">British Migration History: Reconstructing the Curriculum</a></strong><br><i>24 May 2017, Seminar Room SG2, 						<div class="span12">
							<h1>Digital Art</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">Alternate Thursdays, 17:00-19:00pm during term-time. </h4>
							
							<p class="meta">
								<span class="location">Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building</span>
							</p>
							
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Convenors</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Programme 2017-18</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<h4>Digital Art Research Group</h4>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Digital technologies have shaped utopian and dystopian visions of global communication, financialisation, and surveillance, and have expanded our forms of perception. These developments have not only captured the imagination of artists, but also motivated them to become agents in the digitized world. Working across video and online platforms, digital artists have critically commented on themes such as privacy, civil liberties, cultural ownership, the economy and individual agency; at the same time, many have themselves become forerunners in the fields of science, technology, and activism. These practices have often had an impact outside the artistic sphere, cutting across disciplinary and institutional boundaries.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">The focus of this research group is therefore to investigate the role that digital art can play in helping us to understand, critique, and shape the impact of digital technologies on contemporary society. What, if anything, makes the practices in question recognisably artistic? How are established aesthetic concepts challenged when, for example, the work of financial activists is exhibited at contemporary art biennales, or when human rights tribunals rely on digital image analysis provided by architects and filmmakers? This group&rsquo;s interest in the relationship between digital art and the spheres of science, technology and aesthetics will allow us to deepen our understanding of these processes via situated case studies, and to do so within an interdisciplinary context. Each term will be organised around two invited talks and two reading sessions.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><br />
<strong>Michaelmas Term 2017:</strong> <em>Digital Art and Financialisation</em></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Throughout this term, we aim to consider digital art&rsquo;s important and dynamic role in documenting, rethinking, and opposing digital financial technologies. Such practices range from video works shown in a gallery context (Hito Steyerl, Andrew Norman Wilson, Olia Lialina) to grassroots participatory projects (Robin Hood Co-Operative). In interrogating the status of artworks which take global finance as both theme and medium, we also aim to reflect upon the aesthetic and ethical implications of artistic practices embedded in digital technologies.<br />
<br />
<strong>Lent Term 2018</strong>:<em> Digital Art and Surveillance</em></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">While the digitalization of surveillance has become pervasive in contemporary societies, it has also given rise to new loopholes, potential failure, and sites of invisibility. This phenomenon will be our focus during Lent Term, during which we will look at how artists have both used surveillance technologies and exposed their potential perils. Our reading sessions will seek to analyse new forms of artistic agency, mediation, and subjectivity fostered by a post-Foucauldian model of government (&lsquo;super-panopticon&rsquo;).</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p>Administrative assistance: <a href="mailto:gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk">gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk</a></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Convenors</h3>
										<p><strong>Convenors</strong></p>

<p><a href="mailto:agg28@cam.ac.uk">Dr Aline Guillermet&nbsp;</a> (JRF, King&rsquo;s College, Visual Culture, History of Art)<br />
<a href="mailto:mp592@cam.ac.uk">Dr Mara Polgovsky&nbsp;</a> (JRF, Queens&rsquo; College, Latin American Studies, MML)<br />
<a href="mailto:vs418@cam.ac.uk">Dr Vid Simoniti&nbsp;</a> (JRF, Churchill College, Philosophy, History of Art)<br />
<a href="mailto:martin.zeilinger@anglia.ac.uk">Dr Martin Zeilinger&nbsp;</a> ( Lecturer in Media, Dept. of English &amp; Media, Anglia Ruskin University)</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Programme 2017-18</h3>
										<p><table class="table table-bordered table-striped table-hover mt20"><thead><tr><th>Digital Art</th></tr></thead><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27393">'Art and Money Online' in Retrospect</a></strong><br><i>10 October 2017, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Julian Stallabrass (Courtauld Institute of Art) - Digital Art</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27395">Theorising Digital Art as Financial Technology</a></strong><br><i>24 October 2017, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Reading session - Digital Art</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27396">Digital Art as Critical Medium of Exchange</a></strong><br><i>07 November 2017, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Reading Session - Digital Art</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27397">The Artist Leaving the Googleplex</a></strong><br><i>21 November 2017, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Andrew Norman Wilson&nbsp; (Artist) - Digital Art</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27562">Seeing across the Distance: The Dreams and Fears of Televisual Utopias</a></strong><br><i>25 January 2018, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Manu Luksch (Artist) - Digital Art</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27563">The Aesthetics of Surveillance</a></strong><br><i>08 February 2018, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Reading session - Digital Art</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27564">Metric Mysticism</a></strong><br><i>22 February 2018, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Zach Blas (Artist, Goldsmiths, London) - Digital Art</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27565">Crowdsourcing National Security: Gamification Practices in the US-Mexico Border</a></strong><br><i>08 March 2018, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Joana Moll (Artist) - Digital Art</p></td></tr></table></p>
									</div>

	<title>Cambridge Digital Humanities Strategic Network &ndash; CRASSH</title>
	

	<meta name="description" content="Established at the University of Cambridge in 2001, the Centre for Research in the Arts, Social Sciences and Humanities (CRASSH) works actively with the Schools and Faculties across the University undertaking collaborations that cross faculties and disciplines in order to stimulate fresh thinking and dialogue in and beyond the humanities and social sciences and to reach out to new collaborators and new publics." />
	<meta name="keywords" content="crassh, CRASSH, Centre for Research in the Arts, Social Sciences and Humanities, humanities centre, humanities center, interdisciplinary, interdisciplinarity, conferences, seminars, lectures, research, fellowships, call for papers, early career fellowships, graduate, postdoctoral fellowships, visiting fellowships, risk, conference, modelling futures, challenging models, uncertainty, david spiegelhalter" />

						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >2017-18 Programme</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Machine Reading the Archive Programme 2017-18</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="4" >Past Events</a></li>
									</ul>

								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;">Cambridge Digital Humanities Network has been funded by the university since 2011 as a strategic research network. We are a network of researchers at Cambridge who are interested in how the use of digital tools is transforming scholarship in the humanities and social sciences. This transformation spans both the content and practice of humanities research, as the diffusion of digital technologies opens up new fields of study and generates research questions which breach traditional disciplinary boundaries.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">We are now working towards the development of Cambridge Digital Humanities, which will bring together the DH research community with colleagues from the University Library and UIS to provide a greater level of support for DH research at Cambridge.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">We organise an extensive <a href="https://www.digitalhumanities.cam.ac.uk/Methods/">Digital Methods programme</a> which runs throughout the year hosted by CRASSH and in other venues across the University.</p>

<p>Find out more on our website <a href="https://www.digitalhumanities.cam.ac.uk/">www.digitalhumanities.cam.ac.uk</a> or contact <a href="mailto:raa43@cam.ac.uk">Dr Anne Alexander</a>.</p>

<p align="justify">&nbsp;</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">2017-18 Programme</h3>
										<p><strong>Michaelmas Term 2017</strong></p>

<p>Thursday 16 November 2017<br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27498">Curating your own Digital Archive</a></p>

<p>Tuesday 21 November 2017<br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27499">Webscraping for Beginners</a></p>

<p>Monday 27 November 2017<br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27549">The Ethics of Doing Research in the Digital Age: Understanding Digital Footprints</a></p>

<p>Tuesday 5 December 2017<br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27550">Can Social Media Work for Me?</a></p>

<p>Friday 15 December 2017<br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27551">Beyond Words: Workshop 1 (Mapping the Conceptual Terrain)</a></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Machine Reading the Archive Programme 2017-18</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;">Cambridge Digital Humanities and Cambridge Digital History with the support of the Researcher Development Programme and AHRC DTP<br />
<br />
Machine Reading the Archive brings together humanities and social science researchers, archivists and computer scientists to explore the challenges of working with archives in the digital age. Through a mentoring scheme supporting digital archive projects and a series of practical workshops, technical demonstrations, field trips and a one day end-of-programme showcase, we hope to seed new collaborations and encourage the exchange of ideas and practices across professions and disciplines.<br />
<br />
<strong>Registered participants must be PhD students or staff at the University and Colleges of Cambridge.</strong><br />
<br />
There are two ways to take part in the programme &ndash; through our group sessions and workshops, and by applying for a place on our Projects track.<br />
<br />
Machine Reading the Archive Projects provides PhD students and staff at the University of Cambridge individual mentoring and support in developing a digital archives project.<br />
Selected participants for MRtA Projects will be offered 4 x 1 hour individual/paired mentoring sessions with our Digital Methods Fellows, Dr Gabe Recchia and Dr Paul Nulty and 1 x 1 hour individual session on collaboration, networking and funding opportunities with Dr Anne Alexander, Cambridge Digital Humanities Network Coordinator. The sessions will be arranged at mutually convenient times between December 2017 and June 2018. Successful applicants will also be expected to give a short presentation about their project at the end-of-programme workshop in June 2018.<br />
<br />
Participants in MRtA Projects are strongly encouraged to attend Machine Reading the Archive group sessions and other relevant digital methods training sessions and workshops.<br />
Applications for MRtA Projects are open from 18 October to 12 noon on 20 November.<br />
Registration for the MRtA programme group sessions is open throughout the academic year.<br />
<br />
Useful links:<br />
&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Apply for MRtA Projects: <a href="https://www.digitalhumanities.cam.ac.uk/Methods/mtra/mrta-application-Track2">https://www.digitalhumanities.cam.ac.uk/Methods/mtra/mrta-application-Track2</a><br />
&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Read our FAQ about MRtA Projects: <a href="http://www.digitalhumanities.cam.ac.uk/Methods/mtra/mrta-projects-FAQ">http://www.digitalhumanities.cam.ac.uk/Methods/mtra/mrta-projects-FAQ</a><br />
&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Register here for the MRtA programme: <a href="https://www.digitalhumanities.cam.ac.uk/Methods/mtra/mrta-programme-reg-Track1">https://www.digitalhumanities.cam.ac.uk/Methods/mtra/mrta-programme-reg-Track1</a><br />
Dates for your diary:<br />
Group sessions must be booked online as spaces are limited &ndash; please check the website for details: <a href="https://www.digitalhumanities.cam.ac.uk/events">https://www.digitalhumanities.cam.ac.uk/events</a><br />
&bull; Curating your own digital archive (16 November) &ndash; book here: <a href="https://www.digitalhumanities.cam.ac.uk/events/mrta-curating-own-archive-Nov17">https://www.digitalhumanities.cam.ac.uk/events/mrta-curating-own-archive-Nov17</a><br />
&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Webscraping for beginners (21 November) &ndash; book here: <a href="https://www.digitalhumanities.cam.ac.uk/events/mrta-curating-own-archive-Nov17">https://www.digitalhumanities.cam.ac.uk/events/mrta-curating-own-archive-Nov17</a><br />
&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; How to turn your PDFs into searchable text (introduction to simple OCR tools)(23 January)<br />
&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Using Python to transform and analyse your data (introduction to Jupyter notebooks)(22 February)<br />
&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Build and publish a simple digital archive or collection (Introduction to Omeka)(8 May)<br />
&bull;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Text-mining the archive &ndash; an introduction (24 April and 1 May)<br />
<br />
&nbsp;</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="4" class="tab ">

			Monday 20 November 2017

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<div>
<div>
<div>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The competition for 2017-18 is now closed. </strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">The European Institutes for Advanced Study (<a href="http://www.2016-2017.eurias-fp.eu/">EURIAS</a>) Fellowship Programme is an international researcher mobility programme. It builds on the strong reputation of the Institutes for Advanced Study for promoting the focused, self-directed work of excellent researchers within the stimulating environment of a multidisciplinary and international group of fellows.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">The Programme offers 10-month residencies --mainly in the Humanities and Social sciences-- in Berlin, Bologna,&nbsp;Budapest, Cambridge, Delmenhorst, Edinburgh, Freiburg, Helsinki, Jerusalem, Lyon, Marseille, Paris, Uppsala, Vienna, Wassenaar, Z&uuml;rich.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<p><strong>EURIAS Fellow 2017-18</strong><br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/marie-louise-herzfeld-schild">Dr Marie Louis Herzfeld-Schild</a> (Bielelefeld University)<br />
The Emotional Effects of Music between Medicine and Aesthetics (1740-1880)</p>

<p><strong>Past Fellows</strong></p>

<p><strong>EURIAS Fellow 2016-17</strong><br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/daniel-juette">Dr Daniel J&uuml;tte</a> (Harvard)<br />
<em>Transparency: The Cultural History of an Idea</em></p>

<p><strong>EURIAS Fellow 2015-16</strong><br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/fernando-chavarria-mujica">Dr. Fernando Chavarr&iacute;a-M&uacute;gica</a> (University Nova, Lisbon)<br />
<em>Borderland entanglements: A comparative approach to civil-military relations during the First Global Age</em></p>

<p><strong>EURIAS Fellow 2014-15</strong><br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/gabor-kosa">Dr G&aacute;bor K&oacute;sa</a> (E&ouml;tv&ouml;s Lor&aacute;nd University (ELTE), Budapest)<br />
<em>A Comparative Analysis of Manichaean Texts and Paintings</em></p>

<p><strong>EURIAS Fellow 2013-14</strong><br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/dr-chiara-bortolotto">Dr Chiara Bortolotto </a>(&Eacute;cole des hautes &eacute;tudes en sciences sociales (Paris)<br />
<em>The Production of a global norm: grassroots participation in the UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Convention&nbsp;</em></p>

<p><strong>EURIAS Feillow 2012-13</strong><br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/wilson-jacob">Dr Wilson Jacob </a>(Concordia University)<br />
<em><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/25006">Cultures and Politics of the Transregional: Sovereignty between Empires and States</a></em></p>

<p><strong>EURIAS Fellow 2011-12</strong><br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/pavel-blazhek">Dr Pavel Blazek&nbsp;</a> (Czech Academy of Sciences, Prague)<br />
<em><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/24544">Medieval Islamic Marriage: An Interdisciplinary Workshop</a></em></p>
									</div>
								</div>
							</div>
						</article>
					</div>
				</div>

	<li>
		<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/blog/post/waltz-with-bashir-a-discussion-on-visual-technologies-representational-capa" class="title">Waltz with Bashir: A discussion on visual technologies’ representational capacities</a>
		<footer>
			
			Wednesday 22 November 2017
		</footer>
	</li><li>
		<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/blog/post/ukraine-and-the-challenges-of-international-law-5-questions-to-bohdan-tokar" class="title">Ukraine and the Challenges of International Law: 5 Questions to Bohdan Tokarskyi</a>
		<footer>
			
			Monday 20 November 2017

	<meta name="description" content="Established at the University of Cambridge in 2001, the Centre for Research in the Arts, Social Sciences and Humanities (CRASSH) works actively with the Schools and Faculties across the University undertaking collaborations that cross faculties and disciplines in order to stimulate fresh thinking and dialogue in and beyond the humanities and social sciences and to reach out to new collaborators and new publics." />

			<div class="row">
				<div class="span8">
					<article>

						<div style="text-align: justify;">For information on current fellowship competitions and online application please click <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/applications/">here</a>.</div>

<div style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</div>

<p style="text-align: justify; ">The Centre offers a number of programmes to bring scholars from all over the world to CRASSH - from postdoctoral and early career researchers to more established visiting fellows - to interact at the heart of a vibrant interdisciplinary research environment.&nbsp; As the fellowship group grows, it becomes clearer than ever not only what our visitors gain from access to Cambridge research resources, but also how much they bring to Cambridge: the lively intellectual traffic that energises an international university.&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; ">For further information: <a href="mailto:fellowships@crassh.cam.ac.uk">fellowships@crassh.cam.ac.uk</a></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; "><strong>For information about the appointed Fellows for 2017-18 please click <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/crassh-fellows-2017-18">here.</a></strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; "><strong>For information about the Work in Progress Seminars in 2017-18 please click <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/work-in-progress-seminars-2017-18">here.</a></strong></p>

						 <!-- Fellowships -->

            </li>
            <li class="email">
                <a href="mailto:?subject=Fellowships&body=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/fellowships" data-social-text="Share via email">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icon_mailing.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
        </ul>
    </nav>
</div>
</div>
			</div>
			
			<div class="row">
				<div class="span8">
					<article>

						<div style="text-align: justify;">For information on current fellowship competitions and online application please click <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/applications/">here</a>.</div>

<div style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</div>

<p style="text-align: justify; ">The Centre offers a number of programmes to bring scholars from all over the world to CRASSH - from postdoctoral and early career researchers to more established visiting fellows - to interact at the heart of a vibrant interdisciplinary research environment.&nbsp; As the fellowship group grows, it becomes clearer than ever not only what our visitors gain from access to Cambridge research resources, but also how much they bring to Cambridge: the lively intellectual traffic that energises an international university.&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; ">For further information: <a href="mailto:fellowships@crassh.cam.ac.uk">fellowships@crassh.cam.ac.uk</a></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; "><strong>For information about the appointed Fellows for 2017-18 please click <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/crassh-fellows-2017-18">here.</a></strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify; "><strong>For information about the Work in Progress Seminars in 2017-18 please click <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/work-in-progress-seminars-2017-18">here.</a></strong></p>

						 <!-- Fellowships -->

	<div class="row mb15">
		<div class="span12">
			<ul id="breadcrumb">
				<li class="first">You are here:</li>
				
					<li><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk">Home</a> <li class='chevron'><img src='/static/svg/chevron_right_grey.svg' /></li class='chevron'> </li><li><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/">Research</a> <li class='chevron'><img src='/static/svg/chevron_right_grey.svg' /></li class='chevron'> </li><li><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/fellowships/">Fellowships</a> <li class='chevron'><img src='/static/svg/chevron_right_grey.svg' /></li class='chevron'> </li><li class="last">Announcing the Nine Dots Prize</li>

			<div class="row">
				<div class="span8"><h1>Announcing the Nine Dots Prize</h1></div>
				<div class="span4 hidden-phone pt10"><div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>
            <li class="twitter">
                <a href="https://twitter.com/share?text=Announcing the Nine Dots Prize&url=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/fellowships/the-nine-dots-prize" data-social-text="Share on Twitter">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_twitter.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="facebook">
                <a href="http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/fellowships/the-nine-dots-prize" data-social-text="Share on Facebook">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_facebook.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="email">
                <a href="mailto:?subject=Announcing the Nine Dots Prize&body=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/fellowships/the-nine-dots-prize" data-social-text="Share via email">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icon_mailing.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
        </ul>
    </nav>
</div>
</div>
			</div>
			
			<div class="row">
				<div class="span8">
					<article>

						<p><strong><em>&#39;Are digital technologies making politics impossible?&#39;</em></strong></p>

<p><strong>The inaugural Nine Dots Prize offers $100,000 for the best response to this question.</strong></p>

<p><strong>Prize backed by leading international thinkers including Diane Coyle, Simon Goldhill, David Runciman and Saskia Sassen</strong></p>

<p>A new prize launched today (Friday 21 October 2016) is offering US$100,000 and a book deal with Cambridge University Press to whoever can best answer the question &lsquo;Are digital technologies making politics impossible?&rsquo;</p>

<p>The Nine Dots Prize is designed to promote and encourage innovative thinking to address problems facing the modern world. Its name references a lateral thinking puzzle that can only be solved by drawing outside of a box of nine dots arranged in three rows of three.</p>

<p>The Prize will be judged anonymously by a 12-strong Board of internationally recognised and distinguished academics, authors, journalists and thinkers. The Board will be chaired by Professor Simon Goldhill, director of CRASSH, Professor in Greek Literature and Culture and Fellow of King&#39;s College, Cambridge.</p>

<p>The Prize is open to anyone aged 18 years or over writing in English, and welcomes submissions from both new voices and experienced authors. To enter, people are asked to respond to the set question in 3,000 words and provide an outline structure showing how, if they win, they would develop their argument into a short book. A new question will be set every two years.</p>

<p>Chair of the Board, Professor Goldhill says: &ldquo;This is an incredibly exciting and unique opportunity for thinkers to table big ideas that have the potential to change the world. The Board will be looking for entries that display originality in everything from the ideas put forward to the ways in which those ideas are communicated. Respondents are entirely free to critique, agree or disagree with, or reject the premise of the question, but they must engage with it fully and insightfully.&rdquo;</p>

<p>The Nine Dots Prize is funded by the Kadas Prize Foundation, an English registered charity established to fund research into significant but neglected questions relevant to today&rsquo;s world.</p>

<p>Diane Coyle, Board member and Professor of Economics at Manchester University, explains: &ldquo;As it is up to the entrant to decide what the question means to them, we&rsquo;re anticipating a fascinating range of responses to this important topic. Our hope is that the Prize will encourage original and inspiring thinking from diverse individuals coming from a wide variety of places and backgrounds and suggesting innovative new approaches.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Entries must be submitted through the online submission form on the Nine Dots Prize website. The deadline for submitting is midnight on Tuesday 31 January and the winner will be announced in May 2017.</p>

<p>For more information, and to enter the Nine Dots Prize, visit <a href="http://www.ninedotsprize.org">www.ninedotsprize.org</a> and follow the Prize on Twitter @ninedotsprize</p>

						
							
<div class="row relatedBlocks mt20 mb20">

	

</div>
						

					</article>
				</div>

	<div class="row mb15">
		<div class="span12">
			<ul id="breadcrumb">
				<li class="first">You are here:</li>
				
					<li><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk">Home</a> <li class='chevron'><img src='/static/svg/chevron_right_grey.svg' /></li class='chevron'> </li><li><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/">Research</a> <li class='chevron'><img src='/static/svg/chevron_right_grey.svg' /></li class='chevron'> </li><li><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/fellowships/">Fellowships</a> <li class='chevron'><img src='/static/svg/chevron_right_grey.svg' /></li class='chevron'> </li><li class="last">Announcing the Nine Dots Prize</li>

			<div class="row">
				<div class="span8"><h1>Announcing the Nine Dots Prize</h1></div>
				<div class="span4 hidden-phone pt10"><div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>
            <li class="twitter">
                <a href="https://twitter.com/share?text=Announcing the Nine Dots Prize&url=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/fellowships/the-nine-dots-prize" data-social-text="Share on Twitter">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_twitter.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="facebook">
                <a href="http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/fellowships/the-nine-dots-prize" data-social-text="Share on Facebook">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_facebook.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="email">
                <a href="mailto:?subject=Announcing the Nine Dots Prize&body=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/fellowships/the-nine-dots-prize" data-social-text="Share via email">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icon_mailing.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
        </ul>
    </nav>
</div>
</div>
			</div>
			
			<div class="row">
				<div class="span8">
					<article>

						<p><strong><em>&#39;Are digital technologies making politics impossible?&#39;</em></strong></p>

<p><strong>The inaugural Nine Dots Prize offers $100,000 for the best response to this question.</strong></p>

<p><strong>Prize backed by leading international thinkers including Diane Coyle, Simon Goldhill, David Runciman and Saskia Sassen</strong></p>

<p>A new prize launched today (Friday 21 October 2016) is offering US$100,000 and a book deal with Cambridge University Press to whoever can best answer the question &lsquo;Are digital technologies making politics impossible?&rsquo;</p>

<p>The Nine Dots Prize is designed to promote and encourage innovative thinking to address problems facing the modern world. Its name references a lateral thinking puzzle that can only be solved by drawing outside of a box of nine dots arranged in three rows of three.</p>

<p>The Prize will be judged anonymously by a 12-strong Board of internationally recognised and distinguished academics, authors, journalists and thinkers. The Board will be chaired by Professor Simon Goldhill, director of CRASSH, Professor in Greek Literature and Culture and Fellow of King&#39;s College, Cambridge.</p>

<p>The Prize is open to anyone aged 18 years or over writing in English, and welcomes submissions from both new voices and experienced authors. To enter, people are asked to respond to the set question in 3,000 words and provide an outline structure showing how, if they win, they would develop their argument into a short book. A new question will be set every two years.</p>

<p>Chair of the Board, Professor Goldhill says: &ldquo;This is an incredibly exciting and unique opportunity for thinkers to table big ideas that have the potential to change the world. The Board will be looking for entries that display originality in everything from the ideas put forward to the ways in which those ideas are communicated. Respondents are entirely free to critique, agree or disagree with, or reject the premise of the question, but they must engage with it fully and insightfully.&rdquo;</p>

<p>The Nine Dots Prize is funded by the Kadas Prize Foundation, an English registered charity established to fund research into significant but neglected questions relevant to today&rsquo;s world.</p>

<p>Diane Coyle, Board member and Professor of Economics at Manchester University, explains: &ldquo;As it is up to the entrant to decide what the question means to them, we&rsquo;re anticipating a fascinating range of responses to this important topic. Our hope is that the Prize will encourage original and inspiring thinking from diverse individuals coming from a wide variety of places and backgrounds and suggesting innovative new approaches.&rdquo;</p>

<p>Entries must be submitted through the online submission form on the Nine Dots Prize website. The deadline for submitting is midnight on Tuesday 31 January and the winner will be announced in May 2017.</p>

<p>For more information, and to enter the Nine Dots Prize, visit <a href="http://www.ninedotsprize.org">www.ninedotsprize.org</a> and follow the Prize on Twitter @ninedotsprize</p>

						
							
<div class="row relatedBlocks mt20 mb20">

	

</div>
						

					</article>
				</div>

					<div class="row mb10">
						<div class="span12">
							<h1>Food: Field to Table?&nbsp; [2015-2016]</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">From 2015 to 20016</h4>
							
							<p class="meta">
								<span class="location">Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building, CRASSH</span>
							</p>
							
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>
            <li class="twitter">

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Conveners</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Programme 2015-16</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;">Food gives life. It provides energy, strengthens social bonds and enriches culture worldwide. Our collective hunger has remodelled the globe. We have flattened forests, emptied seas and developed an incredible range of technologies to satisfy our collective appetite. Parts of the world have unrestricted access to nutritious food, but many regions are in desperate need of calories or micronutrients. Millions suffer and die from an excess of food while millions suffer and die from a lack of it.<br />
<br />
This research group examines multiple aspects of the global food system, following food across academic boundaries from field to table. We cover the collective impact of technological innovations, market forces and human behaviour on global food security. Our aim is to explore how much optimisation can take place within the traditional architecture of our food system and explore the potential of emerging alternative food systems to provide solutions.<br />
<br />
Food has the power to help billions, provoke conflict and make or break the economies of entire continents. By bringing together early career researchers from across the University for a seminar series and focussed reading group, we hope to stimulate wide discussion on some of the core questions faced in securing our global food future.<br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Themes for 2015-16</strong></p>

<p>Michaelmas Term:&nbsp; Generating Food<br />
Lent Term: &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp; Market Forces<br />
Easter Term:&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Consumer Choices</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p>Open to all.&nbsp; No registration required<br />
Part of the <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/food-field-to-table">Food: Field to Table?</a> Research Group, series</p>

<p>Administrative assistance<a href="mailto:gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk">: gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk</a></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Conveners</h3>
										<p><strong>Conveners</strong></p>

<p><a href="mailto:cga24@cam.ac.uk">Claire Agius</a>&nbsp;(Department of Plant Sciences)<br />
<a href="mailto:lab70@cam.ac.uk">Luke A Braidwood</a><b>&nbsp;</b>(Department of Plant Sciences)<br />
<a href="mailto:klg37@cam.ac.uk">Dr Ksenia Gerasimova</a>&nbsp;(Centre of Development Studies)<br />
<a href="mailto:rh478@cam.ac.uk">Regina&nbsp;Hansda</a>&nbsp;(Department of Geography)<br />
<a href="mailto:gjm38@cam.ac.uk">Greg Mellers</a>&nbsp; (Department of Plant Sciences)<br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Faculty Advisors</strong></p>

<p>Dr Will Simonson<strong>&nbsp;</strong>(Department of Plant Sciences)<br />
Dr Bhaskar Vira (Department of Geography)</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Programme 2015-16</h3>
										<p>&nbsp;<table class="table table-bordered table-striped table-hover mt20"><thead><tr><th>Food field to table</th></tr></thead><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26405">The Importance of Food in a Changing Climate</a></strong><br><i>02 December 2015, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Nazia Habib-Minz (Cambridge), Katrin Glatzel (Imperial College) -Food: Field to Building</i><br><p>Catherine Barnard (Cambridge) -Food: Field to Table?</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26584">The Roles of Gender and Technology in Market 						<div class="span12">
							<h1>Genius Before Romanticism: Ingenuity in Early Modern Art and Science</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							
							 
						</div>

									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >People</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Affiliated Scholars</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="4" >Visiting Fellows</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="5" >Events</a></li>
