								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p><strong>ERC-funded research project</strong><br />
2014&ndash;2019<br />
CRASSH, University of Cambridge</p>

<p><b>What existed in the European imagination before the Romantic concept of &lsquo;genius&rsquo;?</b></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">This five-year ERC-funded research project, led by Dr Alexander Marr, Department of History of Art, will examine notions of unique talent, heightened imagination and extraordinary creativity in art and science by exploring the language, theories, practices and products of ingenium (ingenuity) ca. 1450&ndash;ca. 1750.&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Drawing on the perspectives of history of art, history of science, technology and medicine, intellectual history and literary studies, the project seeks to capture ingenuity across and between disciplines.&nbsp; Studying six countries (France, Germany, the Netherlands, Italy, England and Spain) across three centuries, it will trace ingenuity&rsquo;s shifting patterns and fragmented fortunes over the longue dur&eacute;e.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Research will be conducted in four strands, focused on distinctive but interrelated aspects of ingenuity:</p>

<ul>
	<li>the &lsquo;Language of Ingenuity&rsquo; will chart the word history of the ingenuity family of terms;</li>
	<li>&lsquo;Conceptualizing Ingenuity&rsquo; will explore the intellectual framework of ingenuity through its theoretical treatment in natural philosophy and artistic theory;</li>
	<li>&lsquo;Ingenuity in the Making&rsquo; will examine the cunning knowledge of ingenious craftsmen and the properties of &lsquo;spirited&rsquo; materials;</li>
	<li>&lsquo;Ingenious Images&rsquo; will investigate the visual culture of ingenuity, from the iconography of ingenium to the witty disingenuousness of optical games.&nbsp;</li>
</ul>

<p>This project is based at CRASSH, which also co-hosts jointly with English, the ERC project <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/crossroads"><em>Crossroads of Knowledge in Early Modern England: the Place of Literature</em>.&nbsp;</a></p>

<p>For further information please contact<a href="mailto:genius@crassh.cam.ac.uk">&nbsp;genius@crassh.cam.ac.uk.</a></p>

<p>&nbsp;<img alt="" src="/assets/general/LOGO-ERC.jpg" style="width: 73px; height: 70px;" /></p>

<p><em style="line-height: 1.6em;">Funded&nbsp;by&nbsp;the European Research Council under the European Union&rsquo;s Seventh Framework Programme (FP7/2007-2013)/ ERC grant agreement no 617391.</em></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">People</h3>
										<p><strong>Principal Investigator</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/alexander-marr">Dr Alexander Marr</a>&nbsp;(History&nbsp;of Art, University of Cambridge)</p>

<p><strong>Senior Research Investigator</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/richard-serjeantson1" target="_blank">Dr Richard Serjeantson</a>&nbsp;(History,&nbsp;University of Cambridge) <em>until December 2016</em></p>

<p><strong>Senior Researcher</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/tim-chesters">Dr Timothy Chesters</a> (MML, University of Cambridge) <em>from October 2016</em></p>

<p><strong>Post-doctoral Research Associates</strong></p>

<p><a href="/people/profile/raphaele-garrod">Dr Rapha&euml;le Garrod</a><br />
<a href="/people/profile/jose-ramon-marcaida">Dr Jos&eacute; Ram&oacute;n Marcaida</a><br />
<a href="/people/profile/richard-oosterhoff">Dr Richard Oosterhoff</a></p>

<p><strong>Advisory Board</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.hoart.cam.ac.uk/people/pb214@cam.ac.uk">Professor Paul Binski</a>&nbsp;(Professor of the History of Medieval Art, University of Cambridge)<br />
<a href="http://www.hist.cam.ac.uk/directory/sk111@cam.ac.uk">Professor Sachiko Kusukawa</a> (History and Philosophy of Science, University of Cambridge)<br />
<a href="http://www.english.ox.ac.uk/people/professor-rhodri-lewis">Professor Rhodri Lewis&nbsp;</a>(Professor of English Literature, University of Oxford)<br />
<a href="http://www.english.cam.ac.uk/people/Mukherji/Subha/">Dr Subha Mukherji</a>&nbsp;(English, University of Cambridge)<br />
<a href="http://history.columbia.edu/faculty/smith-pamela-h/">Professor Pamela H. Smith</a>&nbsp;(Seth Low Professor of History, Columbia University)<br />
<a href="http://dornsife.usc.edu/cf/hist/people/faculty_display.cfm?Person_ID=1042779">Professor Jacob Soll</a>&nbsp;(Professor of History and Accounting, University of Southern California)<br />
<a href="http://courtauld.ac.uk/people/joanna-woodall">Professor Joanna Woodall&nbsp;(</a>The Courtauld Institute of Art, University of London)</p>

<p><strong>Administrator</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/gaenor-moore" target="_blank">Mrs Gaenor Moore</a></p>

<p><img alt="" src="/assets/general/gbr_venice.jpg" style="width: 500px;" /></p>

<p><em>From left to right: Jos&eacute; Ram&oacute;n Marcaida, Alexander Marr, Rapha&euml;le Garrod, Richard Oosterhoff (EM Keyword Conversation, Venice September 2016)</em></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Affiliated Scholars</h3>
										<p><strong>Affiliated Scholars</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/sietske-fransen" target="_blank">Dr&nbsp;Sietske Fransen </a>(Post-doctoral Research Fellow, Making Visible, CRASSH) Sietske&#39;s research&nbsp;&nbsp;focuses on the translation of early modern science. By studying translators and their practices she&nbsp;tries to analyse the role and function of translation as a form of circulation of knowledge. Textual translations from Latin to the vernaculars and vice versa are often understood as attempts to reach out to a wider readership. However, personal notebooks and marginal annotations in manuscript and printed books also seem to point towards mnemonic reasons for translating texts. Along the same line of this personal comprehension, she also looks at visualisations of scientific knowledge in manuscripts and printed books - from list and diagrams to actual images. This visual material often seems to have a role in the author&rsquo;s understanding, memorizing and application of the information in the text.</p>

<p><strong>Doctoral Student</strong><span style="line-height: 1.6em;">&nbsp;</span></p>

<p><strong>David Zagoury</strong> <em>(Cambridge Trust Scholar, Queens&#39; College, email <a href="mailto:dz276@cam.ac.uk">dz276@cam.ac.uk</a>)&nbsp;</em>David&#39;s&nbsp;doctoral project explores the faculty of imagination in the intellectual culture of sixteenth-century Italian artists. In particular, he is examining the notion of &#39;fantasia&#39; in the writings of artists and critics from Leonardo onwards, accounting for the sources and the nature of their conception of imagination. He is also investigating the iconography and visual representation of creativity and fantasy during the period.</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="4" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Visiting Fellows</h3>
										<p><u><strong>2014&ndash;2015</strong></u></p>

<p><strong>Dr Ita Mac Carthy (University of Birmingham)</strong></p>

<p>Dr Mac Carthy is Senior Lecturer at the University of Birmingham and specializes in Italian Renaissance literature and art. She focuses, in particular, on the connections between visual and verbal culture, on questions of literary genre and aesthetic practice and on women&rsquo;s studies. She is the author of<em> Women and the Making of Poetry in Ludovico Ariosto&rsquo;s Orlando furioso</em> (2007) and is currently writing <em>The Grace of the Italian Renaissance</em>, a book that explores the rise to prominence of the keyword &lsquo;grazia&rsquo; in early modern Italian society, literature and art. This interest in <em>grazia</em> is part of a broader concern with the keywords that early modern Europeans lived by, and in this vein, she has edited the volume <em>Renaissance Keywords</em> (2013) and co-directs with Dr Richard Scholar a research group, &lsquo;Early Modern Keywords&rsquo;, whose aim is to compile and explore a European vocabulary of culture and society of the period 1450-1700.</p>

<p><strong>Dr Richard Scholar (Oriel College, University of Oxford)</strong></p>

<p>Dr Scholar&#39;s main research interests lie in early modern French literature and thought, comparative and interdisciplinary early modern studies, and questions of critical method and theory. He is&nbsp;the author of two books: <em>Montaigne and the Art of Free-Thinking</em> (2010) and <em>The Je-Ne-Sais-Quoi in Early Modern Europe: Encounters with a Certain Something</em> (2005). His work is principally concerned with the keywords, linguistic structures, and literary forms that enabled early modern writers to test the limits of thought and expression in the period and that thus reveal fundamental features of early modern learning, culture, and society. Dr Scholar is currently working on a major reevaluation of Thomas More&rsquo;s Utopia and its afterlives in European literature and thought and is&nbsp;a member of the ANR-funded research collective Disputes, Controversies and Querelles (with Paris IV-Sorbonne) and a co-director of Early Modern Keywords, a research group that is compiling and exploring a European vocabulary of culture and society of the period 1450&ndash;1700, in the wake of <a href="http://www.legendabooks.com/titles/isbn/9781907975295.html" target="_blank"><em>Renaissance Keywords</em></a> (2013). From 2008&ndash;12, he led a four-year collaborative research project entitled &#39;Francophone Caribbean Writing in Context&#39;, which included a Leverhulme International Research Network on the topic of &lsquo;Caribbean Globalizations&rsquo;.</p>

<p><u><strong style="line-height: 1.6em;">2015-2016</strong></u></p>

<p><strong>Dr Guido Giglioni&nbsp;(Warburg Institute, London)</strong></p>

<p>Dr&nbsp;Giglioni teaches Renaissance Latin and philosophy at the Warburg Institute. His research deals with early modern ideas of life and imagination, and their relationships with both matter and knowledge.&nbsp;He studied philosophy at the University of Macerata, Italy, and graduated in history of science and medicine at the Johns Hopkins University in 2002 with a PhD dissertation on Francis Glisson, a seventeenth-century English anatomist who also&nbsp;engaged in philosophical inquiries on the nature of life. In his treatise on substance and its energy (De natura substantiae energetica, 1672), Glisson laid the foundations for the modern notion of irritability, described as an original property of matter. As Francis Bacon is one of the main sources in Glisson&rsquo;s work, on both a medical and philosophical level, in the past few years, Giglioni has been carrying out a wide-ranging research to trace the Baconian roots of early modern ideas of matter and life (from Telesio to Lamarck). An integral part of Giglioni&rsquo;s research programme is a&nbsp;comprehensive study of the imagination, as this faculty played a&nbsp;key role&nbsp;in explaining the vital processes of embodiment and ensoulment, both below&nbsp;and beyond&nbsp;the level of the representative powers (i.e., the senses and the intellect).</p>

<p><strong style="line-height: 1.6em;">Dr Marisa Bass&nbsp;(Washington University in St. Louis)</strong></p>

<p>Dr Bass is Assistant Professor at Washington University in St. Louis and a specialist in the art of the Netherlands from the fifteenth through the seventeenth centuries. Her research interests include intersections between art and intellectual culture, the visual impact of the Reformation, and Renaissance notions of imagination and invention. Her publications include articles in the Journal of the Warburg &amp; Courtauld Institutes and Simiolus and an essay on Hieronymus Bosch&#39;s "ingenium" in her forthcoming exhibition catalogue <em>Beyond Bosch: The Afterlife of a Renaissance Master in Print</em>&nbsp;(St. Louis Art Museum, April 2015). Her first book <em>The Embodied Past: Jan Gossart and the Invention of Netherlandish Antiquity</em>,&nbsp;is currently under review, and she is in the midst of completing the manuscript of her next book <em>Encrypted Knowledge: The Art of Joris Hoefnagel in the Wake of the Dutch Revolt</em>,&nbsp;which will be the topic of her research at CRASSH.</p>

<p><strong>Professor Claudia Swan (Northwestern University)</strong></p>

<p>Dr Swan is&nbsp;&nbsp;Associate Professor in the Department of Art History at Northwestern University. Her research interests include early modern (16th- and 17th-century) Dutch and Flemish art; art and science; early modern transcultural exchange of art and material culture; print culture; history of collecting and museology; history of the imagination; art historiography and critical traditions of art history. Dr Swan&#39;s recent publications include &ldquo;Exotica on the Move: Birds of Paradise in Early Modern Holland,&rdquo; in special issue, <em>Art History, Early Modern Objects in Motion</em>, ed. Daniela Bleichmar and Meredith Martin, forthcoming 2015; &ldquo;Conceptions, Chimeras, Counterfeits: Early Modern Theories of the Imagination and the Work of Art&rdquo; in <em>Vision and its Instruments, c. 1350&ndash;1750: The Art of Seeing and Seeing as an Art</em>, ed. Alina Payne, forthcoming, The Pennsylvania State University Press; &ldquo;Lost in Translation: Exoticism in Early Modern Holland,&rdquo; in <em>Art in Iran and Europe in the 17th Century: Exchange and Reception</em>, edited by Axel Langer (Museum Rietberg, Zurich, CH, 2013), 100&ndash;116; &ldquo;Birds of Paradise for the Sultan: Early Seventeenth-Century Dutch&ndash;Turkish Encounters and the Uses of Wonder,&rdquo; <em>De Zeventiende Eeuw</em> 29 (2013), 49&ndash;63.</p>

<p><u><strong>2016-2017</strong></u></p>

<p><strong>Professor Peter Stallybrass (University of Pennsylvania)</strong></p>

<p>Professor&nbsp;Stallybrass is Annenberg Professor in the Humanities at the&nbsp;University of Pennsylvania, where he has directed the History of Material Texts seminar since 1993. Peter has been awarded the Andrew Lang Gold Medal from the University of St. Andrews and four teaching awards from Penn. He was the Samuel Wannamaker Fellow at the Globe Theatre in London, the Moses Aaron Dropsie Fellow at the Center for Advanced Judaic Studies, and he is a member of the American Philosophical Society. He has collaborated with Jim Green on curating exhibitions on &ldquo;Material Texts&rdquo; and on Benjamin Franklin at the Library Company and the Grolier Club, and on the book&nbsp;Benjamin Franklin, Writer and Printer (2006). With Heather Wolfe, he curated the exhibition on &ldquo;Technologies of Writing in the Renaissance&rdquo; at the Folger Shakespeare Library. Stallybrass&rsquo;s work focuses on early modern printing and manuscripts and he is at present turning his Rosenbach Lectures in Bibliography on &ldquo;Printing for Manuscript&rdquo; into a book to be published by the University of Pennsylvania Press.</p>

<p><strong>Prof. Dr. Sven Dupr&eacute; (Utrecht University)</strong></p>

<p>Prof, Dr. &nbsp;Dupr&eacute; is Professor and Chair of History of Art, Science and Technology at Utrecht University, and Professor of History of Art, Science and Technology at the University of Amsterdam. He is the Scientific Director of the project &lsquo;Technique in the Arts: Concepts, Practices, Expertise, 1500-1950&rsquo;, supported by a European Research Council (ERC) Consolidator Grant. &nbsp;Previously he was Professor of History of Knowledge at the Freie Universit&auml;t and Director of the Research Group &lsquo;Art and Knowledge in Premodern Europe&rsquo; at the Max Planck Institute for the History of Science in Berlin. In Spring 2015 he was Robert H. Smith Scholar in Residence for Renaissance Sculpture in Context at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London.&nbsp;He is a member of the Descartes Centre for the History and Philosophy of the Sciences and the Humanities at Utrecht University, co-directing (with Wijnand Mijnhardt) the project &ldquo;Creating a Knowledge Society in a Globalizing World, 1450-1800&rdquo; in cooperation with the Max Planck Institute for the History of Science and the Netherlands Institute for Advanced Study (NIAS). He is actively involved in research in technical art history at the&nbsp;Ateliergebouw&nbsp;(Netherlands Institute for Conservation, Art and Science - NICAS) in Amsterdam, where the Rijksmuseum, the Cultural Heritage Agency of the Netherlands and the University of Amsterdam combine their knowledge in the field of restoration and preservation of art objects.</p>

<p><strong>Professor Pamela H.&nbsp;Smith (Columbia University)</strong></p>

<p>Professor Smith&nbsp;&nbsp;specializes in early modern European history and the history of science. Her current research focuses on attitudes to nature in early modern Europe and the Scientific Revolution, with particular attention to craft knowledge and historical techniques.&nbsp; She is founding director of the Making and Knowing Project, founding director of the Center for Science and Society &nbsp;and chair of the Presidential Scholars in Society and Neuroscience. The Making and Knowing Project involved Professor Smith&nbsp;&nbsp;and her team &nbsp;working on a Research and Pedagogical Initiative to produce a digital critical edition and English translation of a remarkable sixteenth-century French manuscript. The manuscript contains a huge variety of recipes and instructions for technical procedures, especially casting, moldmaking and metalworking experiments. These recipes form the basis for the work of PhD students and visiting expert makers in the Making and Knowing Laboratory.</p>

<p><u><strong>2017&ndash;2018</strong></u></p>

<p><strong>Professor Eileen Reeves (Princeton University)</strong></p>

<p>Professor Reeves&nbsp;is Professor and Chair of Comparative Literature and an Associate Member of the Program in the History of Science at Princeton University.&nbsp; She took her Ph.D. in Comparative Literature from Stanford.&nbsp; She works at the intersection of early modern literary studies, the history of art, and the history of science.&nbsp; Much of her research has focused on the figure of Galileo Galilei and his relationship to astronomy, religion, optics, art, and a range of literary forms, including the scientific treatise and dialogue, poetry, dialect literature, journalism, and drama. &nbsp;She is currently at work on a book about early modern color, which explores the complex emergence of chromatic theory, the sometime interest of painters in this philosophical project, the non-naturalistic deployment of color, and the improbably high incidence of lost, stolen, or censored treatises on color.&nbsp; Other recent or ongoing projects include essays on the relationships between optical and musical instruments, between astrology and literature, and between the new sciences and the visual arts.&nbsp;</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="5" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Events</h3>
										<p>Previous&nbsp;events</p>

<p><a href="/assets/general/Programme_withcover.pdf" style="line-height: 1.6em;" target="_blank">Word Histories of Ingenuity in Early Modernity</a><span style="line-height: 1.6em;">, 29 -&nbsp;30 May 2015</span></p>

<p><a href="/assets/general/Programme_withcover-AJM_edit.pdf" target="_blank">Ingenuity and Imagination in Early Modern Northern Art and Theory</a>, 21 - 22 January 2016</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26547" target="_blank">A Public Conversation about the History of Genius</a>,&nbsp;2 March 2016</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26342" style="line-height: 1.6em;" target="_blank">Descartes and Ingenium</a><span style="line-height: 1.6em;">,&nbsp;14 - 15 March 2016</span></p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26794" target="_blank">Ingenium and Imagination in the Renaissance: Diseases, Demons and Dreams,</a> 18 May 2016</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26883">Epistemic Images in Early Modern Germany and its Neighbours</a>, &nbsp;10 - 11 November 2016</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27190">Ingenuity in the Making</a>, 10-12 May 2017 including <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27233">A&nbsp;Public Lecture: Ingenious Failure: Artisanal Languages of Error - Sven Dupr&eacute;</a></p>

			<div class="row">
				<div class="span12">
					<div class="row mb10">
						<div class="span12">
							<h1>Global Science [2013-2015]</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">From 2013 to 2015</h4>
							 
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>
            <li class="twitter">
                <a href="https://twitter.com/share?text=Global Science [2013-2015]&url=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/global-science" data-social-text="Share on Twitter">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_twitter.svg">
                </a>
            </li>

						</div>
					</div>
					<hr>
				</div>
			</div>

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Conveners</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Past events</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;"><br />
Science operates on a global stage, but this is not a recent phenomenon. Our research group explores the relationship between global history and science studies. Science here is broadly construed. Histories of natural knowledge, technology and medicine all fall under the remit of this group. By adopting this approach we look to invite discussion on the relationship between the politics of globalisation and the making of the very category of &lsquo;science&rsquo;. What counts as science is precisely the product of a series of uneven historical encounters. Often the transit of scientific material, from books to barometers, relied on the lopsided development of colonialism and global capitalism. We therefore hope to trace, not only the movement of science across borders, but also the limits of the apparent globalisation of scientific knowledge.<br />
<br />
In 2014-2015 we bring together speakers from history, geography and anthropology. By drawing on academics from across disciplines, we offer a new base for the growing network of academics working on global histories of science.<br />
&nbsp;</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Conveners</h3>
										<p><strong>Conveners</strong></p>

<p><a href="mailto:lss32@cam.ac.uk">Lys Alcayna-Stevens</a>&nbsp; (Department of Social Anthropology)<br />
<a href="mailto:mb843@cam.ac.uk">Megan Barford</a> (Department of History and Philosophy&nbsp;of Science)<br />
<a href="mailto:jh567@cam.ac.uk">James Hall&nbsp;&nbsp;</a>&nbsp; (Department of History and Philosophy&nbsp;of Science)<br />
<a href="mailto:jdgp2@cam.ac.uk">James Poskett&nbsp;</a> (Department of History and Philosophy of Science)<br />
<a href="mailto:tas49@cam.ac.uk">Tom Simpson</a>&nbsp; (Faculty of History)<br />
<a href="mailto:aaw37@cam.ac.uk">Aaron Watts</a> (Faculty of History)</p>

<p><strong>2013-14</strong><br />
Johanna Gon&ccedil;alves Mart&iacute;n&nbsp; (Department of Social Anthropology)<br />
Jagjeet Lally&nbsp; (Faculty of History)<br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Faculty Advisors</strong></p>

<p>Professor Alison Bashford (Faculty of History)<br />
Dr Michael Bravo&nbsp; (Department of Geography)<br />
Dr Rohan Deb Roy&nbsp; (Max Planck Institute for the History of Science)<br />
Dr Johanna Gon&ccedil;alves Mart&iacute;n (Max Planck Institute for the History of Science)<br />
Dr Jagjeet Lally (University College London)<br />
Dr Leon Rocha&nbsp; (University of Liverpool)<br />
Dr Sujit Sivasundaram&nbsp; (Faculty of History)<br />
<br />
&nbsp;</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">

						<img src="/static/svg/crassh_logo.svg" alt="">
						<h1>CRASSH</h1>

			<div class="row">
				<div class="span12">
					<div class="row mb10">
						<div class="span12">
							<h1>Humanitas Visiting Professorships</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							
							 
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">

            <li class="facebook">

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">2015-16</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >2014-15</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >2013-14 </a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="4" >2012-13</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="5" >2011-12</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="6" >2010-11</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">2015-16</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;">Humanitas is a series of Visiting Professorships at Oxford and Cambridge designed to bring leading academics, practitioners and scholars to both universities to address major themes in the arts, social sciences and humanities. Created by the late Lord Weidenfeld,&nbsp;the Programme is managed and funded by the Weidenfeld-Hoffmann Trust with the support of a series of generous benefactors, and administered by TORCH in Oxford and the Centre for Research in the Arts, Social Sciences and Humanities (CRASSH) in Cambridge. For further details about Humanitas and the Weidenfeld-Hoffmann Trust, visit <a href="http://whtrust.org/humanitas/">www.whtrust.org/humanitas</a>.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;<img alt="" src="/assets/general/uchidaweb.jpg" style="width: 140px; height: 140px;" />&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;<img alt="" src="/assets/general/Ahtisaariweb.jpg" style="width: 140px; height: 140px;" />&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;<img alt="" src="/assets/general/Emily_Bell_web.jpg" style="width: 140px; height: 140px;" /></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Chamber Music</strong>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <strong>Statecraft &amp; Diplomacy</strong>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<strong>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Media</strong><br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/mitsuko-uchida">Mitsuko Uchida&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</a>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/martti-ahtisaari">Martti Ahtisaari&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</a>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/emily-bell">Emily Bell</a></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;<img alt="" height="163" src="/assets/general/FerraroRev.jpg" width="137" />&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp; <img alt="" height="156" src="/assets/general/Pijbesweb.jpg" width="156" /></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Sustainability Studies</strong>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<strong> History of Art</strong><br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/paul-ferraro">Paul Ferraro</a>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/wim-pijbes">Wim Pijbes</a></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">2014-15</h3>
										<p>Humanitas is a series of Visiting Professorships at Oxford and Cambridge designed to bring leading academics, practitioners and scholars to both universities to address major themes in the arts, social sciences and humanities. Created by Lord Weidenfeld,&nbsp;the Programme is managed by the Weidenfeld Hoffmann Trust with the support of generous benefactors, and co-ordinated in Cambridge by the Centre for Research in the Arts, Social Sciences and Humanities (CRASSH).</p>

<table align="left" border="0" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="1" style="width: 500px;">
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td>
			<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/murray-perahia"><img alt="" src="/assets/general/Murray-Perahia-square.jpg" style="width: 150px; height: 150px;" /></a><br />
			<strong>Chamber Music</strong><br />
			Murray Perahia</p>
			</td>
			<td><strong><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/xu-bing"><img alt="" src="/assets/general/xubing1-square.jpg" style="width: 150px; height: 150px;" /></a><br />
			Chinese Studies</strong><br />
			Xu Bing</td>
			<td><strong><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/richard-haass"><img alt="" src="/assets/general/Haass-Square.jpg" style="width: 150px; height: 150px;" /></a><br />

			Richard Haass</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td>
			<p><strong><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/johan-rockstroem"><img alt="" src="/assets/general/Rockstrom-square.jpg" style="width: 150px; height: 150px;" /></a></strong><br />
			<strong style="line-height: 1.6em;">Sustainability Studies</strong><br />
			<span style="line-height: 1.6em;">Johan Rockstr&ouml;m</span></p>
			</td>
			<td><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/sir-john-tomlinson"><img alt="" src="/assets/general/Tomlinson-square.jpg" style="width: 150px; height: 150px;" /></a><br />
			<b>V</b><b style="line-height: 1.6em;">ocal Studies</b><br />
			Sir John Tomlinson</td>
			<td>
			<p><strong style="line-height: 1.6em;"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/natasha-walter"><img alt="" src="/assets/general/Natasha-Walter-square.jpg" style="width: 150px; height: 150px;" /></a><br />
			Women&#39;s Rights</strong><br />
			<span style="line-height: 1.6em;">Natasha Walter</span></p>
			</td>

Created by Lord Weidenfeld,&nbsp;the Programme is managed by the Weidenfeld Hoffmann Trust with the support of generous benefactors, and co-ordinated in Cambridge by the Centre for Research in the Arts, Social Sciences and Humanities (CRASSH)</p>

							<h1>International Visiting Fellowships</h1>
						</div>

							<h4 class="date">Open to scholars from outside Cambridge</h4>

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Fellowships</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Fellows 2017-18</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="4" >Work in Progress Seminars</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="5" >Past Fellows</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;">CRASSH Visiting Fellowships are designed to support the Centre&#39;s research interests, projects,&nbsp; and activities. Depending on the Fellowship, Fellows are usually given desk space&nbsp; in the Centre and, where appropriate, funding towards travel, as well as certain practical assistance in their research. CRASSH can help in arranging accommodation with a College, and enable access to the University Library and other departmental libraries.&nbsp; CRASSH may also support visitors who come to Cambridge for a period of days or weeks in order to participate in a particular activity organised by the Centre. For information about the different fellowship opportunities please click on the Fellowships tab on this page. Click <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/applications/">here</a> to view current fellowship opportunities at CRASSH and apply online.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">As well as our established fellowship opportunities, we welcome applications from scholars who already have their own funding in place, and who wish to come to CRASSH for a term or longer. To find out more information please email <a href="mailto:fellowships@crassh.cam.ac.uk">fellowships@crassh.cam.ac.uk</a>. We will&nbsp; require a recent CV and a research proposal to be considered by the Visiting Fellowships Committee.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Fellowships</h3>
										<p style="text-align:justify"><br />
<a href="http://www.2018-2019.eurias-fp.eu/"><strong>CRASSH/Clare Hall/Eurias Fellowship </strong></a>(10 months)<br />
The European Institutes for Advanced Study (EURIAS) Fellowship Programme is an international researcher mobility programme offering 10-month residencies in one of the 19 participating Institutes: Berlin, Bologna, Brussels, Budapest, Cambridge, Delmenhorst, Freiburg, Edinburgh, Freiburg, Helsinki, Jerusalem, Lyon, Madrid, Marseille, Paris, Uppsala, Vienna, Warsaw, Z&uuml;rich. The Institutes for Advanced Study support the focused, self-directed work of outstanding researchers. The fellows benefit from the finest intellectual and research conditions and from the stimulating environment of a multi-disciplinary and international community of first-rate scholars. For information about the previous Fellows and related events please click <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/eurias-fellowship">here.</a> <strong> The competition for 2018-19&nbsp; is now closed.&nbsp; </strong></p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><a href="http://www.wallace-trusts.org.uk/cwt_india.html">The Charles Wallace India Trust </a>(one term)<br />
The Charles Wallace India Trust fellowship at CRASSH offers funding for a term of study and residence in Cambridge during the academic year.&nbsp; The scheme is intended for earlier-career academics from India (defined as resident and domiciled in India, normally between the ages of 25 and 45 years). Applicants should have been in full-time academic employment in an Indian university or research institute of equivalent standing for at least five years and have completed a PhD. For further information about the Fellowship and Fellows please click <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/charles-wallace-india-trust-fellowship">here</a>. <strong>The competition to select a Fellow for 2018-19 has now closed. </strong></p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/balzan-skinner-fellowship">Quentin Skinner Fellowship (previously known as the Balzan-Skinner Fellowship</a>) (one term)<br />
In 2009 the Faculty of History&nbsp; received funding&nbsp; from the International Balzan Prize Foundation to establish an annual Lecture in modern intellectual history since c. 1500. Since then there have been six Balzan-Skinner Fellows at CRASSH. In 2015-16 this Fellowship came to an end and is now known as the Quentin-Skinner Fellowship&nbsp;in Intellectual History since c15.00. The appointed Fellow holds a fellowship at CRASSH for one term, presenting the Quentin-Skinner lecture and participating in the related symposium. For information about the Quentin Skinner Fellowship and previous Balzan-Skinner Fellows please click <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/balzan-skinner-fellowship">here</a>. The Quentin Skinner Fellowship&nbsp; is intended for early career scholars (normally defined as within ten years of attaining the PhD). Like&nbsp; previous Balzan-Skinner Fellows, the Quentin Skinner Fellow will be invited to give a lecture on a subject of their choosing in the broad field of intellectual history since 1500, including the history of political thought, and will organise a half-day colloquium to follow the lecture. <strong>The competition for 2018-19 is now closed. </strong></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Fellows 2017-18</h3>
										<p><strong>Charles Wallace India Trust</strong> <strong>Fellow</strong><br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/ananay-vajpeyi">Dr Ananya Vajpeyi </a>(Centre of Study for Developing Science, Delhi)<br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27350">A Biography of Sanskrit</a></p>

<p><strong>Conversion in the Early Modern Period</strong> <strong>Fellows</strong><br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/miriana-carbonara">Dr Miriana Carbonara</a> (University of East Anglia)<br />
On borders and conversion: Representing, crossing and experiencing the frontier between Bologna and Modena in the early modern period</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/charlotte-rose-millar">Dr Charlotte-Rose Millar </a>(University of Queensland)<br />
Ghost Stories in post-Reformation England</p>

<p><strong>Quentin Skinner Fellow</strong><br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/avi-lifschitz">Dr Avi Lifschitz</a> (UCL)<br />
Philosophy and Political Agency in the Writings of Frederick II of Prussia.</p>

<p><strong>CRASSH/Clare Hall/Eurias Fellow</strong><br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/marie-louise-herzfeld-schild">Dr Marie Louise Herzfeld-Schild</a> (University of Cologne)<br />
The Emotional Effects of Music between Medicine and Aesthetics (1740-1880)</p>

<p><strong>Nine Dots Prize Fellow</strong><br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/james-williams">James Williams</a> (University of Oxford)</p>

<p><strong>IE University Madrid</strong>&nbsp;<strong> Fellows</strong><br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/david-moshfegh">Dr David Moshfegh</a><br />
Ignaz Goldziher and the Rise of Islamwissenschaft as a &lsquo;Science of Religion<br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/marco-caserta">Dr Marco Caserta</a><br />
Learning from Data</p>

<p><strong>ACLS&nbsp; Fellow</strong><br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/christopher-nygren">Dr Christopher Nygren</a> (University of Pittsburgh)<br />
Matter and Similitude in Italian Painting and The Transatlantic Renaissance</p>

<p><strong>CRASSH/Briitsh School in Rome Fellow </strong><br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/helena-pillips-robins">Helena Phillips-Robins</a> (University of Cambridge)<br />
The use of tears in thirteenth and fourteenth-century Italian poetry.</p>

								<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/legal/rss-feeds/">RSS Feeds</a>
							</li>

		</footer>
	</div>

							<h1>Limits of the Numerical</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							
							 
						</div>

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >People</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Events</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p><strong>An ISRF-funded research project</strong><br />
2015&ndash;2018<br />
CRASSH, University of Cambridge</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">This project explores one of the most pressing sets of questions for modern social science and its relation to policy. What are the effects on a system of social policy when numerical quantification and evaluation is introduced into that system? How does the use of numerical evaluation exclude, trivialize or distort other systems of political, moral and social evaluation? What are the political and moral consequences of this shift towards numerical evaluation? These questions are addressed with respect to three distinct strands of social policy &mdash; education, climate change and healthcare &mdash; three areas where social science, policy and the gritty world of politics interact with intense urgency.&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">International and interdisciplinary in its conception, each strand of the research will be conducted by a team from a different major research university &mdash; Chicago, Cambridge, Santa Barbara California. The Cambridge project will focus on healthcare, looking at the role of numerical quantification in the British National Health Service (NHS). In healthcare the UK has led the world in basing the allocation of scarce resources on quantitative economic models. From its inception, the National Institute of Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) has assessed novel interventions in terms of Quality-Adjusted-Life-Years (QALYs). QALYs are now the prime means of evaluating decisions about resource allocation, yet there is no scholarly history of their introduction, nor any detailed account of their effects on the processes of healthcare. How did the dominance of QALYs come about? What effect does the use of QALYs have on the behaviour of actors within the hospital system? Furthermore, what are the philosophical underpinnings, implications&nbsp;and limitations of the use of QALYs as a method of evaluation? This strand of the project will address these questions using a unique range of interdisciplinary approaches in order to produce a fully articulated account of both the historical and anthropological details and the wider social policy implications of numerical quantification within the NHS.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong><a href="/assets/general/Limits_of_the_Numerical_Project_Description.pdf">Project Description</a></strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">The Limits of the Numerical project is funded jointly by the <a href="http://isrf.org/">ISRF </a>and the <a href="http://www.newtontrust.cam.ac.uk/">Isaac Newton Trust</a>.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><img alt="" height="64" src="/assets/general/ISRF_logo.jpg" width="332" /></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">People</h3>
										<p><strong>Research Team in Cambridge </strong>(Healthcare)</p>

<p><a href="http://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/people/john.html">Dr Stephen John</a> (HPS, University of Cambridge)<br />
<a href="http://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/people/alexandrova/">Dr Anna Alexandrova</a> (HPS, University of Cambridge)</p>

<p><strong>Research Associates in Cambridge</strong><br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/gabriele-badano">Dr Gabriele Badano</a><br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/trenholme-junghans">Dr Trenholme Junghans</a></p>

<p><strong>Advisory Board in Cambridge</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.geog.cam.ac.uk/people/amin/">Professor Ash Amin</a> (Geography, University of Cambridge)<br />
<a href="/people/profile/simon-goldhill">Professor Simon Goldhill</a> (CRASSH/Classics, University of Cambridge)<br />
<a href="http://www.econ.cam.ac.uk/people/crsid.html?crsid=tl27&amp;group=faculty">Dr Tony Lawson</a> (Economics, University of&nbsp;Cambridge)<br />
<a href="http://prce.hu/w/index.html">Professor Huw Price</a> (Philosophy, University of Cambridge)</p>

<p><strong>University of California, Santa Barbara</strong> (Education)<br />
<a href="https://www.english.ucsb.edu/people/newfield-christopher">Professor Chris Newfield</a> (Department of English, UCSB)<br />
<a href="https://www.english.ucsb.edu/people/ghosh-bishnupriya">Professor Bishnupriya Ghosh</a> (Department of English, UCSB)</p>

<p><strong>University of Chicago</strong><a href="http://english.uchicago.edu/faculty/chandler"> </a>(Climate Change)<br />
<a href="http://english.uchicago.edu/faculty/chandler">Professor James Chandler </a>(Department of English, Chicago)</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Events</h3>
										<p>14 December 2015 - Limits of the Numerical in Climate Change, Health Care and Higher Education Policy<br />
A one day closed workshop to discuss and debate the issues to be focused on in the three strands of this project.</p>

<p>21-22 July 2016 -&nbsp; <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26814">The Uses and Abuses of Quantification in Healthcare: interdisciplinary perspectives</a></p>

<p>A two day conference discussing how particular measures and models of evidence currently prevalent in healthcare have developed and&nbsp; what the practical effects of the use of such measures and models are, and what philosophical issues&nbsp; they raise.</p>

<p>16 December 2016 - Evidence under Challenge<br />
A one day closed workshop engaging new directions in healthcare policy and regulation.</p>

<p>21 October 2017<br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27410">Who to Trust about your Health?</a></p>
									</div>

						<div class="span12">
							<h1>Making Visible: The visual and graphic practices of the early Royal Society</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >People</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p><strong>AHRC-funded research project</strong><br />
2015&ndash;2019<br />
CRASSH, University of Cambridge</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">How and when did science become visual? How did drawings, diagrams and charts come to be used alongside words and objects by a group of people who hoped to reform and establish a new form of knowledge of nature, based on collaboration, experimentation and observation in the second half of the century? Who made those drawings and diagrams, and what made them &lsquo;scientific&rsquo;?&nbsp; The aim of this project is to understand the roles visual resources and practices played in the development and dissemination of scientific knowledge in the first fifty years of the Royal Society. As one of the earliest institutions dedicated to collective investigation of nature, the Royal Society had few precedents to follow, and faced challenges in forming and presenting a new kind of collaborative knowledge to its audience. Many of the publications sponsored by the Royal Society such as Robert Hooke&rsquo;s <em>Micrographia</em> or Francis Willughby&rsquo;s <em>Historia piscium</em>, as well as the institution&rsquo;s journal, &#39;Philosophical Transactions&#39;, contained extensive illustrations. These were important projects, as the Society grappled with various strategies to present a new form of knowledge and establish its own authority in scientific matters. &nbsp;The archives of the Society contain a rich variety of images that has not yet received much attention by historians of science. This project proposes to undertake a systematic investigation into the visual and graphic practices of the Royal Society during its first fifty years, and examine the roles the Society played in the emergence of a scientific visual culture in the early modern period.<br />
<br />
<a href="/assets/general/Making_Visible_Project_Description_Web-2.pdf"><strong>Project Description</strong></a></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">People</h3>
										<p><strong>Research Team</strong></p>

<p>PI: <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/sachiko-kusukawa">Professor Sachiko&nbsp;Kusukawa</a> (HPS, Trinity College Cambridge)<br />
CI: <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/felicity-henderson">Dr Felicity&nbsp;Henderson</a> (English, University of Exeter)<br />
CI: <a href="/people/profile/alexander-marr">Dr Alexander Marr</a> (History of Art, University of&nbsp;Cambridge)<br />
RA: <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/sietske-fransen">Dr Sietske Fransen</a><br />
RA: <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/katherine-reinhart">Dr Katherine Reinhart</a><br />
Administrator:&nbsp;<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/judith-weik" style="line-height: 1.6em;">Judith Weik</a><span style="line-height: 1.6em;">&nbsp;</span></p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong style="line-height: 1.6em;">Advisory Board</strong></p>

<p><a href="/people/profile/simon-goldhill">Professor Simon Goldhill</a> (CRASSH/Classics, University of&nbsp;Cambridge)<br />
<a href="http://www.bbk.ac.uk/about-us/fellows/michael-hunter">Professor Michael Hunter</a> (History, Birkbeck, University of London)<br />
<a href="http://www.mcgill.ca/ahcs/people/faculty/matthew-hunter">Professor Matthew Hunter</a> (Art History, McGill University)<br />
Keith Moore (Royal Society Library)<br />
<a href="http://www.hps.cam.ac.uk/people/schaffer/">Professor Simon Schaffer</a> (HPS, University of Cambridge)<br />
<a href="http://www.britishmuseum.org/about_us/departments/staff/prints_and_drawings/kim_sloan.aspx">Dr Kim Sloan</a> (British Museum) &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong style="line-height: 1.6em;">Project Partner</strong></p>

<p>The Royal Society, London</p>

						<div class="span12">
							<h1>Moral Psychology [2014-2015]</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">From 2014 to 2015</h4>
							 
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Conveners</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Past events</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;">The Cambridge Moral Psychology Research Group brings together researchers from different disciplines&mdash;including neuroscience, psychology, philosophy, law, and others&mdash;who have a common interest in understanding moral behaviour. The aims of the group are to (1) foster inter-disciplinary collaboration, (2) help its members learn about relevant methods used in other fields, and (3) host discussions with leading academics about the key contemporary questions in moral psychology.</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Conveners</h3>
										<p><strong>Conveners</strong></p>

<p><a href="mailto:nch32@cam.ac.uk">Nora Heinzelmann</a> (Department of Philosophy)<br />
<a href="mailto:gabipavarini@gmail.com">Gabriela Pavarini</a><a href="mailto:gp342@cam.ac.uk"> </a>(Department of Psychology)<br />
<a href="mailto:ij234@cam.ac.uk">Isabelle Jefford</a>&nbsp; (Department of Psychology)<br />
<a href="mailto:jdg48@cam.ac.uk">Juliet Griffin</a> (Department of Psychology)</p>

<p><strong>Previous Convener</strong><br />
<a href="mailto:tot20@cam.ac.uk">Tor Tarantola </a>(Department of Psychology)<br />
Dr Philippe Gilchrist (Deptartment of Psychology)</p>

<p><br />
<strong>Faculty Advisors</strong></p>

<p><a href="mailto:rjh221@cam.ac.uk">Prof Richard Holton</a> (Professor of Philosophy, Faculty of Philosophy)<br />
Dr Benedetto De Martino (Sir Henry Dale Senior Research Fellow, Department of Psychology)<br />
<a href="mailto:tjsd3@cam.ac.uk">Dr Tom Dougherty</a> (Lecturer, Faculty of Philosophy)<br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Previous Faculty Advisors</strong><br />
Dr Simone Schnall&nbsp; (Senior Lecturer, Department of Psychology, Cambridge)<br />
&nbsp;</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Past events</h3>
										<p><table class="table table-bordered table-striped table-hover mt20"><thead><tr><th>Moral Psychology</th></tr></thead><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25792">Emotion and Rationality: Moral Decisions</a></strong><br><i>15 October 2014, Room S1, 1st floor Alison Richard Building (NB different date)</i><br><p>Joshua Greene (Harvard), Rae Langton (Cambridge) at Moral Psychology<br />
&nbsp;</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25793">Hedonism and Well-Being</a></strong><br><i>05 November 2014, Room S1, 1st floor Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Roger Crisp (Oxford), Andrew MacLeod (London) at Moral Psychology</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25909">The Choice of Honesty (Heterogeneous Responses)</a></strong><br><i>10 November 2014, Philosophy Faculty, Philosophy Board Room </i><br><p>Alexander Wagner (Zurich) at Moral Psychology<br />
Venue: Fac of Philosophy</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25794">Interdisciplinary Exchange of Ideas</a></strong><br><i>19 November 2014, Room S1, 1st floor Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Limited places. Moral Psychology group</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25795">Self-Control and Weakness of Will</a></strong><br><i>03 December 2014, Room S1, 1st floor Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Todd Hare (Zurich), Lubomira Radoilska (Kent/Cambridge) at Moral Psychology</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25951">Consciousness and Free Choice</a></strong><br><i>19 January 2015, Lecture Theatre, Dept. of Psychology, Downing site</i><br><p>Neil Levy (Oxford/Melbourne), Aaron Schurger (Lausanne) -Moral Psychology</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25952">Interdisciplinary Exchange of Ideas</a></strong><br><i>26 January 2015, Room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Moral Psychology</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25954">Is Empathy Important for Morality?</a></strong><br><i>09 February 2015, Room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Jesse Prinz (CUNY),&nbsp;Molly Crockett (Oxford) -Moral Psychology</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/25955">What is the Nature of Human Morality?</a></strong><br><i>12 March 2015, Room SG1 & SG2,  Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Shaun Nichols (Arizona) -Moral Psychology</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26195">Clues to the Embodied Metaphorical Mind</a></strong><br><i>27 April 2015, Psychology Lecture Theatre, Downing Site</i><br><p>Spike Lee (Toronto)~Moral Psychology</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26114">Moral Challenges of New Reproductive Technologies</a></strong><br><i>21 May 2015, Room SG1, Alison Richard Building.</i><br><p>Eve-Marie Engels (Germany), Martin Richards, Vasanti Jadva (Cambridge) ~ Moral Psychology</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26116">Has the Obsession with Sacrificial Dilemmas Derailed Moral Psychology?</a></strong><br><i>01 June 2015, Room SG1,  Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>David Pizarro (Cornell), Guy Kahane (Oxford), Sophia Connell (Cambridge) ~ Moral Psychology</p></td></tr></table></p>

			<div class="row">
				<div class="span12">
					<div class="row mb10">
						<div class="span12">
							<h1>Nine Dots Prize</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							
							 
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>
            <li class="twitter">
                <a href="https://twitter.com/share?text=Nine Dots Prize&url=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/nine-dots-prize" data-social-text="Share on Twitter">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_twitter.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="facebook">
                <a href="http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/nine-dots-prize" data-social-text="Share on Facebook">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_facebook.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="email">
                <a href="mailto:?subject=Nine Dots Prize&body=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/nine-dots-prize" data-social-text="Share via email">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icon_mailing.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
        </ul>
    </nav>
</div>

						</div>
					</div>
					<hr>
				</div>
			</div>

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About the prize</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >About the Board</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >How to enter</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About the prize</h3>
										<p>The Nine Dots Prize offers&nbsp;US$100,000 and a book deal with Cambridge University Press to whoever can best answer the question &lsquo;<em>Are digital technologies making politics impossible?</em>&rsquo;</p>

<p>The&nbsp;Prize is designed to promote and encourage innovative thinking to address problems facing the modern world.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The Prize will be judged anonymously by a 12-strong Board of internationally recognised and distinguished academics, authors, journalists and thinkers. The Board will be chaired by Professor Simon Goldhill, director of the Centre for Research in the Arts, Social Sciences and Humanities (CRASSH), Professor in Greek Literature and Culture and Fellow of King&#39;s College, Cambridge.</p>

<p>The Prize is open to anyone aged 18 years or over writing in English, and welcomes submissions from both new voices and experienced authors. To enter, people are asked to respond to the set question in 3,000 words and provide an outline structure showing how, if they win, they would develop their argument into a short book. A new question will be set every two years.</p>

<p>The Nine Dots Prize is funded by the Kadas Prize Foundation, an English registered charity established to fund research into significant but neglected questions relevant to today&rsquo;s world.</p>

<p>The deadline for entries has now passed.&nbsp; The winner will be announced in May 2017.</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About the Board</h3>
										<p>The Board will be composed of twelve internationally recognised and distinguished academics, authors, journalists and thinkers. They are:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Professor Diane Coyle &ndash; Professor of Economics at Manchester University, former Vice Chair of the BBC Trust and Economics Editor of the Independent</li>
	<li>Professor Paul Gilroy &ndash; currently Professor of English at Kings College London, previously Giddens Professor of Social Theory at the London School of Economics</li>
	<li>Professor Simon Goldhill (Chair) &ndash; Director of the Centre for Research in the Arts, Social Sciences and Humanities (CRASSH), Professor in Greek Literature and Culture and Fellow of King&#39;s College, Cambridge</li>
	<li>E.J. Graff &ndash; Senior Fellow at the Schuster Institute for Investigative Journalism at Brandeis University and Managing Editor of the Washington Post&rsquo;s Monkey Cage blog</li>
	<li>Professor Alcinda Honwana &ndash; visiting Professor of Anthropology and International Development at the Open University and formerly was a program officer at the United Nations Office of the Special Representative for Children and Armed Conflict</li>
	<li>Peter Kadas &ndash; Director of the Kadas Prize Foundation</li>
	<li>Professor Ira Katznelson &ndash; President of the Social Science Research Council and former President of the American Political Science Association</li>
	<li>Professor Roger Martin &ndash; Institute Director of the Martin Prosperity Institute and the Michael Lee-Chin Family Institute for Corporate Citizenship at the Rotman School of Management and the Premier&rsquo;s Chair in Productivity &amp; Competitiveness</li>
	<li>Professor Riccardo Rebonato &ndash; Professor of Finance at EDHEC Business School, formerly Global Head of Rates and FX Research at PIMCO</li>
	<li>Professor David Runciman &ndash; Professor of Politics and Head of the Department of Politics and International Studies at the University of Cambridge</li>
	<li>Professor Saskia Sassen &ndash; Robert S. Lynd Professor of Sociology and Co-Chair of the Committee on Global Thought at Columbia University</li>
</ul>

<p>One additional Board member will be announced in due course</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">How to enter</h3>
										<p>Entrants to the Nine Dots Prize will be asked to submit an application in three parts:</p>

<ol>
	<li>A summary response to the question. This response can be up to 3,000 words in length and will form the basis of the short book (of between 25,000 and 40,000 words) that the winner will produce. The summary should cover the main arguments the proposed book will make, the previous research or ideas on which it draws and the key conclusions it will reach.</li>
	<li>An outline structure of this short book, including provisional chapter headings.</li>
	<li>A justification of their ability to complete the book in the time given (approx. nine months). This will outline the entrant&rsquo;s previous experience in communicating effectively about research and ideas, and a commitment from them that their responsibilities will allow the book to be completed in the nine month period. Where applicable this should include confirmation of support from the entrant&rsquo;s institution(s) or employer(s) that sabbatical time has been approved.</li>
</ol>

<p>Full submissions guidance and terms and conditions are available from <a href="http://www.ninedotsprize.org">www.ninedotsprize.org</a></p>
									</div>
								</div>
							</div>
						</article>
					</div>
				</div>

				<div class="span4">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<div class="span4">

						<div class="span12">
							<h1>Open Intellectual Property Models of Emerging Technologies</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">Alternate Wednesdays, 12.00-14.00 during term-time</h4>
							
							<p class="meta">
								<span class="location">Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building</span>
							</p>
							
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Convenors </a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Programme 2017-18</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Open Intellectual Property Models of Emerging Technologies and Implications for the Equitable Society</strong><br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">The guiding question of our research group will be the extent to which open technologies result in equitable sharing of knowledge and cognitive or technology justice. &#39;Open&#39; IP describes a range of approaches to knowledge production, distribution and consumption that allow more or different actors to participate in producing and benefit from technologies. The global shift to knowledge-based economies and increasingly rapid pace of technological advancement means that the question of how society deals with intellectual property (IP) and structures institutions and communities to manage and disseminate knowledge is critically important to our future. Our choices will reflect and shape our societal values, practices and culture. Advocates of open and collaborative approaches point to evidence of real social impact from but there is little published evidence and any effects are heavily context dependent.&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><br />
We are interested in emerging technologies such as synthetic biology, artificial intelligence and electric cars; new networked infrastructure such as distributed energy and new forms of manufacturing such as 3D-printing. Examples of open technologies are found within each of these sectors, situated along a spectrum from fully public domain to forming part of a managed commons. Our research group has a range of interests from biotechnologies and diagnostics; &#39;green&#39; technology and sustainability transitions; governance of risk through to knowledge and technology transfer for international development. We will explore together the legal issues, economic implications and governance of open technologies across key sectors, asking how they are established, what motivates the IP owners and ultimately what impact this might have on societies. This will enable us to push the boundaries of our current knowledge and understanding, cross-fertilising between our respective fields and creating new interdisciplinary insights and novel research ideas.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Administrative assistance:&nbsp;<a href="mailto:gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk">gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk</a></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Convenors </h3>
										<p><strong>Convenors</strong></p>

<p><a href="mailto:jcm80@cam.ac.uk">Jenny Molloy</a> (Coordinator, Synthetic Biology SRI and OpenPlant, Department of Plant Sciences)<br />
<a href="mailto:ft263@eng.cam.ac.uk">Frank Tietze</a>&nbsp; (University Lecturer in Technology &amp; Innovation Management, Institute for Manufacturing, Centre for Technology Management, Department of Engineering)<br />
<a href="mailto:lbj20@cam.ac.uk">Laura James</a>&nbsp; (IdeaSpace and Institute for Manufacturing)<br />
<a href="mailto:jel68@cam.ac.uk ">John Liddicoat</a>&nbsp; (Research Associate, Centre for Law, Medicine and Life Sciences, Faculty of Law)<br />
<a href="mailto:cr573@cam.ac.uk">Catherine Rhodes</a>&nbsp; (Academic Project Manager, Centre for the Study of Existential Risk, CRASSH)<br />
<a href="mailto:ls299@cam.ac.uk">Lalitha Sundaram</a>&nbsp; (Research Associate, Centre for the Study of Existential Risk, Centre for the Study of Existential Risk, CRASSH)<br />
<a href="mailto:lara.allen@centreforglobalequality.org">Lara Allen</a> (Director, Global Challenges SRI; CEO, Centre for Global Equality)<br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p><br />
<strong>Faculty Advisors</strong></p>

<p>Professor Jim Haseloff&nbsp; (Professor of Synthetic Biology, Plant Sciences)<br />
Dr Rob Doubleday&nbsp; (Centre for Science and Policy)</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Programme 2017-18</h3>
										<p><table class="table table-bordered table-striped table-hover mt20"><thead><tr><th>Open Intellectual Property</th></tr></thead><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27427">How Open is Open Intellectual Property?</a></strong><br><i>18 October 2017, Seminar Room SG2,</i><br><p>Reading session - 			<div class="row">
				<div class="span12">
					<div class="row mb10">
						<div class="span12">
							<h1>Cambridge Interdisciplinary Performance Network (CIPN)</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">Alternate Tuesdays, 17:00-19:00pm during term-time</h4>
							
							<p class="meta">
								<span class="location">Seminar room SG1, Alison Richard Building</span>
							</p>
							
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>
            <li class="twitter">
                <a href="https://twitter.com/share?text=Cambridge Interdisciplinary Performance Network (CIPN)&url=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/performance-network" data-social-text="Share on Twitter">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_twitter.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="facebook">

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Convenors</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Programme 2017-18</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="4" >Past events</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="5" >Past Conferences</a></li>
