								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p><strong>Beyond Boundaries: Thinking as/through Performance</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Interest in Performance reflects a movement away from&nbsp;thinking in terms of immutable objects and singular subjects. It focuses attention instead on collective contexts. It offers an umbrella approach with which to interrogate a given phenomenon (both individual and collective). Thinking as/through Performance proposes a different way to mean &ndash; a &#39;kind of thinking in its own right&#39; (Cull/Minors 2012) &ndash; which performances, theatricality, theatre, and the arts in practice can also model.&nbsp;</p>

<p>A few questions that frame our thinking are:</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">What does it mean to frame, stage, display or enact? In what sense might all forms of self-consciously public statements &ndash; art, politics, academic discourse &ndash; be seen as performance?<br />
How is our post-print digital era, with its forces of equivalence and convergence, prompting reconsideration of traditional categories and boundaries &ndash; i.e. of the disciplinary itself?<br />
How do we understand objects (fixed, a record) when they cannot exist separately from their experience on the part of somebody or other (time-bound, embodied)?<br />
How do we understand the subject when it depends on imagined and actual collectivities to position itself?</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Each session is flexibly organised around two short presentations from different disciplinary backgrounds, followed by extended discussion. We also regularly host workshops, performances and panel discussions in collaboration with creative practitioners. CIPN aims to provide a platform for discursive encounters that foster greater dialogue between the academy and creative practice more generally.&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">After a first introductory year (2013-14), the Cambridge Interdisciplinary Performance Network (CIPN) has programmed seminars with a slight emphasis on current debates in Anthropology (2014-15), Art History (2015-16), English (2016-17). This year we turn to Theology and Philosophy to explore questions surrounding the nature of being and the complex interrelationship between the material and immaterial, and how these relationships are enacted daily in the performance of place, through the roles of ritual and tradition, and by the affective powers of music, art and memory.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Please feel free to get in touch with the seminar convenors:<span style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><a href="mailto:rb761@cam.ac.uk" style="text-align: justify;">Rozelle Bosch</a><span style="text-align: justify;">, </span><a href="mailto:rls56@cam.ac.uk" style="text-align: justify;">Rachel Stroud</a><span style="text-align: justify;"> or&nbsp; </span><a href="mailto:clef3@cam.ac.uk" style="text-align: justify;">Clare Foster</a><span style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</span><span style="text-align: justify;"> for further information.<br />
To sign up to receive information about events relating to the concept of performance at</span><br />
<a href="mailto:Ucam-performance-network@lists.cam.ac.uk">Ucam-performance-network@lists.cam.ac.uk</a><br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p>Administrative assistance: <a href="mailto:gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk">gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk</a></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Convenors</h3>
										<p><strong>Convenors</strong><br />
<br />
<a href="mailto:rb761@cam.ac.uk">Rozelle Bosch</a> (Philosophical Theology, Faculty of Divinity)<br />
<a href="mailto:rls56@cam.ac.uk">Rachel Stroud&nbsp;</a> (Faculty of Music)<br />
<a href="mailto:clef3@cam.ac.uk">Dr Clare Foster</a> &nbsp;(Faculty of Classics/ English/Creative Writing)&nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Previous Convenors</strong></p>

<p><a href="mailto:yyy23@cam.ac.uk">Yesim Yaprak Yildiz </a>(Departmemnt of Sociology)<br />
Neylan Bagcioglu (History of Art)<br />
<a href="mailto:ggb24@cam.ac.uk&gt;">Jack Belloli</a> (Faculty of English)<br />
<a href="mailto:mjb255@cam.ac.uk">Michael Byrne </a>(CMPCP, Dance)<br />
<a href="mailto:clef3@cam.ac.uk">Dr Clare Foster</a> &nbsp;(Faculty of Classics/ English/Creative Writing) &nbsp;<br />
<a href="mailto:jlt46@cam.ac.uk">Dr Jonas Tinius</a> (Division of Social Anthropology)<br />
<a href="mailto:ru210@cam.ac.uk">Rin Ushiyama </a>(Department of Sociology)</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>-</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><img alt="" src="/assets/general/Clare_Foster.jpg" style="height: 99px; width: 77px; margin: 10px; float: left;" /><strong>Clare Foster</strong> (Creative Writing, Classics) was a screenwriter based in Los Angeles from 1990-2008, before returning to England to take the MA in Classical Reception Studies at UCL. She just completed an AHRC-funded Phd at Cambridge about Greek drama, theatre history, and the performance of tradition. She is now a British Academy Post-Doctoral Fellow at UCL (2015-18), looking at the history of current attitudes to &lsquo;adaptation&rsquo;.<br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><img alt="" src="/assets/general/Jonas_Tinius.jpeg" style="width: 77px; height: 99px; margin: 10px; float: left;" /></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Jonas Tinius</strong> (Division of Social Anthropology) is a PhD candidate working on contemporary artistic institutions in Germany with a focus on public theatres. He is editor of Anthropology, Theatre, and Performance: The Transformative Potential of Performance (with Alex Flynn, Palgrave 2015).&nbsp;<br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><img alt="" src="/assets/general/Michael_Byrne.jpg" style="width: 77px; height: 99px; margin: 10px; float: left;" /></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><br />
<strong>Michael Byrne</strong> (CMPCP, Faculty of Music) is a PhD candidate exploring creativity and ageing in the narrative works of The Royal Ballet. Using the reconstruction of Helpmann&#39;s Miracle in the Gorbals as a central case study, his research analyses the embodied histories of senior dancers and the intergenerational transmission of knowledge in performance.&nbsp;<br />
<br />
<img alt="" src="/assets/general/Neylan_Bagcioglu.png" style="width: 77px; height: 99px; margin: 10px; float: left;" /><br />
<strong>Neylan Bagcioglu</strong> (History of Art) is a PhD candidate working on radical and collaborative art practices in Britain during the 1970s, with a special focus on the politics of the artist project. She has been published in the Turkish newspapers H&uuml;rriyet and Radikal as an art critic, and has worked for organisations including Istanbul Foundation for Culture and Arts (IKSV), Istanbul Modern Museum and Apple Inc.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong><img alt="" src="/assets/general/Rachel_Stroud.jpg" style="width: 77px; height: 99px; margin: 10px; float: left;" />Rachel Stroud </strong>(Faculty of Music) is a PhD candidate working on notation and performance in Beethoven&#39;s late string quartets, conceiving of the notation not as a codification of the composer&#39;s intentions, but as a social artefact. Other research interests include issues of sociality in ensemble playing, such as performing without a conductor. Rachel is also a professional baroque violinist and has performed all over the world in countries ranging from Latvia to Argentina, specialising in particular in the performance of early-nineteenth century repertoire on historical instruments.&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong><img alt="" src="/assets/general/Rin_Ushiyama.jpg" style="width: 77px; height: 99px; margin: 10px; float: left;" />Rin Ushiyama</strong> (Department of Sociology) is a PhD candidate&nbsp;working on cultural sociology,&nbsp;collective memory and social performance, with a specific focus on contemporary Japan. His dissertation examines how the Aum Affair, a series of crimes and terrorist attacks committed by the religious movement Aum Shinrikyo in the early 1990s, has been remembered and commemorated.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><img alt="" src="/assets/general/Jack_Belloli.JPG" style="width: 77px; height: 99px; margin: 10px; float: left;" /><br />
<strong>Jack Belloli</strong> (English) is a PhD candidate looking at the relationship between philosophical constructions of skill and experimental theatre practice since Beckett. He also co-convenes the AHRC-funded Materials in Practice reading group, and has wider research interests in how theories of practice and self-fashioning might inform contemporary Anglophone writing in less apparently &ldquo;performative&rdquo; genres.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>&nbsp;<img alt="" src="/assets/general/Rozelle_Bosch.jpg" style="width: 77px; height: 99px; margin: 10px; float: left;" /></strong><strong>Rozelle Bosch</strong> is a PhD candidate at the Faculty of Divinity who is working on an ontology of the flesh. An investigation which seeks to understand how Dante&#39;s Divine Comedy and Catherine of Siena&#39;s writings are central to what she calls "incarnational performances". Her research interests range from topics relating to gender theory, everyday performances wherein gesture, sign and symbols are instrumental and the question as to how everyday existence can be "incarnational".<br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><img alt="" src="/assets/general/yyaprak.jpg" style="width: 77px; height: 99px; margin: 10px; float: left;" /><strong>Yesim Yaprak Yildiz</strong> is a PhD candidate in the Department of Sociology working on public confessions of state officials on past atrocities with a focus on Turkey. As part of her research, she is looking into performance and performativity in public confessions. Her research interests include transitional justice, political violence, human rights and politics of memory.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">---</p>

Registration required- CIPN</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26966">Shakespeare: Translating, Adapting, Inhabiting</a></strong><br><i>10 October 2016, Seminar Room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Simon Palfrey (Oxford), Enza De Francisci (UCL)- at Performance Network (CIPN)</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26967">Performance and Wellbeing</a></strong><br><i>24 October 2016, Seminar Room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Amanda Kelleher (Professional Clown), Jane Rich (Cambridge Community Arts), John Harper (Founder of Rize)&ndash; at Performance Network (CIPN)</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26968">Performing Cities</a></strong><br><i>07 November 2016, Seminar Room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Lizzie Richardson (Durham), Michael Hrebeniak (Cambridge)- at Performance Network (CIPN)</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26969">Landscape, Dwelling and Site-Specific Practice</a></strong><br><i>21 November 2016, Seminar Room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Stephen Bottoms (Manchester), Yvonne Salmon (Cambridge) - Joint event Performance Network (CIPN) and Alchemical Landscape</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27063">Identities in Popular Performance</a></strong><br><i>23 January 2017, Seminar room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Ross Cole (Cambridge), Broderick Chow (Brunel, London)- at Performance Network (CIPN)<br />

			<div class="row">
				<div class="span12">
					<div class="row mb10">
						<div class="span12">
							<h1>Photography between Invisibility and the Unseen [2016-17]</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">Alternate Wednesdays, 14.30-16.30 during term time</h4>
							
							<p class="meta">
								<span class="location">Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building</span>
							</p>
							
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>
            <li class="twitter">
                <a href="https://twitter.com/share?text=Photography between Invisibility and the Unseen [2016-17]&url=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/photography-between-invisibility-and-the-unseen" data-social-text="Share on Twitter">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_twitter.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="facebook">
                <a href="http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/photography-between-invisibility-and-the-unseen" data-social-text="Share on Facebook">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_facebook.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="email">
                <a href="mailto:?subject=Photography between Invisibility and the Unseen [2016-17]&body=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/photography-between-invisibility-and-the-unseen" data-social-text="Share via email">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icon_mailing.svg">

    </nav>
</div>

						</div>
					</div>
					<hr>
				</div>
			</div>

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Convenors</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Programme 2016-17</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;">The promise of mechanical and digital visual technologies is often assumed to originate in their ability to render the invisible visible, hence contributing to the wider de-mystification constitutive of modernity. This Seminar will approach a key technology in this respect, photography, from an angle that seeks to explore the extent to which it (and by extension other similar technologies) is also involved in a far more nuanced and complex epistemological and ontological operation of transforming the invisible into the "unseen", in the sense of deepened marking of human consciousness by the felt consequential and unsettling presence of something out of view. Recent literature on photographic techniques and practices, ranging from visual studies, history, anthropology, and science and technology studies have illuminated ways in which the symbolic and epistemic efficacy of photography derives not simply from its power of revealing what is hidden in the world, but equally from configuring a series of phenomena, events or forms as lying "at the edge of sight" (Smith 2013). Hence, at the same time as it stabilizes vision by showing what was hitherto imperceptible, photography also amplifies the experience of "imperceptibility" itself, by revealing human interaction with the world to be structured around irreducible visual blind spots. The Seminar will bring together scholars from diverse disciplines who are in various ways exploring this dialectic of the simultaneous stabilization of vision and expansion of the unseen, and who are documenting how photography&#39;s generative suspension between invisibility and the unseen shapes different "fields of vision" in the contemporary world. Focused on aesthetic, affective, semantic, evidential, and political aspects of the topic and their entanglements, the Seminar will foster critical, interdisciplinary approaches and dialogue on a key theoretical area of photography studies today.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Administrative assistance: <a href="mailto:gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk">gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk</a></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Convenors</h3>
										<p><strong>Convenors</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/christos-lynteris" target="_self">Dr Christos Lynteris</a> (Senior Research Associate/ ERC Principal Investigator CRASSH)<br />
<a href="mailto:fp12@cam.ac.uk">Professor Francois Penz </a>(Professor of Architecture and the Moving Image, Department of Architecture, and Director of Martin Centre for Architectural and Urban Studies)<br />
<a href="mailto:bp356@cam.ac.uk">Dr Brawnyn Poleykett </a>(Research Associate, CRASSH)<br />
<a href="mailto:rs839@cam.ac.uk">Dr Rupert Stasch</a> (Lecturer, Social Anthopology)</p>

<p><br />
<strong>Faculty Advisors</strong><br />
<br />
Professor Andrew Webber (Professor of Modern German and Comparative Culture, MML)<br />
Professor Nicholas Thomas (Prof of Historical Anthropology/Director, Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology).</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Programme 2016-17</h3>
										<p><table class="table table-bordered table-striped table-hover mt20"><thead><tr><th>Photography between Invisibility and the Unseen</th></tr></thead><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26985">Unlocking Le Corbusier's Photographic Eye</a></strong><br><i>19 October 2016, Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building. NB Different time today</i><br><p>Tim Benton (Open University) -At Photography between Invisibility and the Unseen</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26986">Anthropology, Fieldwork and Photography: "Seeing through" the Collections at...</a></strong><br><i>02 November 2016, Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building.</i><br><p>Anita Herle (Cambridge)- at Photography between Invisibility and the Unseen</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26987">Unseen therefore Untold: Notes from the Architectural Press Archive</a></strong><br><i>09 November 2016, Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building. NB Different date*</i><br><p>Marco Iuliano (Liverpool)- at Photography between Invisibility and the Unseen</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26988">Intimacy and the Participatory 'Plongée': Henri Gaden, West Africa, 1894-1939</a></strong><br><i>16 November 2016, Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Roy Dilley (St Andrews)- at Photography between Invisibility and the Unseen</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26989">Photographs, Monuments and Making of 'Public Histories': Britain, 1850-1930</a></strong><br><i>30 November 2016, Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Elizabeth Edwards FBA -at Photography between Invisibility and the Unseen</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27090">Portraits, Characters and Persons</a></strong><br><i>18 January 2017, Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building.</i><br><p>Marilyn Strathern (Cambridge)- at Photography between Invisibility and the Unseen</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27092">9% of the Lunar Surface between Visibility and Invisibility, and Stereoscopic Lunar Photography</a></strong><br><i>15 February 2017, Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building.</i><br><p>Carmen P&eacute;rez Gonz&aacute;lez (Bergische Universit&auml;t Wuppertal) -at Photography between Invisibility and the Unseen</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27093">Realisms and Indexicalities of Photographic Propositions</a></strong><br><i>01 March 2017, Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building.</i><br><p>Chris Ball (Notre Dame/CRASSH)-at Photography between Invisibility and the Unseen</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27094">More than Corpses, less than Ghosts. The Hidden and the Invisible in early Ethnographic Photography</a></strong><br><i>15 March 2017, Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Gregory Delaplace (Universit&eacute; Paris Ouest)-at Photography between Invisibility and the Unseen</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27176">CANCELLED The Beastly and the Beautiful: Caging and Camera-Trapping Big Cats in India</a></strong><br><i>10 May 2017, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Nayanika Mathur (Sussex) at Photography between Invisibility and the Unseen.</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27177">The Human Figure in the Photography of Inter-War Modernism</a></strong><br><i>24 May 2017, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building *NB Different Date</i><br><p>Valeria Carullo (Royal Institute of British Architects) at Photography between Invisibility and the Unseen</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27178">From the 'Trust Me' to the 'Show Me' Era</a></strong><br><i>31 May 2017, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Dimitrios Bouras (Photojournalist ) at Photography between Invisibility and the Unseen.</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27179">CANCELLED: The Unseen Epidemic: On Medical Photographs of AIDS</a></strong><br><i>07 June 2017, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Lukas Engelmann (CRASSH) at Photography between Invisibility and the Unseen</p></td></tr></table></p>
									</div>
								</div>
							</div>
						</article>

<head>
	<!-- META DATA -->
	
	<title>Power and Vision: The Camera as Political Technology &ndash; CRASSH</title>
	

	<meta name="description" content="Established at the University of Cambridge in 2001, the Centre for Research in the Arts, Social Sciences and Humanities (CRASSH) works actively with the Schools and Faculties across the University undertaking collaborations that cross faculties and disciplines in order to stimulate fresh thinking and dialogue in and beyond the humanities and social sciences and to reach out to new collaborators and new publics." />
	<meta name="keywords" content="crassh, CRASSH, Centre for Research in the Arts, Social Sciences and Humanities, humanities centre, humanities center, interdisciplinary, interdisciplinarity, conferences, seminars, lectures, research, fellowships, call for papers, early career fellowships, graduate, postdoctoral fellowships, visiting fellowships, risk, conference, modelling futures, challenging models, uncertainty, david spiegelhalter" />

						<div class="span12">
							<h1>Power and Vision: The Camera as Political Technology</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">Alternate Wednesdays, 12:00 - 14:00 during term-time. </h4>
							
							<p class="meta">
								<span class="location">Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building</span>
							</p>
							
						</div>

					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Convenors</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Programme 2017-18</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="4" >Blogs</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;">This interdisciplinary research group seeks to address the disconnect between popular and academic critique of the way contemporary political crisis is covered in mainstream media. We assert that there is a dearth of pragmatic, accessible discussions about how images work, rather than what they purportedly show. As fake news and multimedia increasingly suffuse the visual landscape, it is imperative to initiate an academic and public discussion about how what we see, and the way it is contextualised, underpins popular claims about how contemporary political power operates. We ask: can academics, artists, and visual practitioners help us all better understand how political issues are imagined and imaged? In order to achieve this aim, the group will organise a series of reading groups, seminars, film screenings, master classes, and practice-based events focused on dissecting the camera as a political technology of power.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Michaelmas Term 2017</strong>: <em>The Technological History of Visualising Politics </em></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">The events of this term will focus on how devices of imaging political crisis have given rise to popular interpretations of conflict. We will explore the technological history of the camera, from the genesis of mainstream photojournalism and film in the 19th century to the contemporary widespread usage of drone imaging. There will also be space to discuss how the aesthetics of data, and visualisation of facts, has historically emerged from assumptions about the objective powers of observational technologies.</p>

<p><strong>Lent&nbsp; Term 2018</strong>: <em>Technologies of Seeing Others</em></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">We will focus on how images are used to make claims about difference, both across cultural divides and across the perceived boundary between the human and non-human. The conceptual lynchpin of this term&rsquo;s events will be the technological production of alterity, and how images serve to both underscore and cast into doubt what might otherwise be interpreted as clear-cut boundaries of cultural, political, and racial difference.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Administrative assistance: <a href="mailto:gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk">gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk</a></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Convenors</h3>
										<p><a href="mailto:ncm40@cam.ac.uk">Natalie Camille Morningstar&nbsp;</a> (PhD in Social Anthropology)&nbsp;<br />
<a href="mailto:jaf83@cam.ac.uk">Jessica A. Ferna&#769;ndez de Lara Harada</a>&nbsp; (PhD in Latin American Studies) &nbsp;&nbsp;<br />
<a href="mailto:mm2134@cam.ac.uk">Matthew Mahmoudi&nbsp;</a> (MPhil (incoming PhD) in Development Studies) &nbsp;&nbsp;<br />
<a href="mailto:kam95@cam.ac.uk">Katherine Anne Mato&nbsp;</a> (PhD in Latin American Studies)&nbsp;<br />
<a href="mailto:easmm2@cam.ac.uk ">Engy A. S. M. Moussa</a>&nbsp; (PhD in Politics and International Studies) &nbsp;&nbsp;<br />
<a href="mailto:kjp41@cam.ac.uk ">Karoliina J. Pulkkinen</a> ( PhD in History and Philosophy of Science)&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Faculty Advisors</strong></p>

<p><a href="mailto:dsab2@cam.ac.uk">Dr Duncan Bell</a>&nbsp; (Reader in Political Thought and International Relations, Department of Politics and International Studies)&nbsp;<br />
<a href="mailto:hme25@cam.ac.uk">Professor Harri Englund</a>&nbsp; (Division of Social Anthropology, Director Centre of African Studies, Fellow Churchill College)&nbsp;<br />
<a href="mailto:tf239@cam.ac.uk">Dr Tanya Filer</a> (Research Associate on the Leverhulme-funded Conspiracy and Democracy Project at CRASSH)&nbsp;<br />
<a href="mailto:em310@cam.ac.uk">Dr Ella McPherson</a> (Department of Sociology)<br />
<a href="mailto:es251@cam.ac.uk">Erica Segre</a>&nbsp;&nbsp;(Lecturer in Latin American Studies, Senior Fellow of Trinity College, Associate Teaching Fellow at Newnham College, Centre for Film and Screen, Faculty of Modern and Medieval Languages)<br />
<a href="mailto:gdw27@cam.ac.uk">Dr Graham Denyer Willis</a>&nbsp; (University Lecturer, Centre of Development Studies and Centre of Latin American studies)</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Programme 2017-18</h3>
										<p><table class="table table-bordered table-striped table-hover mt20"><thead><tr><th>Power and Vision</th></tr></thead><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27423">From Analogue to Aerial Surveillance: Reading the History of Political Imaging</a></strong><br><i>11 October 2017, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Reading session&nbsp;- Power and Vision</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27424">Screening of  'Waltz with Bashir' (2008)</a></strong><br><i>25 October 2017, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Ari Folman (Film Director) - Power and Vision</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27425">The Production of Journalism and Fact-Making</a></strong><br><i>08 November 2017, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Alexia Singh (Save the Children,Reuters, Magnum),&nbsp;Eliot Higgins (Bellingcat, Brown Moses Blog)&nbsp;- Power and Vision</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27426">Reconstructing the Effects of a Drone Strike (Screening)</a></strong><br><i>22 November 2017, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Christina Varvia (Forensic Architecture)&nbsp;- Power and Vision</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27568">Reading the Technologies of Seeing Others</a></strong><br><i>24 January 2018, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Paul Halliday (Goldsmiths), M&oacute;nica Moreno Figueroa (Cambridge) - Power and Vision</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27578">Imaging the Politics of the Refugee Crisis</a></strong><br><i>07 February 2018, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Issam Kourbaj (Syrian Artist), Simon Bainbridge (Editor of the British Journal of Photography) - Power and Vision</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27567">Settling in the City: A Workshop on Migration</a></strong><br><i>21 February 2018, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Sam Ivin (Photographer) - Power and Vision.<strong> Limited places. Online Registration.</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27579">Visual Production of Alterity in Urban, Digital and Genetic Spaces</a></strong><br><i>07 March 2018, Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Felipe Hern&aacute;ndez (Cambridge), Paulo Drinot (UCL), Sarah Abel (Iceland) - Power and Vision</p></td></tr></table></p>

	<title>Projects &ndash; CRASSH</title>
	

	<meta name="description" content="Established at the University of Cambridge in 2001, the Centre for Research in the Arts, Social Sciences and Humanities (CRASSH) works actively with the Schools and Faculties across the University undertaking collaborations that cross faculties and disciplines in order to stimulate fresh thinking and dialogue in and beyond the humanities and social sciences and to reach out to new collaborators and new publics." />

			<div class="row">
				<div class="span8">
					<article>

						<p>CRASSH runs a programme of interdisciplinary, collaborative research projects funded by a number of different sponsors.&nbsp; Current projects, hosted or co-hosted by CRASSH, are located in the Alison Richard Building and at other locations nearby on the Sidgwick Site.&nbsp; Regular project meetings are held in CRASSH&#39;s main office in the ARB.&nbsp;</p>

        <ul>
            <li class="twitter">
                <a href="https://twitter.com/share?text=Projects&url=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/projects" data-social-text="Share on Twitter">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_twitter.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="facebook">
                <a href="http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/projects" data-social-text="Share on Facebook">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_facebook.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="email">
                <a href="mailto:?subject=Projects&body=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/projects" data-social-text="Share via email">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icon_mailing.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
        </ul>
    </nav>
</div>
</div>
			</div>
			
			<div class="row">
				<div class="span8">
					<article>

						<p>CRASSH runs a programme of interdisciplinary, collaborative research projects funded by a number of different sponsors.&nbsp; Current projects, hosted or co-hosted by CRASSH, are located in the Alison Richard Building and at other locations nearby on the Sidgwick Site.&nbsp; Regular project meetings are held in CRASSH&#39;s main office in the ARB.&nbsp;</p>

						 <!-- Projects -->

							<li>
								<a href="http://www.chameleonstudios.co.uk/" target="_blank">Web Design by Chameleon</a>

		</footer>
	</div>

							<h1>Religious Diversity and the Secular University</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">2017 - 2021</h4>
							 
						</div>

							<div class="socialShare">

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >People</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Events</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="4" >Reading Group</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;">Andrew W Mellon funded project from April 2017 to March 2021<br />
<br />
One of the most pressing contemporary problems not just for the academic community but also &ndash; and more disturbingly &ndash; for the political order of the world is how to understand and respond to the current toxic combination of religion and politics. It is a fundamental concern on the one hand for the issue of diversity. How should the liberal ideal of a tolerant and mixed society comprehend claims to exclusive and totalizing visions of truth, which set themselves against such liberal ideals? We may recognize that there is now, nationally and globally, a new and complex map, which has more than one monotheism, and polytheism, competing alongside secular standpoints. The challenge, in brief, may be expressed like this: how can we take account of theological difference without going to war for belief? Quite simply, diversity in modern society cannot be adequately broached without an engagement with religion. It is, on the other hand, an equally if differently problematic arena of conflict for universities and other institutions of education. Current attempts at legislation in Britain and elsewhere (e.g. Britain&rsquo;s 2015 &ldquo;Prevent&rdquo; strategy) demonstrate little but bafflement, and consequently a profoundly incoherent response to the vexing issues of how teaching and other university practices should engage with the raft of interests unhelpfully sloganized as fundamentalism. The modern secular university &ndash; itself the result of a long and contested development &ndash; in part because of its very history, has left religion in a systematically awkward and often vexed space on campus, for all participants: teachers, students, administrators. &nbsp;This project aims to approach these problems from a new direction and with new methods of engagement. It will place the dialogic dynamics of religious interaction at the heart of a series of interlinked workshops, summer schools and seminars, to explore how the university can explore the issue of religious diversity in the most sophisticated, historically grounded and productive manner.<br />
<br />
<a href="/assets/general/Project_Summary.pdf">Project Summary</a> (PDF)</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">For further information on the project, please contact the <a href="mailto:sjp229@cam.ac.uk?subject=Religious%20Diversity%20%26%20University%20Responses%20Enquiry">project administrator</a>.</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">People</h3>
										<p><a href="mailto:sdg1001@cam.ac.uk">Professor Simon Goldhill</a><br />
Project Director</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/theodor-dunkelgruen">Dr Theodor Dunkelgr&uuml;n</a><br />
Senior Research Associate and Academic Co-Ordinator</p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/samuel-sami-everett" target="_blank">Dr Samuel Everett</a><br />
Research Associate</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">

						<div class="span12">
							<h1>Seeing Things: Early Modern Visual and Material Culture</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							
							 
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">

					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >People</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;">A collaboration between CRASSH and the Early Modern Studies Institute (EMSI) at the University of Southern California / Huntington Library supported by CRASSH, EMSI, and a Cambridge Humanities Research Grant.<br />
<br />
The past several decades have witnessed an explosion of interest in the study of visual and material culture. Visual studies has challenged existing methodologies and disciplinary structures, while developing new methods to analyse processes of looking and being viewed. Likewise, material-culture studies has placed &lsquo;things&rsquo; centre-stage in subjects from which they were previously absent and fashioned sophisticated means for researching objects in society and culture. The two fields have much in common: capacious interdisciplinarity, the rupturing of the canon, nontraditional objects of study, and a bespoke methodological toolkit. Yet they are rarely brought together in meaningful dialogue, their practitioners remain dispersed, and the benefits of their alignment remain unrealised. Our first intellectual aim is to develop a framework in which to realise this potential.<br />
<br />
Visual and material culture changed rapidly in the early modern period thanks to dramatic social and economic upheaval, radical technological advances, the expansion of global networks of exchange, and significant shifts in philosophical and political thinking. The programme will support advanced research into how, why, and to what effect these changes occurred. By looking back to a period when the assumed categories of modern social order, intellectual disciplines and habits of thought are not yet firmly established, we will be able to see more clearly our contemporary stake in understanding the cultural world through what we see and what we consume.<br />
<br />
<em>Seeing Things</em> will provide an interdisciplinary research environment in which innovative scholarship may be undertaken, in which methodologies will be debated and reconfigured, and in which the parameters of a new, integrated field may be staked out.&nbsp; In particular, it will encourage collaboration between scholars at the participating institutions, visiting fellows, and researchers at different career stages. &nbsp;</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">People</h3>
										<h3>Programme Director</h3>

Sean Nelson</p>

			<div class="row">

					<div class="row mb10">
						<div class="span12">
							<h1>Technology and Democracy (Cambridge Centre for Digital Knowledge)</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">2014 to 2017</h4>
							 
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>
            <li class="twitter">

                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="facebook">

            </li>
            <li class="email">

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >People</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Visiting Fellows</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="4" >Publications</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="5" >Media</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p>The Digital Revolution &mdash; a phenomenon driven by the conjunction of the personal computer, the Internet and the mobile phone &mdash; has now been under way for half a century.&nbsp;In the process it has triggered the most comprehensive transformation of our information environment since Gutenberg&rsquo;s invention of printing by moveable type.&nbsp;It has unleashed a wave of &lsquo;creative destruction&rsquo; through our economies, triggered the emergence and rapid growth of powerful new global corporations, enabled governments and companies to engage in the most intrusive kinds of surveillance and enriched the lives of billions by giving them access to knowledge, communications and&nbsp; networking facilities that were once the exclusive preserve of elites.</p>

<p>Despite all that, it&rsquo;s still early days.&nbsp;The Internet is just over 40 years old, and it didn&rsquo;t become a mainstream communications medium until 1993.&nbsp; So we&rsquo;re about the same distance into the Internet revolution as the citizens of Mainz were in 1477, two decades after Gutenberg launched his revolution. And just as they had no idea of the ways in which that technology would shape the world for the next 400 years, we are likewise largely in the dark about what the digital future holds.</p>

<p>The goal of this philanthropically-supported project&nbsp; &mdash; which is led by John Naughton and David Runciman &mdash; is to explore the implications of digital technology for society.&nbsp; Questions in which we are interested include:</p>

<ul>
	<li>Are we living through a &lsquo;third industrial revolution&rsquo;, akin to the other technology-driven upheavals which have shaped the world in which we live?</li>
	<li>In what ways are digital technologies different from earlier disruptive forces?&nbsp; Are they increasing rather than diminishing inequality?</li>
	<li>Will computing and advanced robotics displace many categories of middle-class employment, as some scholars now predict?&nbsp; If so, how will democracies cope with the ensuing disruption?</li>
	<li>What are the implications for democracy of the pervasive surveillance now practised by governments and corporations?&nbsp; Can privacy &mdash; and personal data &mdash; be protected in such a world?</li>
	<li>Is the pace of technological development now too rapid for society to absorb the disruption that it brings? If so, how could we enhance social adaptability?</li>
	<li>How can the gap between the pace of&nbsp;technical&nbsp;change and that of legislative and regulatory adaptation be closed?</li>
</ul>

<hr />
<p>The <strong>Cambridge Centre for Digital Knowledge (CCDK)</strong> constitutes an ambitious response to the current state of digital knowledge, in a form that enables swift, scalable and dynamic response to rapidly changing intellectual, cultural and technological conditions.</p>

<p>The premise of CCDK is that we are now entering the third phase of Digital Humanities. The first phase prioritized the digitization of analogue materials. The second phase involved the growth of a digital humanities discipline, which has promoted new working practices in the humanities and social sciences. One result of these two phases has been the facilitation and increased&nbsp;speed&nbsp;of access to data. The third phase now urgently requires new forms of understanding that will use new technologies to transcend rather than perpetuate well-worn approaches in the humanities and social sciences. The CCDK is structured around two strands of research which represent the two most pressing concerns of digital humanities: Digital Epistemology and Digital Society.</p>

<p>The&nbsp;Cambridge&nbsp;Centre for&nbsp;Digital Knowledge&nbsp;comprises of the&nbsp;<strong>Technology and Democracy&nbsp;project</strong>, the&nbsp;<strong>Concept Lab</strong>&nbsp;and the&nbsp;<strong>Digital Society&nbsp;project</strong>.</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">People</h3>
										<p><strong><span style="line-height: 1.6em;">Project Leaders</span></strong></p>

<p>Professor <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/david-runciman">David Runciman</a>&nbsp;(POLIS, University of Cambridge)<br />
Professor <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/john-naughton">John Naughton</a>&nbsp;(CRASSH, University of&nbsp;Cambridge)</p>

<p><strong>Research Fellows</strong></p>

<p>Dr&nbsp;<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/daniel-wilson">Daniel Wilson</a><br />
Dr <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/nora-ni-loideain">Nora Ni Loideain</a></p>

<p><strong>Project Administrator</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/judith-weik">Judith Weik</a></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Visiting Fellows</h3>
										<p><strong>David Vincent&nbsp;</strong>is Emeritus Professor of Social History at The Open University, and Visiting Professor at Keele University.&nbsp;He is the author or editor of sixteen books on British and European social history.&nbsp; His publications include&nbsp;<em>Bread, Knowledge and Freedom.&nbsp;A Study of&nbsp;Nineteenth-Century&nbsp;Working Class Autobiography</em>&nbsp;(Methuen, 1982);&nbsp;<em>Literacy and Popular Culture.&nbsp;England</em> 1750&#8209;1914&nbsp;(Cambridge University Press, 1989);&nbsp;<em>The Culture of Secrecy: Britain 1832&#8209;1998</em>&nbsp;(Oxford University Press, 1998),&nbsp;<em>The Rise of Mass Literacy. Reading and Writing in Modern Europe</em>&nbsp;(Polity Press, 2000);&nbsp;<em>I Hope I Don&rsquo;t Intrude.&nbsp;Privacy and its Dilemmas in Nineteenth-Century Britain</em>&nbsp;(Oxford University Press, 2015).&nbsp;His next book is&nbsp;<em>Privacy. A Short History</em>&nbsp;(Polity, January 2016). &nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Charles Arthur&nbsp;</strong>is a freelance Tech Journalist and previously was technology editor at The Guardian. He has also written for The Independent and the New Scientist about technology, science and the environment.</p>

<p><strong>Christena Nippert-Eng</strong> ( visiting March to April 2017)&nbsp;is a sociologist and Professor of Informatics at Indiana University Bloomington.&nbsp;Her scholarly interests include cognitive and formal sociology, everyday life, privacy, culture, technology, user-centered design, and multi-species research.</p>

<p><strong>Lawrence Quill</strong> (visiting March to April 2017) is Professor of Political Science at San Jose State University. His books include&nbsp;<em>Secrets and Democracy: From Arcana Imperii to WikiLeaks</em>.</p>

<p><strong>Frank Pasquale</strong> (visiting May to June 2017) is Professor of Law at the University of Maryland Francis King Carey School of Law. His research agenda focuses on challenges posed to information law by rapidly changing technology, particularly in the health care, Internet, and finance industries. His book&nbsp;<em>The Black Box Society: Technologies of Search, Reputation, and Finance</em>&nbsp;develops a social theory of reputation, search, and finance.</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="4" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Publications</h3>
										<p>Coming soon!</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="5" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Media</h3>
										<p>Recording of project events and conferences: <a href="https://sms.cam.ac.uk/collection/1978689">https://sms.cam.ac.uk/collection/1978689</a></p>
									</div>
								</div>
							</div>
						</article>
					</div>
				</div>

		</footer>

							<h1>The Concept Lab (Cambridge Centre for Digital Knowledge)</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

							<h4 class="date">2014 to 2017</h4>
							 
						</div>

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >People</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Publications and Working Papers</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="4" >The CCDK</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p>The Concept Lab&nbsp;studies the architectures of conceptual forms. It is committed to the view that concepts are not equivalent to the meanings of the words which express them. The Lab considers conceptual architectures as generating structured environments for sensing that one has arrived at understanding. Through computational methodologies it seeks to describe and analyse these structured environments which have both internal and external manifestations. With respect to the internal structure of concepts we aim to characterise not only form and function but also modalities and other attributes of conceptual entities. In the case of external features we seek to uncover the conceptual networks within which concepts circulate. In both cases the Lab develops data driven accounts of these structures and networks derived from large scale corpora.</p>

<p>The Concept Lab aims to generate a substantial repository of data that will allow us to understand better how concepts work. Although our primary focus is on the cultural expression and manifestation of conceptual forms, deriving our data from the written record of linguistic usage, we intend our work to contribute to the understanding of concepts in the widest sense. Thus, although the Lab does not engage in experimental methodologies for exposing cognitive behaviours and does not, correspondingly, seek to explain how human agents possess concepts it does regard its work as complementary to such studies.</p>

<p>A second strand of work concerns the historical extension of conceptual forms. This aspect of our project seeks to identify where, how and why concepts change or emerge over time. To this end it is engaged in the production of a number of case studies that explore both the computational methodologies that are continuously revised by the Lab and the histories of words, concepts and usages that heretofore have provided the common currency of the history of ideas.</p>

<p>The Lab has a North American counterpart working in tandem with the Cambridge group.&nbsp;The four researchers in Cambridge &ndash; Peter de Bolla, Paul Nulty, Gabriel Recchia and John Regan &ndash; regularly meet remotely with the four researchers in North America &ndash; Clifford Siskin, Mark Algee-Hewitt, Bill Blake and Yohei Igarashi.&nbsp;The entire group has a yearly workshop that meets either in Cambridge or North America.</p>

<p>The work of the Lab is intended to contribute to two larger projects.&nbsp;One, the Cambridge Centre for Digital Knowledge based in CRASSH, seeks to further our understanding of how new knowledge is produced in the digital domain.&nbsp;The second, the Re: Enlightement Project, seeks to promote innovative means for creating new knowledge.</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">People</h3>
										<p><strong>The Concept Lab Cambridge</strong></p>

<p><strong>Director </strong></p>

<p>Professor <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/peter-de-bolla">Peter de Bolla</a>&nbsp;(English, University of Cambridge)</p>

<p><strong>Research Associates</strong></p>

<p>Dr&nbsp;<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/dr3">Paul&nbsp;Nulty</a><br />
Dr <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/john-regan">John Regan</a><br />
Dr <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/gabriel-recchia">Gabriel Recchia</a></p>

<p><strong>Project Administrator</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://Judith Weik">Judith Weik</a></p>

<p><strong>The Concept Lab North America</strong></p>

<p><strong>Director</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://english.fas.nyu.edu/object/CliffordSiskin.html">Clifford Siskin</a>&nbsp;(English,&nbsp;NYU)</p>

<p><strong>Research Group</strong></p>

<p><a href="https://english.stanford.edu/people/mark-algee-hewitt">Mark Algee-Hewitt</a>&nbsp;(English,&nbsp;Stanford University)<br />
<a href="http://english.fas.nyu.edu/object/BillBlake.html">Bill Blake</a>&nbsp;(English, NYU)<br />
<a href="http://english.uconn.edu/yohei-igarashi/">Yohei Igarashi</a>&nbsp;(English, University of&nbsp;Connecticut)</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Publications and Working Papers</h3>
										<p><strong>Publications</strong></p>

<p>Nulty, Paul. (2017). "Network Visualisations for Exploring Political Concepts". <em>Proceedings of the 12th International Conference on Computational Semantics (IWCS)</em>.</p>

<p>Recchia, G. &amp; Nulty, P. Improving a fundamental measure of lexical association. To appear in&nbsp;<em>Proceedings of the 39th Annual Conference of the Cognitive Science Society</em>.</p>

<p>Recchia, G., Jones, E., Nulty, P., Regan, J., &amp; de Bolla, P. (2016). Tracing shifting conceptual vocabularies through time. In Ciancarini, P. et al. (Eds.): <em>Knowledge Engineering and Knowledge Management: EKAW 2016 Satellite Events, EKM and Drift-an-LOD, Bologna, Italy, November 19&ndash;23, 2016, Revised Selected Papers</em>&nbsp;(pp. 19-28). Springer International AG: Cham, Switzerland. doi: 10.1007/978-3-319-58694-6</p>

<p>Recchia, G. (2016). The utility of count-based models for the digital humanities.&nbsp;Abstract in proceedings of the&nbsp;<em>Digital Humanities Congress 2016</em>. Sheffield: HRI Online&nbsp;Publications, 2016.&nbsp;<a href="https://www.hrionline.ac.uk/dhc/2016/paper/98">https://www.hrionline.ac.uk/dhc/2016/paper/98</a></p>

<p>Recchia, G. (2017). Fall and rise of AI: Computational methods for investigating cultural narratives. Invited presentation to&nbsp;<em>AI Narratives: Workshop 1</em>, Leverhulme Centre for the Future of Intelligence and the Royal Society, 16 May 2017, Hughes Hall, Cambridge.</p>

<p>de Bolla, P., Jones, E., Nulty, P., Recchia, G., &amp; Regan, J. (2016). The Concept Lab. Invited presentation to The Stanford Literary Lab and Alan Liu&rsquo;s research group at UC Santa Barbara.</p>

<p>Recchia, G. (2016). Tracing concepts through time. Invited talk at Natural Language and Information Processing Seminar Series, University of Cambridge, UK.</p>

<p>Recchia, G. (2016). Big data in the social sciences and the humanities. Invited talk/workshop at Cambridge AHRC Doctoral Training Partnership: Workshop on Big and Small Data, University of Cambridge, UK.</p>

<p>Recchia, G. (2015). Making sense of language: It&rsquo;s okay to count. Invited talk at Microsoft Research Cambridge, UK.</p>

<p>Recchia, G. (2015). The unreasonable effectiveness of co-occurrence based models. Big Data Methods for Social Sciences and Policy, University of Cambridge, UK.</p>

<p><strong>Working Papers and Presentations</strong></p>

<p>Dr John Regan, Blog post:&nbsp;<a href="https://ccdkconceptlab.files.wordpress.com/2015/04/the-concept-of-system-in-david-humes-the-history-of-england.pdf">The Concept of System in David Hume&rsquo;s The History of England</a><br />
<br />
Dr Paul Nulty, Blog post:&nbsp;<a href="http://paulnulty.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/booktitles1.html">Titles in Digital Book Collections, 1700&ndash;1900</a><br />
<br />
Concept Drift&nbsp;Workshop at International Conference on&nbsp;Knowledge Engineering and Knowledge Management, Bologna, Italy, 2016<br />
Gabriel Recchia, Ewan Jones, Paul Nulty, John Regan, and Peter de Bolla presented:&nbsp;Tracing Shifting Conceptual Vocabularies Through Time<br />
<a href="http://event.cwi.nl/drift-a-lod/2016/papers/Drift-a-LOD2016_paper_1.pdf">Workshop paper</a><br />
<a href="http://Workshop presentation">Workshop presentation</a><br />
<br />
Gabriel Recchia, Blog post: &nbsp;<a href="http://www.twonewthings.com/gabrielrecchia/2016/06/11/numberless-degrees-of-similitude-word-vectors/">Numberless Degrees of Similitude: A Response to&nbsp;Ryan Heuser&rsquo;s &#39;Word Vectors in the Eighteenth Century, Part&nbsp;1&#39;</a></p>

<p>Nulty, P. Detecting and Visualizing the Linguistic Structure of Political Concepts. presented at:&nbsp;Applied Quantitative Text Analysis Conference, LSE. 2017</p>

<p>Nulty, P. and Regan, J. Methods for Distributional Concept Analysis. presented at: The Digital Archive Today Colloquium, Faculty of English, University of Cambridge. 2017<br />
&nbsp;</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="4" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">The CCDK</h3>
										<p>The Cambridge Centre for Digital Knowledge (CCDK) constitutes an ambitious response to the current state of digital knowledge, in a form that enables swift, scalable and dynamic response to rapidly changing intellectual, cultural and technological conditions.</p>

<p>The premise of CCDK is that we are now entering the third phase of Digital Humanities. The first phase prioritized the digitization of analogue materials. The second phase involved the growth of a digital humanities discipline, which has promoted new working practices in the humanities and social sciences. One result of these two phases has been the facilitation and increased speed of access to data. The third phase now urgently requires new forms of understanding that will use new technologies to transcend rather than perpetuate well-worn approaches in the humanities and social sciences. The CCDK is structured around two strands of research which represent the two most pressing concerns of digital humanities: Digital Epistemology and Digital Society.</p>

<p>The&nbsp;<strong>Cambridge&nbsp;Centre for&nbsp;Digital Knowledge</strong>&nbsp;comprises of the&nbsp;<strong>Technology and Democracy</strong>&nbsp;project, the&nbsp;<strong>Concept Lab&nbsp;</strong>and the&nbsp;<strong>Digital Society</strong>&nbsp;project.</p>
									</div>
								</div>
							</div>
						</article>
					</div>
				</div>

				<div class="span4">

				<li>The History of Cross-Cultural Comparatism</li>

			<div class="row">
				<div class="span12">
					<div class="row mb10">
						<div class="span12">
							<h1>The History of Cross-Cultural Comparatism</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							
							 
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>
            <li class="twitter">
                <a href="https://twitter.com/share?text=The History of Cross-Cultural Comparatism&url=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/the-history-of-cross-cultural-comparatism" data-social-text="Share on Twitter">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_twitter.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="facebook">
                <a href="http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/the-history-of-cross-cultural-comparatism" data-social-text="Share on Facebook">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_facebook.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="email">
                <a href="mailto:?subject=The History of Cross-Cultural Comparatism&body=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/the-history-of-cross-cultural-comparatism" data-social-text="Share via email">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icon_mailing.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
        </ul>
    </nav>
</div>

						</div>
					</div>
					<hr>
				</div>
			</div>

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >People</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Sawyer Seminars</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;"><br />
The aim of this project is to compare the comparative cultures of different periods and to reconsider the specificities of modern comparative approaches within the variety of comparative moments. Four moments will be investigated through papers on themes&nbsp; and key individual authors: the comparatisms of ancient Greece, 17th century Humanism, 19th century England, and post-modern approaches. The great variety&nbsp; of comparative approaches found in each moment will provide plenty of opportunity for original investigations into particulars and details, and even more material for the systematic, comparative assessment of the cultures they embody.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Two sets of interrelated questions will run through the entire seminar.&nbsp; 1) The interaction of religion, power, and translation at play in the classifications of cultural comparison. So, how do the different areas of comparison &ndash; law, religion, customs, political systems and so forth &ndash; change the practices of comparison? At what points and how do cultural comparisons become part of a narrative of political, religious or imperial power? What is the relation between <em>translatio imperii </em>and other forms of translation inherent in comparison? How do different forms of comparison interrelate and contest each other?&nbsp;&nbsp; 2) The differential roles of past and present cultures in the analysis of cultural difference: what are the consequences of adopting a practice of synchronic or diachronic comparison? When and for what purposes does it become critical to compare the contemporary with the past? Or with other contemporary cultures? Special attention here will be given to the exceptional role of Athens and Jerusalem in shaping the Western understanding of cultural difference. The link between the first and second thematic strands are evident: the choice for religious, political, social (etc) comparisons and the agendas such choices embody, find specific form in the construction of comparisons with the great traditions of religious, political, and intellectual pasts summed up in the classical and biblical traditions.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">One running thread will be followed through the vast and open-ended history of Western cultural comparisons: Greek religion. The representations of Greek religious thought and practice, so prominent in classical art and literature, continued to offer the Christian West a powerful image of difference at the heart of its shared cultural memory. The reception of Greek religion is a key component in the development of cultural comparison in the West, and it has a long and complex history. The Cambridge Sawyer Seminars will look at four moments in that evolution: the imperial and late antique reconfigurations of a comparative Hellenism, the theological comparatisms of the early modern period, and the development of a science of imperial comparison in the 19<sup>th</sup> century. Modernity, our fourth area, can &ndash; we maintain and set out to demonstrate &ndash; only be fully appreciated within this historical perspective, not least since so much of modernity defines itself in hostile or longing contrast to these pasts. Most of the invited participants will be scholars who not only have an interest in the history of cultural comparison, but also work actively in comparative research of their own. Contributors will be asked to discuss the specificities of individual approaches, and to contrast them to other approaches from the same moment, so as to uncover the ideological faultlines involved in the works in question, the stakes at play, as well as the debates, conflicts, and disagreements provoked by the idea of comparison itself.&nbsp; The first seminar took place in September 2014 and&nbsp; the second will take place in December 2014. For information about all the seminars please click on the relevant tab on this page.&nbsp; This preparatory work will pave the way for the conference in September 2015, where the thematic threads of all four comparative moments will be investigated side by side. We will pay regular fares for the air and train travel of all participants, and accommodations in Cambridge Colleges.&nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">People</h3>
										<p><strong>Convenors</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/simon-goldhill">Professor Simon Goldhill</a>&nbsp;(CRASSH/Classics, University of Cambridge)<br />
<a href="http://www.nri.org.uk/lloyd.html">Professor Sir Geoffrey Lloyd</a>&nbsp;(Needham Research Institute)<br />
<a href="http://www.classics.cam.ac.uk/directory/renaud-gagne">Dr Renaud Gagn&eacute;</a>&nbsp;(Classics,&nbsp;University of Cambridge)</p>

<p><strong>Research Fellow</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/dmitri-levitin">Dr Dmitri Levitin </a>has been appointed to a three-year fellowship, jointly between the Sawyer Seminar and the Needham Institute. In the first year of the appointment Dr Levitin will assist with the organisation and work of the Sawyer Seminars.</p>

<p><strong>Lloyd-Dan David Research Fellowship at the Needham Research Institute and Darwin College Cambridge</strong></p>

<p>The competition to select a&nbsp; postdoctoral research fellow to work on the Comparative Study of any aspect of Science and Civilization in the Ancient World (defined as down to 1000 AD) at the <a href="http://www.nri.org.uk/">Needham Research Institute</a> has now closed.<br />
<br />
&nbsp;</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Sawyer Seminars</h3>
										<p><strong>Sawyer Seminars&nbsp; 2014-15</strong></p>

<p><strong>Seminar 1: 18-19 September 2014</strong><br />
<em><strong>Comparative Cultures of Ancient Greece</strong></em></p>

<p>Papers and Respondents</p>

<p>Johannes Haubold (University of Durham)<br />
<em>Babel, Bible and the Greeks: comparative entanglements in the study of ancient Mesopotamia</em><br />
Respondent: Tom Harrison (University of Liverpool)</p>

<p>Tim Whitmarsh (University of Oxford)<br />
<em>Can syncritics live their syncrisis? Cultural comparatism in the high Roman Empire</em><br />
Respondent: Guy Stroumsa (University of Oxford)</p>

<p>Philippe Borgeaud (University of Geneva)<br />
<em>R&eacute;action et imitation: Mo&iuml;se et le diable inventeurs de religions</em><br />
Responden: Giovanna Ceserani (Stanford University)</p>

<p>Renaud Gagn&eacute;<em> </em>(University of Cambridge)<br />
<em>The Road to Hyperborea: Centre and Periphery in early Greece</em><br />
Respondent: Corinne Bonnet (SFR,&nbsp; France)</p>

<p>Claude Calame (University of Lausanne)<br />
<em>Sappho, Goethe and Steff la Cheffe: an impertient comparison in "lyric" forms and ethnopoetics</em><br />
Respondent: Simon Goldhill (University of Cambridge)</p>

<p>Geoffrey Lloyd (Needham Reserch Institute)<br />
<em>The multiple valences of comparatisms and the problem of mutual (un)intelligibility</em><br />
Respondent: Glenn Most (SNS, Italy)</p>

<p><strong>Seminar 2: 12-13 December 2014</strong><br />
<strong><em>The Theological Comparatism of 17th Century Humanism</em></strong></p>

<p>Papers and Respondents</p>

<p>Tony Grafton (Princeton)<br />
<em>Comparison in the Study of Late Jews and Early Christians, 1498-1742</em><br />
Respondent: Bruce Lincoln (Chicago)</p>

<p>Guy Stroumsa (Oxford)<br />
<em>The Scholarly Discovery of Religion in Early Modern Times</em><br />
Respondent: Claude Calame (University of Lausanne)</p>

<p>Richard Serjeantson (Cambridge)<br />
<em>Comparativism against Christianity? Edward Herbert and Pagan Religion</em><br />
Respondent: Dmitri Levitin (Cambridge)</p>

<p>Jonathan Sheehan (Berkeley)<br />
<em>Jesus and the Cretan Zeus: Dead Gods and the Comparative Project of&nbsp; Christian Apologetics</em><br />
Respondent: Philippe Descola (College de France)</p>

<p>Giovanna Cesarani (Stanford)<br />
<em>The Athenian and the Jewish Republic in the 16th Century: A Tale of Two Men and (at least) Three Cities</em><br />
Respondent: Tim Whitmarsh (University of Oxford)</p>

<p>Debora Shuger (UCLA) :<br />
<em>Lancelot Andrewes, "A Discourse of ceremonies retained and used in Christian churches"</em><br />
Respondent: Philippe Borgeaud (University of Geneva)</p>

<p><strong>Seminar 3: 20-21 February 2015</strong><br />
<strong><em>Towards a Science of Cultural Comparisons in the 19th Century</em></strong></p>

<p>Papers&nbsp; and Respondents</p>

<p>Theodor Dungelgrun (CRASSH, Cambridge)<br />
<em>The Key to the Key to all Mythologies: Collation, Conversion and the Hebrew Bible in the 19th Century</em><br />
Respondent: Tony Grafton (Princeton)</p>

<p>Simon Goldhill (Cambridge)<br />
<em>What has Alexandria to do with Jerusalem? Writing the History of the Jews in the 19th Century</em><br />
Respondent: Francois Hartog (EHESS)</p>

<p>Tom Harrison (Liverpool)<br />
<em>Herodotean Comparativisms</em><br />
Respondent: Dobora Shuger (UCLA)</p>

<p>Corinne Bonnet (SFR, France)<br />
<em>On ne fait pas l&rsquo;histoire en dehors de l&rsquo;histoire: Quelques r&eacute;flexions sur le comparatisme d&rsquo;Ernest Renan</em><br />
Respondent: Carlo Severi (EHESS)</p>

<p>Miriam Leonard (University College London)<br />
<em>Gods in Exile: Greek/Jew/Christian Comparisons amongst the Young Hegelians</em><br />
Respondent: Marilyn Strathern (Cambridge)</p>

<p>Peter Mandler (Cambridge)<br />
<em>Looking around the World</em><br />
Respondent: Anthony Grafton (Princeton)</p>

<p><strong>Seminar 4: 23-24 April 2015</strong><br />
<strong><em>Modern Doubts and New Beginnings</em></strong></p>

<p>Papers and Respondents</p>

<p>Philippe Descola (College de France)<br />
<em>Anthropological comparatisms: generalisation, symmetrisation, bifurcation</em><br />
Respondent: Miriam Leonard (UCL)</p>

<p>Marilyn Strathern (Cambridge)<br />
<em>Friends and relations: comparisons and comparatism</em><br />
Respondent: Geoffrey Lloyd (Needham Research Institute)</p>

<p>Carlo Severi (EHESS)<br />
<em>Tools, Ornaments and the Human Mind</em><br />
Respondent: Renaud Gagne (Cambridge)</p>

<p>Caroline Humphrey (Cambridge)<br />
<em>Dealing with Kinds: An 18th Century History of the Mongols</em><br />
Respondent: Johannes Haubold (Durham)</p>

<p>Bruce Lincoln (Chicago)<br />
<em>The Perils of Comparison: Ancient and Modern Interpretations of the Scythian</em> *<em>A-naryas</em><br />
Respondent: Philippe Borgeaud (Geneva)</p>

<p><strong>Final Seminar: 24 and 25 September 2015</strong></p>

<p>Papers and Respondents</p>

<p>Bruce Lincoln (Chicago)<br />
<em>What are the roles that the history of cultural comparatism can play in the practice of it?</em><br />
Respondent: Guy Stroumsa (Oxford)</p>

<p>Philippe Borgeaud (Geneva)<br />
<em>Is the mirage of ancient Greek religion a determining factor in the constitution of modern cultural comparatism?</em><br />
Respondent: Phiroze Vasunia (UCL)</p>

<p>Anthony Grafton (Princeton)<br />
<em>Do nineteenth-century Western sciences of cultural comparison constitute a break with early modern practices of comparison?</em><br />
Respondent: Miriam Leonard (UCL)</p>

<p>Matt Candea (Cambridge)<br />
<em>The elision of lateral comparison in anthropology</em><br />
Respondent: Dmitri Levitin (Cambridge)</p>

<p>Marilyn Strathern (Cambridge)<br />
<em>What turns comparison into comparatism?</em><br />
Respondent: Jonathan Sheehan (Berkeley)</p>

<p>Philippe Descola (College de France)<br />
<em>What is incomparability?</em><br />
Respondent: Brooke Holmes (Princeton)</p>
									</div>

		    })(window,document,'//static.hotjar.com/c/hotjar-','.js?sv=');
		</script>

					<div class="row mb10">
						<div class="span12">
							<h1>The Politics and Paradoxes of Transparency [2016-17]</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">Alternate Wednesdays, 12.00-14.00 during term time</h4>
							
							<p class="meta">
								<span class="location">Seminar SG2, Alison Richard Building</span>
							</p>
							
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>
