			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Convenors</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Programme 2016-17</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;">A new Research Group on the Politics and Paradoxes of Transparency will launch at CRASSH in 2016-17, run by Ella McPherson (Sociology) and Alfred Moore (CRASSH). The group will explore the&nbsp;ambivalent effects of ideals and technologies of transparency.&nbsp;Transparency is commonly assumed to be a good thing to which regimes, organisations, and even people should aspire. Yet it is also widely recognised that transparency can be corrosive. It seems to be both a cure for and a cause of distrust. It has been associated with ways of taming bureaucracy that themselves generate more bureaucracy. It promises immediacy in personal relations yet can generate distance. Transparency for some can create obscurity for others.&nbsp;Transparency is&nbsp;a complex conceptual compound, a response to very different problems of corruption, limited knowledge, political exclusion and governance in complex environments, each of which invokes distinct and often conflicting political goods.<br />
<br />
While it is common to talk of new technologies heralding an &lsquo;age of transparency&rsquo;, in this research group we want to focus on particular examples of how technologies accelerate, mediate, and co-produce ideals and practices of transparency in three different areas: (i) the public sphere and&nbsp;the production of public knowledge, (ii) political economy and&nbsp;the relations between individuals and commercial actors, and (iii) the reordering of personal relations. We will ask how technologies of transparency&nbsp;reproduce and reorder relations of power,&nbsp;and how opening up institutions and practices can at the same time introduce new patterns of closure and seclusion.&nbsp;In each of these areas we will bring a multi-disciplinary focus on concrete examples, with the aim of developing a more precise set of research questions around the politics and paradoxes of transparency.&nbsp;<br />
<br />
The format will consist of a closed reading group, which will meet twice a term to discuss the texts of authors invited from across disciplines, as well as a one open lecture per term.&nbsp; Please register your interest below to receive further information on joining the reading group as well as on the lecture schedule.<br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><br />
<strong>Please join the<a href="https://lists.cam.ac.uk/mailman/listinfo/crassh-transparency">&nbsp;mailing list&nbsp;here</a>&nbsp;to receive further information </strong>on joining the reading group as well as on the lecture schedule.<br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Administrative assistant: <a href="mailto:gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk">gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk</a></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Convenors</h3>
										<p><strong>Convenors</strong></p>

<p><a href="mailto:em310@cam.ac.uk">Dr Ella McPherson</a> (Lecturer in the Sociology of New Media and Digital Technology, Department of Sociology)<br />
<a href="mailto:am2214@cam.ac.uk">Dr Alfred Moore</a> (Research Fellow, CRASSH)<br />
<a href="mailto:od252@cam.ac.uk">Dr Olivier Driessens</a> (Department of Sociology) <a href="http://www.sociology.cam.ac.uk/people/academic-staff/odriessens">FI</a></p>

<p><br />
<strong>Faculty Advisors</strong></p>

<p>Professor John Naughton (Senior Research Fellow, CRASSH, Director, Press Fellowship Programme Wolfson College)<br />
&nbsp;</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Programme 2016-17</h3>
										<p><table class="table table-bordered table-striped table-hover mt20"><thead><tr><th>Politics and Paradoxes of Transparency</th></tr></thead><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26893">The Origins and Effects of the UK Freedom of Information Act.</a></strong><br><i>26 October 2016, Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building.</i><br><p>Benjamin Worthy (Birkbeck), Public Lecture [Online Registration]-at The Politics and Paradoxes of Transparency</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26992">Accountability and the State in the Age of Technology</a></strong><br><i>09 November 2016, Erasmus Room at Queens' College, Silver Street, Cambridge CB3 9ET [*NB Different venue  and time today]</i><br><p>Graham Denyer Willis (Cambridge), Ernesto Schwartz-Marin (Durham) at <strong>2pm only today </strong>[Online Registration]- At The Politics and Paradoxes of Transparency</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26892">Fact-checking and the Production of Political Knowledge</a></strong><br><i>23 November 2016, Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Tanya Filer (Cambridge), Jason Reifler (Exeter) [Online Registration] -at The Politics and Paradoxes of Transparency</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27085">Cancelled:Politics of Personalised Insurance Pricing in the Age of Wearable Devices: Big Data...</a></strong><br><i>08 February 2017, Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Liz McFall (Open University), Dan Wilson (Cambridge)- at Politics &amp; Paradoxes of Transparency</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27084">Crowdsourcing Corporate Transparency</a></strong><br><i>22 February 2017, Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building.</i><br><p>Richard Mills (Cambridge), Milena Marin (Amnesty) -at Politics &amp; Paradoxes of Transparency</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27086">Technology, Transparency, and Policing</a></strong><br><i>08 March 2017, Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Barak Ariel (Cambridge), Adam Edwards (University of Cardiff)-at Politics &amp; Paradoxes of Transparency</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27087">'Transparency' From Transgression to Common Sense -With Notes on the Role of Technology</a></strong><br><i>10 March 2017, Seminar room B4. Institute of Criminology, Sidgwick Ave. NB Change of venue and time*</i><br><p>Public Lecture, Michael Schudson (Columbia)-at Politics &amp; Paradoxes of Transparency. Online registration required.</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27191">Cultural History of Transparency</a></strong><br><i>03 May 2017, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Reading Group&nbsp;at The Politics and Paradoxes of Transparency</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27192">Wearables and the Quantified Self: Transparency, Big Data and Solidarity</a></strong><br><i>17 May 2017, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Reading Group at&nbsp;The Politics and Paradoxes of Transparency</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27193">Organizational Transparency: Practices, Governance and Trust</a></strong><br><i>31 May 2017, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building *NB different date</i><br><p>Reading Group at&nbsp;The Politics and Paradoxes of Transparency</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27272">Breaking Aleppo: The Facts and Figures of the Conflict</a></strong><br><i>13 June 2017, S2, Alison Richard Building, 7 West Road</i><br><p>Part of&nbsp; the Politics and Paradoxes of Transparency Research Group series.</p></td></tr></table></p>
									</div>

							<h1>The Politics of Economics</h1>
						</div>

							<h4 class="date">Alternate Tuesdays 12:00-14:00 during term-time</h4>
							
							<p class="meta">
								<span class="location">Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building</span>

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Convenors</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Programme 2017-18</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;">Economics affects politics, politics affects economics, and there is politics internal to economics. The Politics of Economics will bring different disciplinary&nbsp;angles together for a discussion of these aspects of the politics-economics relation, and their normative and epistemic consequences.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Economics has been criticised from many angles. The Politics of Economics will not rehash these criticisms but will instead examine the ways in which politics and economics have been and are by necessity entwined in order to think about how we can and should structure economic advice.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><br />
Sign up to our mailing list for pre-circulated papers and announcements&nbsp;<a href="https://lists.cam.ac.uk/mailman/listinfo/ucam-politics-of-economics">here</a></p>

<p>Administrative assistance: <a href="mailto:gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk">gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk</a></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Convenors</h3>
										<p><strong>Convenors</strong><br />
<br a="" href="mailto:rd533@cam.ac.uk" />
<a href="mailto:jw675@cam.ac.uk">Jack Wright&nbsp;</a> ( PhD Candidate, History and Philosophy of Science)<br />
<a href="mailto:rd533@cam.ac.uk">Raffaele Danna</a> (PhD Candidate, History)<br />
<a href="mailto:kch34@cam.ac.uk">Kim Caspar Hecker</a> (PhD Candidate, POLIS)<br />
<a href="mailto:jmv32@cam.ac.uk">Jens van &#39;t Klooster </a>(PhD Candidate, Philosophy)<br />
<a href="mailto:acp62@cam.ac.uk">Alice Pearson</a> (PhD Candidate, Sociology)<br />
<a href="mailto:iabs2@cam.ac.uk">Ida A. B. Sognnaes</a> (PhD Candidate, Land Economy)</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><img alt="" src="/assets/general/Jack_Write_PE.png" style="width: 109px; height: 100px; margin-left: 10px; margin-right: 10px; float: left;" /><strong>Jack Wright </strong>is a doctoral candidate in the Department of History and Philosophy of Science. Jack works on scientific pluralism and contextualism and what they mean for economics, with a particular focus on how economic expertise can and should be structured. Jack has also written on the epistemic status of economic modelling and the use of evidence-based and data driven forms of reasoning in policy making. Jack has previous degrees in mathematics, economics, and philosophy.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><img alt="" src="/assets/general/Raffaele_Danna.png" style="width: 100px; height: 100px; margin-left: 10px; margin-right: 10px; float: left;" /><strong>Raffaele Danna</strong> is a PhD candidate at the Faculty of History. His research focuses on the diffusion of the &ldquo;Commercial Revolution&rdquo; from Italy to Europe relying mainly on the diffusion of the Hindu-Arabic numeral system between the XIII and the XVI centuries. He holds a BA and an MA in Philosophy from the University of Bologna. He is broadly interested in interdisciplinary approaches to History as well as to contemporary issues, an interest which he fosters also by sitting on the editorial board of Pandora &ndash; Rivista di Teoria e Politica.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><img alt="" src="/assets/general/Kim_Hecker.png" style="width: 109px; height: 100px; margin-left: 10px; margin-right: 10px; float: left;" /><strong>Kim Hecker</strong> is a PhD candidate at the Department of Politics and International Studies looking at the relationship between contemporary perspectives on technological change and 20th century political thought. His wider research interests range from topics relating to philosophy of technology to &#39;realist&#39; political theory.</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><img alt="" src="/assets/general/Jens_van_t_K.png" style="width: 109px; height: 100px; margin-left: 10px; margin-right: 10px; float: left;" /><strong>Jens van &#39;t Klooster</strong> is a PhD candidate in Philosophy who works on financial markets, distributive justice, and related topics. His dissertation is titled &lsquo;How to make money: Distributive justice, finance and monetary constitutions&rsquo; and makes a case for money and finance as a central concepts of political philosophy.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><img alt="" src="/assets/general/Ida_Sognnaes.png" style="width: 111px; height: 100px; margin-left: 10px; margin-right: 10px; float: left;" /><strong>Ida Sognnaes</strong> is a PhD researcher at the Cambridge Centre for&nbsp;Environment, Energy and Natural Resource Governance (C-EENRG) working on the interactions between energy, environment, and economic systems. Her thesis examines the application of integrated economic models to guide sustainable development. Ida has a broad interdisciplinary background centred&nbsp;around environmental issues and has degrees in applied mathematics and physics, political science, and energy and resources. Prior to setting up&nbsp;The Politics of Economics Ida ran&nbsp;Paper 0&nbsp;for two years. &nbsp;</p>

<p>&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Faculty Advisors</strong></p>

<p>Dr Stephen John (Lecturer in History and Philosophy of Science)<br />
Dr Anna Alexandrova (Lecturer in History and Philosophy of Science)<br />
Dr Ha-Joon Chang (Reader in Economics and Director of the Centre of Development Studies)<br />
Professor David Runciman (Professor of Politics and Head of POLIS)</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Programme 2017-18</h3>
										<p><table class="table table-bordered table-striped table-hover mt20"><thead><tr><th>Politics of Economics</th></tr></thead><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27419">Why Do Rich People Love Austerity?</a></strong><br><i>10 October 2017, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Dan Hausman (Wisconsin-Madison) - Politics of Economics</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27420">Philosophy and Public Policy after Piketty</a></strong><br><i>24 October 2017, Seminar Room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Martin O&#39;Neill (York) - Politics of Economics</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27421">The Politics of New Economic Technologies</a></strong><br><i>07 November 2017, Seminar Room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Hannah Kuchler (Financial Times), Mathew Lawrence (The Institute for Public Policy Research),&nbsp;Julian Gruin, (Amsterdam) - Politics of Economics</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27422">The Two Puzzles of Social Democracy: How it Confutes Market Doctrines</a></strong><br><i>21 November 2017, Seminar Room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Avner Offer (Oxford) - Politics of Economics</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27556">The Last Crisis of Social Democracy: Economics and "Populisms"</a></strong><br><i>23 January 2018, Seminar room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Wolfgang Munchau (Financial Times), Federico Fubini (Corriere della Sera) - Politics of Economics</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27557">Is There Really an Empirical Turn in Economics?</a></strong><br><i>06 February 2018, Seminar room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Beatrice Cherrier (Caen) - Politics of Economics</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27558">Economics and Democracy: The Role of Think Tanks</a></strong><br><i>20 February 2018, Seminar room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Paul Johnson (Institute for Fiscal Studies), Angus Armstrong (National Institute for Economic and Social Research) - Politics of Economics</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27559">Populism and Central Bank Independence</a></strong><br><i>06 March 2018, Seminar room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Rosa Lastra (Queen Mary, London) - Politics of Economics</p></td></tr></table></p>
									</div>
								</div>
							</div>
						</article>

			<div class="span3">
				<hr class="visible-phone mb20">
				<h3>Blog</h3>
				
<ul class="blog">
	

	<li>

					<div class="row mb10">
						<div class="span12">
							<h1>Theologies of Reading</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							<h4 class="date">Alternate Wednesdays 17:00-19:00 during term-time</h4>
							
							<p class="meta">
								<span class="location">Seminar room SG2, Alison Richard Building</span>
							</p>
							
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">
							<div class="socialShare">
    <nav role="social">
        <ul>
            <li class="twitter">
                <a href="https://twitter.com/share?text=Theologies of Reading&url=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/theologies-of-reading" data-social-text="Share on Twitter">
                    <img src="/static/svg/icons_twitter.svg">
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="facebook">
                <a href="http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/programmes/theologies-of-reading" data-social-text="Share on Facebook">

                </a>
            </li>

			<div class="row mt20">
				<div class="span8">
					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Convenors</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Programme 2017-18</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;">To read, and read at the same time one&rsquo;s own reading, the notion of reading, the mechanical or quasi-mechanical necessity for that particular reading, at this moment, in this place, in this state. [&hellip;]&nbsp; To read, and doubt what you read, but in an abstract way, without <em>reading</em> the doubt.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&mdash;Simone Weil<br />
&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>What is it to read?&nbsp; Why and how do we read?</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Today, the assumption made by most is that reading is about &lsquo;getting&rsquo; content. Reading has become so much the medium of consumption, that we are at risk of losing the ability to reflect on the action of reading itself. To do so is to assume that meaning or truth remains stable in a text, and may seem an encroachment on the freedom of the individual reader. Yet liberalism has its own encroachments, assuming not only the possibility but the desirability of disinterested reading.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">This seminar series, held at CRASSH in 2017-18, sets out to interrogate the assumption that reading should or could be disinterested. It asks instead: in what ways does reading remain interested in questions of truth and meaning?</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Historically, religious traditions have formulated some of the most detailed regimes of reading, resulting in practices such as Lectio Divina, Quranic recitation and Midrash. But literary-critical disciplines such as philology, prosody and deconstruction have also developed practices of reading which, though they may disavow &lsquo;truth&rsquo;, share common terms, methodologies and horizons of meaning with religious practices. All these practices, we propose, bear scrutiny as &lsquo;theologies&rsquo; of reading. New practices continue to emerge. While some, following Michel Foucault and Peter Sloterdijk, insist on the therapeutic and &lsquo;anthropotechnic&rsquo; uses of texts, the media suggests speed and velocity as a criterion of value. In the face of this multiplicity of programs, all vying for supremacy while disavowing the possibilities of a common practice it has never been more important to refrain from asking not only, &lsquo;what do we read?&rsquo; but also: &lsquo;how do we read?&rsquo;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Each session introduces two speakers who will deliver brief presentations of a reading practice &mdash;historical or contemporary, sacred or secular&mdash;and then, together with the group, will discuss a pre-circulated text which resists or exemplifies the style under consideration.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><br />
Administrative assistance: <a href="mailto:gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk">gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk</a></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Convenors</h3>
										<p><strong>Convenors</strong></p>

<p><a href="mailto:rej34@cam.ac.uk">Dr Ruth Jackson</a>&nbsp; (Research Associate at CRASSH on the Bible and Antiquity in 19th Century Culture project.Discipline: Theology)<br />
<a href="mailto:sak54@cam.ac.uk">Dr Simone Kotva</a>&nbsp; (Junior Research Fellow, Emmanuel College and Faculty of Divinity. Discipline: Theology)<br />
<a href="mailto:lgmbk2@cam.ac.uk ">Dr Laura Kilbride</a>&nbsp; (Junior Research Fellow, Peterhouse and Faculty of English. Discipline: English)</p>

<p><br />
<strong>Faculty Advisors</strong></p>

<p>Professor Janet Soskice&nbsp; (Professor of Philosophical Theology, Faculty of Divinity, Cambridge)<br />
Dr Christopher Burlinson (CTO in English at Jesus College, Cambridge)<br />
Professor Simon Goldhill (Director of CRASSH, Classics, Cambridge)</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Programme 2017-18</h3>
										<p>&nbsp;<table class="table table-bordered table-striped table-hover mt20"><thead><tr><th>Theologies of Reading</th></tr></thead><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27376">Hermeneutics</a></strong><br><i>04 October 2017, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Andrew Bowie (Royal Holloway,&nbsp;London),&nbsp;Alison Scott-Baumann (SOAS, London) - Theologies of Reading</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27377">Lectio Divina</a></strong><br><i>18 October 2017, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>David Foster (Benedictine Monk),&nbsp;&nbsp;Richard Irvine&nbsp;&nbsp;(Open University) - Theologies of Reading</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27378">Recitation and Memory</a></strong><br><i>01 November 2017, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Mirina Paananen &nbsp;(Oxford),&nbsp;Tariq Moqbel (Cambridge) - Theologies of Reading</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27379">Reading as Commentary</a></strong><br><i>15 November 2017, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Daniel Boyarin (California),&nbsp;Andrea Schatz (KCL ) - Theologies of Reading<br />
<strong>Register Online please.</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27380">Prosody</a></strong><br><i>29 November 2017, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Clive Scott (East Anglia),&nbsp;David Nowell-Smith (East Anglia) - Theologies of Reading</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27544">Translation</a></strong><br><i>17 January 2018, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Simon Goldhill (Cambridge), Robin Kirkpatrick (Cambridge)- Theologies of Reading</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27545">Philology (Grammar & God)</a></strong><br><i>31 January 2018, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Brian Cummings (York), Giles Waller (Cambridge)- Theologies of Reading</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27546">Rhetoric</a></strong><br><i>14 February 2018, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Terrence Cave (Oxford),&nbsp; Sophie Read (Cambridge)&nbsp;- Theologies of Reading</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27547">Reading and Fundamentalism</a></strong><br><i>28 February 2018, Seminar Room SG2, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Matthew Engelke (LSE), Tim Jenkins (Cambridge) - Theologies of Reading</p></td></tr></table></p>
									</div>

										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >Convenors</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Programme 2017-18</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="4" >Past events</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="5" >Previous Themes</a></li>

								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Imaginative Things: Curious Objects 1400-2000</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Following a highly successful year in which the <em>Things</em> seminars explored objects and embodiment, during 2017-18 we further our investigation into the connection between material culture and the mind. We explore how objects affect cognition not just in virtue of their functional characteristics or their more obvious ties to human practices, but also through their ability to generate awe, curiosity, whimsy, and drama due to their construction and materials as well as their symbolic significance.&nbsp;<br />
<br />
<em>Imaginative Things </em>examines of objects which may at first appear merely ornamental and fanciful, but which can in fact trigger forms of divergent and creative thinking, as well as a diverse range of emotions that lead to original insights. Things such as these influence cognitive processes via the action of visual and aesthetic stimuli, as well as through the way they engage physically with space and exert agency upon the body.&nbsp;<br />
<br />
We renew our commitment to a nuanced interdisciplinary approach and the desire to bridge the gap between academic researchers with practitioners. Furthermore, this year we dedicate at least one session per term to a &lsquo;workshop&rsquo; style seminar, where the discussion of a topic is followed by a &lsquo;making session&rsquo;. Our aim is to integrate academic investigation with a hands-on appreciation of materials and practices complementing a merely theoretical appreciation of creative processes. Our opening session on Wednesday 11th October constitutes a first example of this new exciting format. We will explore the practice and art of paper marbling with independent artist Hayrettin Kozanoglu and literary scholar Dr Mary Newbould. Future workshops include topics such as leatherwork and taxidermy. Turning the audience into active participants will provide a valuable opportunity to gain different perspectives on materials and practices, fostering a direct engagement which takes into account the emotional as well as intellectual responses objects trigger through sight, sound, touch, and smell.&nbsp;<br />
<br />
<em>Imaginative Things</em> will be run in collaboration with Dr Marta Ajmar at the V&amp;A Research Institute, consolidating a successful partnership which began during the last academic year. Together we will maintain the traditional configuration of <em>Things</em> in Cambridge, while holding one session in Lent and Easter terms at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London. This will grant us privileged access to a multitude of objects from the museum&rsquo;s collection. Our discussions will be complemented and enriched through viewing as well as handling original artefacts. These sessions will thus provide the audience with an extensive, multifaceted, and multi-sensorial understanding of how studying the whimsical side of material culture opens the way to a deeper understanding of objects. Looking into the histories of materials, as well as our mental, emotional, and physical engagement with them, and the cognitive processes involved in creating, interacting, remembering will reveal the power of these <em>Imaginative Things</em> both today and in the past.<br />
<br />
Administrative assistance: <a href="mailto:gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk">gradfac@crassh.cam.ac.uk</a></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">

Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Christine Slottved Kimbriel, Jose Ramon Marcaida (Cambridge)- Things</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26691">Art and Science</a></strong><br><i>11 May 2016, Seminar Room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Stella Panayotova, Carola-Bibiane Sch&ouml;nlieb (Cambridge)- Things</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26692">Slaves</a></strong><br><i>25 May 2016, Seminar Room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>James Poskett (Cambridge), Stefan Han&szlig; (Berlin)- Things</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26693">Bronze</a></strong><br><i>08 June 2016, Seminar Room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Victoria Avery (Cambridge), Andrew Lacey (Artist and Independent Scholar)- Things</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26878">Encounters.</a></strong><br><i>05 October 2016, Seminar Room SG1, Alison Richard Building (NB Different date)</i><br><p>Marta Ajmar (V&amp;A Museum), Roger Kneebone (London), Fleur Oakes (Independent artist)- at Things</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26879">Armour</a></strong><br><i>26 October 2016, Fitzwilliam Museum today </i><br><p>Victoria Bartels (Cambridge) - at Things</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/26880">Passageways</a></strong><br><i>09 November 2016, Seminar Room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Jacqueline Nicholls (Independent Artist), Daniel J&uuml;tte (CRASSH, NYU) - at Things</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a Things</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27067">Collecting</a></strong><br><i>25 January 2017, Seminar room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Sean Silver (Michigan), Ruth Scurr (Cambridge) -at Things</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27068">Curiosities</a></strong><br><i>08 February 2017, Site visit to UL</i><br><p>Visit to UL, Jill Whitelock (UL) -at Things</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27069">Dress</a></strong><br><i>22 February 2017, Seminar room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Rebecca Unsworth (QMUL/V&amp;A), Elizabeth Currie (Central Saints Martins) -at Things</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27070">Death</a></strong><br><i>15 March 2017, Seminar Room SG1, Alison Richard Building (NB Different date)</i><br><p>Emily Rose (Harvard), John Robb (Cambridge) -at Things</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27168">Food</a></strong><br><i>03 May 2017, Seminar Room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>David Gentilcore (Leicester), Richard Fitch (Historic Royal Palaces) at&nbsp;Things</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27169">Porcelain</a></strong><br><i>17 May 2017, Fitzwilliam Museum Site Visit</i><br><p>Fitzwilliam site visit with&nbsp;Helen Ritchie (Dept of Applied Arts) at&nbsp;Things</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27170">Hands</a></strong><br><i>31 May 2017, Seminar Room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>James Daybell (Plymouth) at&nbsp;Things</p></td></tr><tr><td><strong><a href="/events/27139">Curiosity and Cognition: Embodied Things 1400-1900</a></strong><br><i>16 June 2017, Seminar Room SG1, Alison Richard Building</i><br><p>Embodied Things: Histories of Cognition, Practices, &amp; Theories.&nbsp;</p></td></tr></table></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="5" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Previous Themes</h3>
										<p><strong>2016-17&nbsp;Embodied Things: Histories of Cognition, Practices, &amp; Theories</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">We would like to propose an overarching theme of &lsquo;embodiment&rsquo; in connection with material culture as a framing device for the Things seminars in 2016-17. The aim of this innovative approach, which is at the cutting-edge of current scholarship, is to further investigate human understanding of the world vis-&agrave;-vis objects. These seminars will examine a wide range of embodied practices, focusing on the historical and theoretical underpinnings of this larger theme.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">The point of departure focuses on the significance of embodiment in all processes of cognition and learning, moving beyond an obstructive divide between &#39;mind&#39; and &lsquo;hand&#39; - between &lsquo;intellectual&rsquo; and &lsquo;manual&rsquo; knowledge. In particular, we will probe the interaction of objects in relationship to the body and explore issues regarding sensorial experiences. This new approach will allow us to probe the connection between humans and objects in the wider understanding of culture. Discussions will focus on diverse topics including the making of objects and the skills required, artisanal epistemology, and the languages of embodied knowledge from 1400-1900.&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">We seek to break down the divide between the Humanities and Sciences, and this theme will bring together speakers from diverse disciplinary backgrounds within academia and beyond, such as museum curators, conservators, artists, performers, medical experts and scientists. The seminars will engage with topics from Art History, Musicology, History, Archaeology, Anthropology, History and Philosophy of Science, Medicine, Psychology, and Biology amongst others, in order to foster discussion and the development of ideas within and between each discipline; for instance, we have invited Victoria Bartels to speak about the embodiment of the use of armour in the Renaissance, for a site visit to the Fitzwilliam Museum.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">In 2016-17, we intend to collaborate with Marta Ajmar (Victoria &amp; Albert Museum Research Institute) who will be a visiting scholar in Cambridge, and Roger Kneebone (Imperial College) to convene the seminars. Together, we will keep the traditional Things format with a two-speaker minimum, but alternate each &lsquo;conventional&rsquo; seminar with a new style of sessions, including on-site visits, performance-based seminars, and roundtable-style presentations and discussions. The traditional format will continue monthly, with the new sessions complementing them on alternate weeks.&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">Building on the success of the traditional Things discussion-based seminar, next year&rsquo;s sessions will also include more site visits and performative aspects to increase audience engagement. Visits may include the Fitzwilliam Museum to see manuscripts in the Founder&rsquo;s Library in conjunction with a presentation on-site by speakers to explore historical human interaction with manuscripts. Other site visits could include an object session at the Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology to view fan capes. To incorporate a performative aspect, some sessions would include speakers demonstrating the embodied practices discussed in their presentations. For instance, we will invite Victoria Bartels (University of Cambridge) on Renaissance armour, Professor James Daybell (Plymouth University) on gloves, and Professor John Rink (University of Cambridge) on musical performance. These demonstrations combined with comparative papers will provide the audience with a comprehensive examination of how studying material culture through the lens of embodiment facilitates a deeper understanding of objects and their use, and of humanity&rsquo;s historical interactions with &lsquo;things&rsquo;.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>2015-16&nbsp;Things - (Re)constructing the Material World</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&#39;Things&#39; is now a firmly established part of CRASSH and the interdisciplinary community of Cambridge, having been founded in 2011. In 2015-16, we are focusing on the theme of construction and reconstruction in response to an exciting turn in material culture studies, where scholars have been thinking more about production and collaborating with craftspeople and museum professionals to develop a deeper understanding how objects were made, as well as used and consumed. We want to stretch the definition of &#39;reconstruction&#39; even further, to explore how scholars are bridging gaps in the archive, crossing disciplinary borders, and collaborating with practitioners outside of academia in order to &#39;reconstruct&#39; ideas, spaces, and &#39;things&#39; from the past.<br />
<br />
Many of our speakers will be exploring how objects were made and crafted and how knowledge of construction can help us to understand more about how things were used and valued in the early modern world. Some of these speakers will be reconstructing these processes step-by-step in laboratories, workshops, and performance spaces, and we look forward to learning from their practical expertise and experiments.<br />
<br />
Conservators and curators have a different approach to &#39;reconstruction,&#39; and we hope to hear more about how they repair damaged objects and imaginatively bring their collections to life through artistic collaboration and interpretative installations.<br />
<br />
Some of our speakers will be performing less literal kinds of &#39;reconstruction&#39;. We are looking forward to learning how scholars have filled in gaps in their archival sources in innovative ways - employing interdisciplinary methodologies, new approaches to biography and historical fiction, the history of emotions, literary reading, visual analysis, and thinking with &#39;things&#39; to reconstruct the material world.<br />
<br />
While our speakers come from a diverse range of backgrounds - as makers, academics, and museum professionals - they all share a deep interest in objects and place &#39;things&#39; at the heart of their work.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>2014-15&nbsp;Things that Matter</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">In the 2014-2015 academic year, we are pushing the already popular series in new and innovative directions. Considering the &ldquo;material turn&rdquo; in scholarship, this year&rsquo;s series will emphasise the importance of materiality in object study, and we have thus entitled the next year&rsquo;s seminar: Things that Matter, 1400-1900. This play-on-words emphasizes the need to focus scholarship on the material composition of an object in addition to the object&rsquo;s relevance, appearance, and use. A deeper awareness of the matter will allow speakers to emphasize how the economic, cultural, and physical attributes of certain materials and their meanings contributed to understanding the value and connotations of objects in their original contexts.</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>2013-14 Things: Comparing Material Cultures 1500-1900</strong></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">With the dawning of modernity came the age of &lsquo;stuff.&rsquo; Public production, collection, display and consumption of objects grew in influence, popularity, and scale. The form, function, and use of objects, ranging from scientific and musical instruments to weaponry and furnishings were influenced by distinct&nbsp; and changing features of the period. Knowledge was not divided into strict disciplines. In fact, practice across what we now see as academic boundaries was essential to material creation. This seminar series uses an approach based on objects to encourage us to consider the unity of ideas of this period, to emphasise the lived human experience of technology and art, and the global dimension of material culture. It does this by inviting pairs of speakers, often from different institutional backgrounds, to speak to a particular kind of &lsquo;thing&rsquo; or a theme that unites disparate &lsquo;things&rsquo;. Previous &lsquo;Things&rsquo; seminars have concentrated on the early modern period generally and the long eighteenth century in particular; this year we have taken the step into the nineteenth century, the era that brought us the mass production of &lsquo;things&rsquo;. Our aim continues to be to look at the interdisciplinary thinking through which material culture was conceived, and to consider the question of what a &#39;thing&#39; is, with the ultimate goal of gaining new perspectives on the period 1500-1900 through its artefacts.</p>
									</div>
								</div>
							</div>
						</article>
					</div>
				</div>

						<div class="span12">
							<h1>Visual Representations of the Third Plague Pandemic</h1>
						</div>
					</div>

					<div class="row">
						<div class="span8">
							
							 
						</div>
						<div class="span4 hidden-phone">

					<div class="row mb30">
						<article class="span8">
							<div id="tabs">
								<div class="tabBar hidden-phone">
									<ul>
										<li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="1" class="active">About</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="2" >People</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="3" >Advisory Board</a></li><li><a href="#" data-tab-link-id="4" >Events</a></li>
									</ul>
								</div>
								<div class="tabContent">
									<div data-tab-id="1" class="tab active">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">About</h3>
										<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>ERC-funded research project</strong><br />
2013&ndash;2018</p>

<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Visual Representations of the Third Plague Pandemic</strong> is an interdisciplinary research project led by social anthropologist, <a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/christos-lynteris">Dr Christos Lynteris</a>. The project is funded by a European Research Council Starting Grant (under the European Union&#39;s Seventh Framework Programme/ERC grant agreement no 336564). The HI of the project between October 2013 and September 2017 was CRASSH (University of Cambridge). As of October 2017 the project&#39;s HI is the <a href="https://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/anthropology/" target="_blank">Department of Social Anthropology</a> at the University of St Andrews, with CRASSH remaining a co-beneficiary until the project ends in September 2018.</p>

<p>The project will collect and analyse photographs as well as other visual documents of the third plague pandemic, which broke out in 1855 in Southwest China (Yunnan) and raged across the globe until 1959, causing the death of approximately 12 million people.</p>

<p>As Yersinia pestis spread from country to country and from continent to continent, it left behind it not only a trail of death and terror, but also a growing visual archive on the first global pandemic to be captured by the photographic lens. Rather however than forming a homogeneous or linear visual narrative, these photographic documents provided diverging perspectives on the pandemic, which, more often than not, were not simply different from region to region, but in fact conflicting within any single locus of infection.&nbsp;</p>

<p>The project&rsquo;s hypothesis is that its visual representation played a pivotal role in the formation of both scientific understandings and public perception of infectious disease epidemics in the modern era.</p>

<p>While investigating the visual record of the third plague pandemic in East Asia, South Asia, Africa and the Americas, researchers will engage in a collaborative and interdisciplinary analysis of the entangled history of the visual representation of the pandemic, taking as a common analytical ground four different but vitally interlinked aspects of the visual representation of the pandemic: &nbsp;</p>

<ul>
	<li>The Built Environment</li>
	<li>Civil Disturbance and Public Order</li>
	<li>Death, Corpses and Burial</li>
	<li>Race, Class and Discrimination</li>
</ul>

<p>For further information on the project, please <a href="mailto:plague@crassh.cam.ac.uk">contact the Plague team</a>&nbsp;or <a href="http://eepurl.com/OL4RX">sign up to the project mailing list</a>.</p>

<p>You can also visit the <a href="https://visualplague.wordpress.com/" target="_blank">Visual Plague project blog </a>for updates and news about the team&#39;s activities.</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="2" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">People</h3>
										<p><strong>Principle Investigator</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/christos-lynteris">Dr Christos Lynteris</a>, Senior Lecturer, <a href="https://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/anthropology/staff_profiles/dr-christos-lynteris/" target="_blank">Social Anthropology</a>, University of St Andrews&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Post-doctoral Research Associates</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/LukasEngelmann">Dr. des. Lukas Engelmann</a> (2014 &ndash; 2017)<br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/nicholas-evans">Dr Nicholas Evans</a> (2014 &ndash; 2017)<br />
<a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/people/profile/branwyn-poleykett">Dr Branwyn Poleykett</a></p>

<p><strong>Administrative support</strong></p>

<p><a href="mailto:sjp229@cam.ac.uk">Ms Samantha Peel</a></p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="3" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Advisory Board</h3>
										<p><strong>Advisory Board</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://unitedphotoindustries.com/about-upi/our-team/sam_barzilay/">Sam Barzilay</a>, Creative Director, United Photo Industries/Photoville Festival, New York, USA</p>

<p><a href="http://www.bbk.ac.uk/history/our-staff/full-time-academic-staff/professor-john-henderson">John Henderson</a>, Professor of Italian Renaissance History, Department of History, Classics and Archaeology, Birkbeck, University of London; Fellow, Wolfson College, University of Cambridge</p>

<p><a href="http://www.quaibranly.fr/en/the-public-institution/biographies/frederic-keck.html">Fr&eacute;d&eacute;ric Keck</a>, Director of the Department of Research and Education, Mus&eacute;e du Quai Branly, Paris; Charg&eacute; de Recherche, CNRS/ EHESS, Laboratoire d&#39;Anthropologie Sociale.</p>

<p><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/anthropology/people/academic_staff/d_napier">David Napier</a>, Professor of Medical Anthropology, Department of Social Anthropology, University College London, University of London</p>
									</div><div data-tab-id="4" class="tab ">
										<h3 class="visible-phone mt20">Events</h3>
										<p>Past events:</p>

<ul>
	<li>
	<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27212">Assembling Epidemics: Disease, Ecology and the (Un)natural,</a> 8-9 September 2017</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/27238">Photography, Alterity &amp; Epidemics: Exhibition at the Royal Anthropological Institute</a> 11 May - 30 June 2017</p>
	</li>
	<li><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26602">Techniques, Technologies and Materialities of Epidemic Control</a> 16-17 September 2016</li>
	<li>
	<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26034">Corpses, Burials and Infection&nbsp;</a>4-5 December 2015&nbsp;</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26519">Attacking Humanitarians: Ebola and the breakdown of social accommodations over bruials, political subjection, and economic appropriation in the Republic of Guinea</a>&nbsp;4 December 2015</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/26524">Mapping Contagion</a> (co-convened) 20 November 2015</p>
	</li>
	<li>
	<p><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/25544">Plague and the City: Disease, Epidemic Control and the Urban Environment</a><span style="line-height: 1.6em;"><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/25544">&nbsp;</a>5 December 2014</span></p>
	</li>
	<li><a href="http://www.crassh.cam.ac.uk/events/25872">Managing Project Data: a workshop</a>&nbsp;30 October 2014</li>
</ul>
